PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGH COURT OF AUSTRALIA RULE OF COURT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I seek leave to make a statement relating to a notice I intend to give to withdraw a notice of disallowance of a High Court of Australia rule.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —When giving notice, on 17 August 1982, of a motion to disallow the High Court Rule contained in Statutory Rules 1982 No. 77, I indicated to the Senate that the Committee was corresponding with the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia concerning the retrospective operation of interest rates on judgment debts. The Committee was concerned that the Rule doubled the rate of interest which had previously applied, with retrospective effect to 21 April 1980. Following the Committee's inquiries, the Chief Justice has now advised that the Court has agreed to amend the Rule to overcome the problem identified by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee wishes to express its appreciation of the co-operation of the Chief Justice and the Court in this matter. I therefore give notice that it is my intention, on the next day of sitting at the time for giving notices of motion, to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name for the next day of sitting, to disallow the High Court of Australia Rule of Court Amending the High Court Rules, as contained in Statutory Rules 1982 No. 77 and made under the Judiciary Act 1903.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to commend the work of Senator Lewis's Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I believe that the Committee has done a palpably valuable thing for the community and that this matter should not be allowed to go just with a whimper, without any comment. I, on behalf of my party, pay a great tribute to Senator Lewis and the various parties represented on his Committee for the work they have done in this instance.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ryan)-by leave-agreed to:

That Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in the name of Senator Ryan and relating to the disallowance of the Fire Brigade ( Administration) (Amendment) Ordinance 1982, be postponed till the next day of sitting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. What terms of reference will Mr Costigan be given to investigate the affairs of Mr Denis Horgan? Will they be made public? Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister's decision to ask Mr Horgan to stand down ? Since Mr Horgan's involvement in Treamog Pty Ltd has been public knowledge for nearly four months, why has it taken so long to ask Mr Horgan to stand down? Is it, in the Government's view, acceptable to be caught selling one company to a tax evasion promoter but not acceptable to be caught selling nine companies to two tax evasion promoters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has publicly indicated that he has communicated with Mr Horgan and that there has been communication about how the allegations that have been made in this place, and not least by the honourable senator who asked me this question, might be dealt with. That matter is still under discussion between Mr Horgan and the Government. I am unable to say at this stage what precise course of action is to be followed. With respect to the question of agreement, I assume that is raised because, as I have advised anyone who has cared to ask, Mr Denis Horgan is a friend of mine and has been for some years. He is a man who, on everything I know of him, is an honourable man who maintains extremely high public and private standards. I would not wish in any sense to leave any other impression about him. I would have to say in respect of the matters which have been raised that I regard him, on what I know of him, as a man superior to his detractors. That might explain that part of the question which asks why this has taken so long.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that because Mr Horgan has been associated with the Liberal Party he has been singled out for considerable criticism and comment for party political reasons. That has become a matter of some political significance. Clearly from the point of view of the Government it is a matter which has to be clarified and sorted out to the satisfaction not only of the Government but also of the Australian people, and that is a matter which I trust will occur quickly. The present position is that the matter is under discussion between the Government and Mr Horgan. I simply make it quite clear that on what I know of that man, as I said before, he maintains extremely high standards and I believe him to be a superior man to his detractors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Regarding the Minister's belief that Mr Horgan is superior to his detractors, did he have in mind when he said that that the Prime Minister is one of those detractors?
—I would be very pleased if any words of the Prime Minister could be pointed out to me which would enable him to be so classified.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. What research has been done in Australia on the potential of using the silicon chip as a solar cell? How much was spent on solar energy research in Australia in 1981? Is it true that Australia is a world leader in certain technology in respect of silicon chip development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There has been some development through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation laboratory in Adelaide co-ordinating the design and fabrication of Australia's first multi- project silicon chip. In addition, the CSIRO has transferred the technology for custom designing of silicon chips to potential users working in research institutions and industry. I understand that Australia is the first country in the world outside the United States of America where individual scientists and engineers have access to this technology. There are 46 individual designs represented on the first multi-project chip, including a processor for a bionic ear for deaf people, an insulin diffuser for diabetics, a new tool for on-the- spot assessment of mineral deposits and a device for improving the performance of the CSIRO's radio telescope at Parkes. There are a number of other facts that are in the brief I have from the Department of Science and Technology. I will see that further information is handed to Senator Watson.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister's reason for asking Mr Horgan to stand down, as stated yesterday, was that it is very important that statutory office holders do, and be seen to do, the right thing. Will the Prime Minister apply to the High Commissioner to London the same standards as he seeks to apply to Mr Horgan, and ask Sir Victor Garland to stand down until Mr Costigan has investigated the disposal of Stirling West, Greenbank and Frederic Salon Pty Ltd, and any other family companies which former Minister Garland declared to the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I would have thought the honourable senator would know, the basis for the matter concerning Mr Horgan is that the McCabe-Lafranchi report mentioned Mr Horgan's association with some companies which were sold to people who allegedly took part in a bottom-of-the-harbour situation. There is no such allegation regarding Sir Victor Garland. No allegation has been made publicly in these cases regarding Sir Victor Garland. So the question is entirely out of order.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it true that the carillon on an island in Lake Burley Griffin near the Australian National Gallery will not be played on the occasion of the Queen opening the National Gallery on 12 October? Is it a fact that Malcolm Williamson, Master of the Queen's Musick, who is at present in Australia, was asked to compose a piece of music for the carillon especially for that occasion? Does the Minister agree that there should be an inquiry into the management of the carillon as to how this very fine musical instrument may best be used, in view of the fact that it is not at present administered with any coherent policies or guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked a question recently about this matter and I did not have the information. It was to have been supplied to me. I hope that I can get it before the end of Question Time. If so, I will make it available.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ATOMIC TESTING IN THE UNITED STATES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is along the same lines as the question I asked yesterday. I hope that I get as helpful and as frank an answer as the answer which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle gave me yesterday and for which I thank her. I ask a similar question concerning the United States Government's tests in Nevada and the effects of those tests. Is the Government aware of the current court case in Utah where nearly 1,200 residents are claiming millions of dollars in compensation for ill health arising from tests in the 1950s and 1960s? Is the Government aware that, despite the fact that an epidemiologist at the University of Colorado estimates that in this area there is four times the incidence of leukaemia, six times the rate of bone cancer, three times the number of melanomas and twice as much brain cancer, there has been only one official cancer survey there by the United States Government since 1950? Is the Government aware of the United States Government's trenchant opposition to any claims for compensation? Will the Australian Government be as helpful as it was yesterday in using its good offices with the American Government to press for it to become more forthcoming on this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the facts as outlined in the question by Senator Chipp. I will undertake to refer them to the Minister. If the question were placed on notice a public response could be given on the matters raised within it. As far as the question of contact with the United States Government is concerned, I will refer that to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether any contact has been made or is likely to be made in view of the question which has been raised this morning.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONVENTION ON THE TRANSFER OF SENTENCED PERSONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Is it correct that the Council of Europe is expected to establish a new international agreement called the 'Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons' and that this Convention will allow foreigners convicted in one country to serve their gaol terms in their homeland? Is the Minister in a position to seek Australian participation in such an agreement? Moreover, will the Australian Government take the initiative to seek to establish this kind of agreement among the countries in our own region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is correct that the Council of Europe is expected to establish an international agreement along the lines suggested. I regret that in the relatively brief period that I have represented the Acting Attorney-General in this place I have not had a chance to catch up with what appears to be a very positive step in trying to ensure that prisoners who are imprisoned outside their own homeland are dealt with in an adequate way. It may be, of course, of real relevance to Australia, given the fact that a number of Australian citizens recently have found themselves, often in highly publicised situations, in foreign gaols and living in conditions which, I think, are foreign to most Australians. I think that is a matter of some public concern. I suppose one's concern ought to be heightened by the fact that on at least one notable occasion of which I can think there was an ultimate acquittal after a fair period of incarceration. The honourable senator raises a significant point in his question. I will ask the Acting Attorney-General to have the matter examined.

ANSWER.PARA: I say in passing that, as a federation, we probably still have some minor problems to iron out. For example, I think prisoners sentenced in the Australian Capital Territory are unable to enjoy the salubrious conditions to which they are normally accustomed as residents of the Australian Capital Territory when they are incarcerated in New South Wales gaols under conditions which are quite foreign to the lucky residents of this part of Australia, which has the highest per capita income of any part of the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer that the Government will consider taking this matter up and urgently examining it. At the same time can there be an examination of the interstate position within Australia?

—Yes. The point of the latter part of my answer was that there are, indeed, within our federal system, with its separate systems of law enforcement and separate gaol authorities, some questions similar to those which arise between different countries. I know that that is a matter which is occasionally of some controversy within Australia, although I think there are in general fairly reasonable arrangements between the States. I will also ask the Acting Attorney-General to consider that aspect of the question and let Senator Teague have a considered reply.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAXATION LAW: ONUS OF PROOF PROVISIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General aware that, as revealed by the taxation documents tabled yesterday, the Treasurer wrote to the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, on three separate occasions- December 1978, February 1979 and May 1979-seeking his advice on just one aspect of the proposed new criminal legislation, a proposal already at that stage a year old, namely, the aspect concerning the onus of proof? Is the Minister further aware that the Treasurer received on each occasion no more than a formal acknowledgment-of the kind to which we have become all too accustomed-in January 1979, February 1979 and June 1979 respectively and that it was not until 19 July 1979, seven months after the initial request for advice, that the Attorney gave anything approaching a substantive reply? Can the Minister explain how a matter of central importance, supposedly, to the Government's legislative program and taxation strategy could have been allowed to languish that way in the Attorney- General's Department for seven months, while, as Mr O'Reilly was making painfully clear at the same time, thousands of companies were going to the bottom of the harbour with the consequent massive loss to revenue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before replying in very specific terms to the question raised by Senator Evans I make the general comment that the question, like so many points made in the debate on matters currently concerning us, seems to assume that the item under examination is the only matter receiving the attention of the Government, the Attorney-General's Department and the Attorney-General at any one time. The point made by the Treasurer in an interview this morning was that at that time there was a whole series of measures being undertaken by the Government. If one looks through the legislative program of the Government from 1976 on, one finds a constant stream of legislation staunching the flow of tax avoidance which was of so much concern to both the community and the Government. I think it is important to understand that, whilst Senator Evans now talks of the millions of dollars being lost here, he raised in the Senate a week or two ago the problem of trust stripping-a matter which also was of great concern to the Government, a matter which has been legislated against and a matter in which firm action has been taken by the Government. That is but one of many examples of areas of tax avoidance which were attended to by the Government over the relevant period.

ANSWER.PARA: The advice which I have is that the letter written by the Treasurer to the Attorney-General, which letter was referred to in the question, was received in the Attorney-General's office on 2 January 1979 and, after an interim reply dated 8 January 1979, was sent to the Department, going first to the Business Affairs Division and then to the Justice Division on about 18 January 1979. I take it that honourable senators will not mind my giving the detail of this matter. I assure them that the question is not a Dorothy Dixer. To my knowledge, Senator Evans has not given notice of it, but I do have detailed advice on it. When Mr Howard's letter was received in the Justice Division, a decision had to be made on whether the Attorney-General would be asked to confirm the approach agreed upon with the Australian Taxation Office in the previous year-namely, to place the onus on a defendant to establish an innocent intention-or whether the matter should be completely reviewed. The Justice Division had been reluctantly persuaded in the previous year by the Taxation Office that in the circumstances the reverse onus approach was justified but, having regard to the Treasurer's own doubts, there was a need to review the earlier approach.

I should add that here we were dealing not with legislation which proposed merely the recovery of tax but with legislation which, unusually, imposed criminal penalties as the sanction to prevent a particular form of tax avoidance . One was looking at a situation where one was concerned about the onus of proof , not of liability to pay tax but of liability for criminal punishment. The first step was to examine the difficulties of proof that would arise in establishing, without the benefit of a reverse onus provision, the elements of the offence proposed by the Taxation Office-to be a party to an arrangement that deprived a company or trustee of capacity to pay tax, including unremitted pay- as-you-earn deductions. Discussions on this question had commenced in March 1979 with officers of the Crown Solicitor's Division. I am advised that the Taxation Office would have been informed of this review. In other words, discussion took place in March 1979 on that quite important question, which goes to a matter of civil liberties, not merely to a matter of tax liability. I would have thought that Senator Evans, if no one else on the Opposition benches, would appreciate that a point of principle and of concern is involved there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand, too.

—I am sorry; Senator Tate would also understand. I am grateful for the interjection. We have the great consolation of knowing that, if something happens to Senator Evans, Senator Tate will be there to fill the gap.

ANSWER.PARA: It was also necessary to involve and consult the First Assistant Secretary in this matter. At that time he was heavily involved in the preparation of, and attendance in Parliament for the debate on, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Bill. I suspect, therefore, that his attention was probably unduly prolonged by the verbal ministrations of Senator Evans who, I am sure, was taking a very active interest in that piece of legislation. This Bill was introduced on 8 March 1979 and debated in the Senate throughout most of the autumn session. That, again, is a reminder of the fact that both the Government and its departments seldom have their attention fixed on one item at a time. Honourable senators will recall the very intense interest in this place in the detail of the ASIO legislation because of the very important questions of civil liberties which were involved and which occupied the attention of the Attorney and of relevant senior officers for very considerable periods during that session. However, consultations with the Taxation Office continued. The Office explained the circumstances that were likely to arise. It was concluded that the 1978 approach needed to be substantially varied. Of course, it is a matter of record that the form of the legislation and the question of the onus were the subject of variation between the earlier discussions and the time when the Bill was ultimately introduced.

The alternative formula arrived at was that the basic offence was to be a party to an arrangement with the intention of reducing the capacity of a company or trustee to pay tax, or knowing that the arrangement was likely to have that effect. Evidence that the arrangement was not entered into in the ordinary course of business, or explicable by ordinary commercial considerations, and that the arrangement had reduced the capacity of the company or trustee to pay tax would be prime evidence that the defendant had the prohibited intention. However, this formula was arrived at only after there had been many consultations with interested departments and several alternative formulations had been put forward and discarded for practical and policy considerations.

In other words, yes, there was a delay of the sort which is indicated in the documents and which was mentioned by Senator Evans in his question. That delay was in part occasioned by the fact that other significant jobs were being done by some of the people concerned but also because significant questions of policy needed consideration. The consideration resulted in a different approach being taken by the Government. All of that contributed to the delay about which Senator Evans has expressed concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. It relates to access by commercial broadcasters to Australia 's proposed domestic satellites. Commercial television operators in Western Australia are fearful that the large Melbourne and Sydney based commercial stations will be able to transmit programs all over Australia, thereby making it difficult for the local stations to attract advertising revenue and to maintain a reasonable viewing audience. To some extent the same concern exists as between regional broadcasters and those in Perth. I understand that the Government has received submissions from the Perth based stations; however, some of the smaller regional stations have yet to make their views known to the Government. Will the Minister ask the Minister he represents to withhold a decision on this matter until he has obtained the views of all commercial broadcasters in Western Australia?

—I am always intrigued, in discussions of this kind, when people talk about the big four or the big three in the eastern States as if they are some kind of devils. Coming from the eastern States, I enjoy watching what they offer in the way of television viewing. But I do understand Senator Thomas' s concern about the needs of his State and about the needs of regional television operators. I am aware that at present the Minister is examining the issues which the honourable senator set out in his question. He is receiving inputs. Senator Thomas has already made it known that the Perth television channels have made submissions to the Minister. I believe that the Minister would welcome other inputs if people have views to put. Therefore, I suggest to the honourable senator that he make known to the regional telecasters to whom he referred the appropriateness of their also making a submission to the Minister. I understand that he will be examining and considering all these submissions before any decision is made. To that extent, the question is open and the course of action suggested by Senator Thomas seems to be appropriate.

—I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General a question which follows his reply to Senator Evans, in the course of which he stated that the Government had not dealt expeditiously with some aspects of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes because it was at the same time robustly dealing with other forms of tax avoidance, including trust stripping. Why, then, has no retrospective legislation been introduced at any stage to recoup the revenue lost through this blatant form of tax avoidance? Does the Minister acknowledge, as did the Treasurer in his statement of 11 May 1982, that trust stripping had been going on apace to the grave injury of the revenue-indeed, to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars? In particular, why have the matters in respect of which the special prosecutor, Mr Gyles, Q.C., may launch prosecutions or undertake civil proceedings been confined by the Government, by notice in yesterday's Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, in such a way as to exclude his pursuing the question of recovery of revenue lost through trust stripping? Why is it that the Government will not allow the special prosecutor to pursue the recouping of moneys lost through trust stripping as vigorously as we may expect him to pursue the recouping of moneys lost through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes ?

—Perhaps I should correct one small point on which I may unintentionally have caused a little misunderstanding in the Senate. I was not suggesting an exactly contemporaneous consideration of trust stripping and the measure; I was saying that throughout that period a series of matters were under consideration. I would have to refresh my memory on the timing of each of those, as to what precisely was under consideration at the time those letters were before the Attorney-General. The question of the retrospective recovery of taxation under the proposed legislation is related to the Government's attitude to the loss of revenue occasioned by conduct which was declared criminal in the 1980 legislation. It is an unusual step to take and the Government has taken it in these limited circumstances only. I will have to look more closely at the general point raised by Senator Tate in his question and let him have a more considered reply. At the moment, the intention of the Government is to restrict the recovery in the way outlined by Senator Tate in his question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Are we to understand from the Minister's reply that the special prosecutor is to be confined to prosecuting for breach of the 1980 legislation and he will not be pursuing the recovery of bottom-of-the-harbour tax moneys in respect of schemes entered into before that legislation of 1980?
—I have not seen the precise terms of reference of the special prosecutor. I would need to look at those before replying.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Northern Land Council in the Northern Territory is challenging the right to extend community government to Aboriginal communities, saying that no council established to manage community affairs has jurisdiction over land controlled by the NLC on behalf of traditional owners. An example of the Council's stand was seen last week when it boycotted a ceremony establishing a community government council at Angurugu on Groote Eylandt. Can the Minister comment on the correctness of this advice from the NLC, where it could possibly be said that it is playing a role of the servant ruling the master? Under the Aboriginal land rights legislation, land councils were set up to 'ascertain and express the wishes and the opinions of Aboriginals living in the area of the land council as to the management of Aboriginal land in that area', et cetera. If such actions are sustained, what ramifications does the Government expect, considering its policies of self-management and self- determination for Aboriginal people in communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff raises an important question. I think honourable senators will realise, having listened to the question, that the matter is complex. What has occurred is that there has been some misunderstanding of what Mr Blitner said on behalf of the Northern Land Council and what the situation is. I understand that an examination has been made of the transcripts of statements which he made on Australian Broadcasting Commission television, I believe, on 17 September, and on ABC radio over the weekend of 18 and 19 September. I am advised that what Mr Blitner said, in fact, was that no council set up to manage community affairs had jurisdiction over land controlled by the Northern Land Council on behalf of traditional owners. I think that is correct. He observed that there had been no consultation by the Northern Territory with the Northern Land Council in this matter. The thrust of his statement was that community councils, once they are set up-Senator Kilgariff talked about the one at Angurugu-cannot intrude into those areas of responsibility which have been given to the Northern Land Council in the administration of Aboriginal land conferred by the Aboriginal Land Rights ( Northern Territory) Act. Of course, Mr Blitner is correct in that statement. If land has been granted to a lands trust by the Land Rights Act, the Northern Land Council has a role in the management of that land.

ANSWER.PARA: It seems to me that there is a genuine area of overlap or uncertainty at the margin between community councils and the Land Council in terms of the management of communities and land. I do not believe that there was anything in Mr Blitner's statement that would enable one to say that community councils have no role or are not seen to have a role. I think what Mr Blitner was pointing out is that, where land was granted under the Land Rights Act, the Land Council has a role, and continues to have a role, which must be recognised and which it will carry out.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Is it the case that trading stock schemes have been a sufficiently virulent and persistent form of tax avoidance to warrant legislation in 1977, 1978, 1979 and 1981 to amend sections 36 and 36A of the Income Tax Assessment Act? I ask whether it is further the case that the Treasurer acknowledged, in a Press statement of 1 January 1981, that:

QUESTION.PARA: The problem has become very serious. The schemes have recently been promoted on a wide scale. The Commissioner of Taxation has information indicating that one promoter, over a recent period of six months, processed some $52m in trading stock through such schemes.

In view of the revenue lost through these schemes, which the Government has been well aware is large and continuing, what steps have been taken to recoup that lost revenue? In particular, why was none of the remedial legislation made retrospective to the date of first known operation of these schemes, in the same way as the Government proposes to recover tax evaded under bottom-of-the-harbour schemes back to 1972?

TALK.START.PARA: —The latter part of the question is almost specious because the Government has made it clear that it does not intend, in general, to act on a recoupment basis with respect to the various avoidance schemes which have been brought to an end by Government legislation. If the honourable senator wants a reply to the detailed matters in her question I suggest that she puts the question on the Notice Paper.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to an article in the daily Press and on radio news that the Tranby Co-op College for Aborigines in Sydney will have to close due to the lack of Federal Government funds? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the report is correct? If so, what effect will such an action have on the Aboriginal students at Tranby?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of this morning's radio broadcast which set out an allegation about a situation which Senator Lajovic mentioned in his question. I have not seen many of the newspaper reports but I have seen a statement from Senator Ryan, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, in which the same kind of allegation is made. I believe that the allegation is incorrect and I will give some figures now. I have not heard recently from Tranby Co-op College for Aborigines or from anyone else in New South Wales on this matter. My Department' s role in funding Tranby College is to pay allowances to students in eligible programs through the program called AbStudy. This money is paid; it will continue to be paid and there has been no attempt that it not be paid.

ANSWER.PARA: Since I read Senator Ryan's Press release and since I heard this morning's radio broadcast I have asked what exactly is the situation. In the year ending April 1982 Tranby students received almost $24,000 from my Department for courses that they attended at Tranby through the AbStudy scheme. For that financial year the allocation was $41,000. Approximately $52,000 has been allocated this year. The amount allocated this year for that College was in accord with the submission that we received from Tranby for the amount needed for AbStudy funding in 1982 and 1983.

As far as we are aware neither have the New South Wales technical and further education authorities nor has Tranby made any submission for funding for the College above the levels currently operating. If that is the case it is very hard to know how people can say that a decision on our behalf is going to have the effect of forcing the College to close. It may be that they have taken a management decision in light of what is available to them and they want to claim that the Department in some way is responsible for this.

It might help honourable senators to look at the sources of Commonwealth funds that go into technical and further education courses in New South Wales for Aboriginal people. There are two sources and I have figures for two financial years. Last financial year the Department of Aboriginal Affairs contributed a little more than $650,000 and this year it will contribute a little more than $ 800,000 to TAFE activities in New South Wales for Aboriginals. That is not consistent either with Senator Ryan's Press release or with the claims that have been made. Last financial year my Department spent $137,000 through AbStudy and this year it has allowed $165,000. Neither of those figures makes it possible to sustain any kind of claim that there has been a cut in funding. They do not make it easy to sustain the assertions by the Labor Party that Commonwealth funding cutbacks are responsible in any way for decisions which may have been taken in New South Wales or by Tranby College. We have provided the money for Tranby because we are aware and appreciative of what Tranby does. We have given money in accordance with the kinds of inputs that have come from Tranby. I cannot understand the assertions made in the Press. From what I can discern from the facts before me, they have no basis. I certainly cannot understand any basis upon which Senator Ryan or the Australian Labor Party would make the claims which they have made on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware that documents tabled yesterday disclose that on no fewer than 18 occasions between 20 February 1978 and 12 November 1980 the Commissioner of Taxation pleaded with the Government to take urgent action to combat tax evasion through company stripping or bottom-of-the-harbour schemes? How can the Government explain its tardy response to these urgent calls, such that it took two and half years to introduce legislation while hundreds of millions of dollars were being lost to the revenue? In view of the full and frank correspondence between the Commissioner of Taxation, the Treasurer and the Attorney-General, will the Minister now acknowledge that the attempt by those Ministers to rely on the secrecy provisions of the tax Acts was a crude and cynical attempt to avoid accepting responsibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of Senator Childs's question, I thought that the Labor Party relied upon the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which said that the Ministers could not have known. I thought that in this debate quite clearly the Labor Party had upheld the Costigan report as a paragon of virtue. That report said that the Ministers could not have known. In the period mentioned by Senator Childs this Government took many actions to overcome tax evasion, and a list of those actions is now in Hansard. I direct the attention of Senator Childs and the Senate to it. The Government was enormously active in those years, unlike the three years in which the Whitlam Government was in power, when it did nothing and when the notorious Curran scheme was running. It was known to that Government and it did nothing at all. There was no legislation on the books even though that Government knew those things.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have made it very clear that in all these matters there was a need, first of all, to get the most expert legal opinions- and there was a very great difference in legal opinions. There was a great worry about principles of the rule of law in terms of reverse onus of proof. There was a need to be sure that when we acted we acted with equity to all, and so we did. I remind the Senate that by 1980 the law had been passed that put an end to the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do we know? There are at least another nine companies you have not prosecuted since.

—The interjection asks how we know. Mr Costigan says it is so. Presumably Senator Evans has not read the Costigan report. The Costigan report states that by the action of this Government by 1980 the bottom-of-the- harbour schemes had been stopped. I point out to the Senate that the record of the Government over the years is one of unprecedented action to stop tax evasion . Indeed, the action in 1980 by the Government put an end to the bottom-of-the- harbour schemes. If there were delays, they were legitimate delays in making sure that we were acting legally, that we were not acting with inequity against people and that we were not offending the rule of law. The list is in Hansard and I commend it to Senator Childs.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce and is about dumping in Australia. Is it a fact, as reported, that the dumping branch of the Department of Industry and Commerce currently has before it some 68 complaints from Australian industry and that, notwithstanding the increased staff levels provided last year, inquiries are taking up to 12 months to resolve? Will the Government give consideration to imposing some trade sanctions against countries dumping in Australia by imposing , say, import bans for a set period? Will the Government also give consideration to contracting some of the investigatory work to private enterprise in order to speed up investigations during this period of economic recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest information which I have with respect to the present position on dumping applications is from the early part of this month. I am advised that at that time there were 68 cases on hand before the Department. That is in fact double the number of a year ago and there are signs that it is still on the increase. I would agree with the suggestion implicit in the question asked by Senator Lewis that increased concern about dumping is likely to reflect the more competitive trade conditions around the world and the eagerness of overseas manufacturers to dispose of their goods at whatever price.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister indicated to me earlier this month that he had taken steps to make sure that resources are adequate to deal with the increasing number of claims in what is an important and sensitive area for Australian industry. Clearly the anti-dumping provisions are meant to be available without delay to meet situations in which unfair competition is being experienced by Australian industries. I will ask the Minister to let me have a more up to date assessment both of the number of cases on hand and of the resources available to deal with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister seen reports from United States naval authorities that the FFG7 frigates in service or being built for the Australian and United States navies are fitted with a fire control system, the Mark 92 system, which is not capable of fighting a contemporary naval war, especially against modern air attacks such as by cruise missiles and supersonic aircraft, particularly in bad weather? Have the ships' builders also admitted this deficiency? Are reports also accurate that Australian Defence officials have stated an opposite view, saying that the system is adequate in our own ships? Will the Government see that this matter is fully investigated so that we can be assured that the most modern ships in our Navy, the FFG7 frigates HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Canberra, can fight a contemporary naval war?

—I am afraid I have no immediate information on that particular question from Senator Mason. I will need to refer it to Mr Sinclair, the Minister for Defence, and obtain a detailed answer for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the following statement by the Treasurer on 27 June 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: It was because the Government believed, on the basis of legal advice provided to it, that the then existing law was an insufficient response to these practices, that it decided to enact the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act.

I draw attention to the fact specifically that advice came from officers of the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department that the existing law was deficient for one reason or another.

Is the Minister aware that, contrary to the Treasurer's statement, the tabled documents disclose no evidence of such legal advice having been given and that the meetings of these officers, as confirmed by Mr Menzies of the Attorney- General's Department at the hearings of Estimates Committee A on 13 September, dealt only with the question of the form of the new legislation and never with the question of the adequacy of the existing laws? Is this not a case of Mr Howard misleading the Parliament and the public generally? Why was there no attempt to utilise the existing law during the tortuous gestation period of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is no instance of the Treasurer having misled the Parliament. The Treasurer in his statement of 27 June referred to by Senator Gietzelt pointed out that the advice that was given to the Government was as he stated it and nothing that he has now provided is contrary to that advice. I have nothing further to add to what the Treasurer said on that earlier occasion. If he wishes to make any further comment on the question now raised by Senator Gietzelt, I will see that that is advised to Senator Gietzelt.
—I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister explain why such legal advice has not been part of the tabled documents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It was made clear yesterday in the statement I made on tabling the documents that the Solicitor-General had considered the counsels' opinions and the other legal advice that had been received by the Government. It was considered by the Solicitor-General, after he personally examined those opinions, that it would not be proper for them to be tabled and made public. He felt that harm could be caused both to those who may be prosecuted and to those who may be proceeded against civilly or to the cause of the prosecutor or the civil complainant. He considered that in many instances both sides would be injured and that injury, in his view, could not be avoided by excising names. I think the honourable senator will remember that when Senator Evans asked for certain documents to be tabled he made the observation that he did not wish to seek documents that would be prejudicial to any legal proceedings that might follow.
—Not to individuals, just to legal proceedings. These are new criteria, and some unstated ones.
— I expect that Senator Evans and Senator Gietzelt, who raised this matter, would accept the opinion of the Solicitor- General which was quoted by the Treasurer when tabling the documents yesterday.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: When is the off-shore constitutional settlement legislation to be proclaimed and what are the nature and extent of the hold-up points at this juncture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great deal of progress has been made and all States have co-operated. It is the intention of the Commonwealth that all of the off- shore constitutional settlement legislation should be proclaimed as soon as possible. However, there is a need for completion of discussions with one or several of the States. In particular, at the moment there is a matter regarding the definition of the historic bays in South Australia. That is a matter that ought to be capable of resolution fairly quickly and when this is done I am hopeful that we will be able to make the proclamation in the very early future.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Have any representations been received from the Queensland Government in relation to the payment of excise on diesel fuel used by the Queensland Railways ? If so, what has been the Federal Government's response? If the Federal Government's policy is not altered, will the Queensland Railways in future be paying about $4m a year towards road funding through the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of what representations were made by Queensland. I am conscious that some State governments did make representations at the time of the announcement of the diesel fuel arrangements. I will check the matter for Senator Colston and see that some advice is given to him as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BUILDERS LABOURERS FEDERATION: CONSTRUCTION OF AUSTRALIAN POLICE ACADEMY

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory aware of the black ban which has been operating at the instigation of the Builders Labourers Federation on construction of the Australian Police Academy? Is the Minister aware that this action has no relationship to the conduct of the employer, John Pfeiffer Constructions, but is to extract from the police an undertaking not to interfere in any future trespass by the BLF? Is the Minister aware that at least 10, if not 15, jobs have as a result been unavailable to workers and that, by now, about 40 workers should be employed on that job? Is the Minister aware that the impact of this conduct of the union may put the viability of the employer at risk? Is the real reason for the action of the BLF more sinister? Does it fear the installation and operation of computers for police use?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm that the facts outlined by Senator Reid in her question are essentially true in that there has been significant action in relation to the Police Academy. Senator Reid draws our attention to some matters concerning the Builders Labourers Federation. I suppose it is well known that the BLF has particular ways of operating in this country. These kinds of matters have been drawn to our attention in recent times, especially in relation to royal commission reports and certain other prosecutions which are pending in Victoria. Those, of course, are matters which are now obviously extending their tentacles into the Australian Capital Territory in relation to the firm John Pfeiffer Constructions mentioned by Senator Reid. It is clear that this kind of activity is going to jeopardise jobs in the Australian Capital Territory at a time when I understand private industry, especially the building industry, in the Australian Capital Territory is concerned about its future. It is amazing to think that a union of the status that the BLF claims to have is determined to destroy the building industry in the Australian Capital Territory by this kind of action. The viability of the kind of industry that must of course be maintained in this area and throughout Australia will be destroyed if this kind of activity is allowed to continue.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the proposition put by Senator Reid in her question in relation to the police activity and the installation of computers, that is a matter about which only she can conjecture. I am not aware that this is going forward. It is consistent, I suppose, with the general proposition that anything that might be aimed at detecting crimes in all areas of public life in this country ought to be supported. Indeed the Government does support it. It is clear from some of the actions of the BLF over past years that maybe they do not support that kind of activity. Indeed that has become evident in some of the activities of the union itself. In relation to the further information sought by Senator Reid about the solution to the strife at the Police Academy, I will endeavour to get some further information for her.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the Federal Government will lose about two-thirds of its industrial relations specialists because of a departmental move from Melbourne to Canberra? Is it true that several senior advisers, including three assistant secretaries in the Industry Policy and Operations Division of the former Department of Industrial Relations , have already left the Department? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the Goverment will not allow an already appalling relationship between it and the trade union movement to become even worse because the Government cannot or will not maintain its industrial relations specialists in the Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points suggested by that question, both of which I think are points which would in fact be broadly agreed even by the honourable senator who asked the question. The first is that the administration of Commonwealth departments is and is required to be largely centralised in Canberra. The reason for that is the interaction between departments, the interaction between the Cabinet and departments and so on. There has been, since I think 1927, a process of transfer from the cities of Sydney and Melbourne to Canberra. That process was continued and may even have been accelerated by the Labor Government. In any event as I understand it, it was not a matter of partisan dispute within this Parliament. In fact, it is the view of the Government that the efficiency and effectiveness of the Department would be enhanced by locating its major operation in Canberra although, of course, it is intended to maintain elements of the Department in Melbourne, in common with other major Australian cities.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been, of course, a very important element of the Department in Melbourne until now. I understand that, as has always been the case when transfers of this sort are effected, a number of senior officers have indicated that they do not wish to transfer to Canberra. That is a matter that can be contentious at the very highest levels, right up to the High Court, I suppose. There are a number of Australians who prefer living somewhere other than in Canberra. I suppose, with my peculiar Western Australian loyalties, I am one of them. I would have to say that, yes, on my understanding there will be some loss of staff because of the transfer. That loss of staff is not in any sense peculiar. It has occurred because of other transfers, for reasons which would be well understood by honourable senators.

As to allowing this to worsen the relations between the trade union movement and the Government, I would have thought there would be pretty broad agreement in the industrial relations area that the Government has been making quite a number of positive approaches to the trade union movement. For example, the current Minister has, I think, already developed close ties with the trade union movement. He has made it a habit to visit the movement on its own ground. When he visited my own State of Western Australia I think he visited the trade union movement at its headquarters. Of course, the Government has encouraged greater communication with the trade union movement. I was one of a large group of Ministers who took part in discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and employers some months ago, discussions which were aimed at ensuring that as far as possible we had a common understanding of the problems facing Australia, including the economic situation.

There is a whole series of ways in which the Government and the Minister are promoting better relations with the trade union movement in the hope that that will assist industrial relations in Australia and, indeed, our economic management. The shift to Canberra should not be seen as something which is, in the view of the Government, in any way designed to reduce either the effectiveness of the Department or the communications which must be carried out between the Government and the trade union movement. Without reference to the Minister I can give the Senate the assurance that every care will be taken to ensure that the negative effects, which are the concern of the honourable senator who asked the question, will not occur.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CLOSER ECONOMIC RELATIONS WITH NEW ZEALAND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Although there have been many agreements and understandings reached by industry panels on both sides of the Tasman in relation to closer economic relations with New Zealand, I understand there are a number of unresolved outstanding issues which will have to be settled on a government to government basis. Is it still the Government's intention to have the agreement in place by 1 January 1983? If so, when does the Government propose to sign the agreement?

—I think it has been some months since I looked in any detail at what was happening with respect to the closer economic relations negotiations which, in an active sense, have been very much the problems of the Minister for Trade and Resources, although many other Ministers are very keenly involved, not the least being the Minister for Primary Industry because of the very substantial interests of such people as vegetable growers, fruit growers, dairy producers and so on. My understanding is that there has been no recent change in the dates which were established by the Government for entering into an agreement. I will have to check that detail and let the honourable senator have a more authoritative reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether he is aware of the letter written by the Prime Minister to the Treasurer on 15 July 1977, which was tabled yesterday, drawing the Treasurer's attention to a paper detailing a number of tax avoidance schemes, one of which was a Slutzkin scheme and that the letter stated in part:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we should be looking to appropriate legislation at the earliest possible date.

In view of the fact that the Treasurer has claimed consistently that the Government only became aware of the extent of Slutzkin schemes in 1978 and 1979, how does the Minister explain this apparent contradiction? Is it not the case that it is now clear that the Government knew about these schemes in July 1977 or earlier, but took three and a half years to pass any law against them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the letter but I am aware that a letter in such terms exists. My understanding is that both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have made detailed explanations about that matter. I will seek further information on the matter and let Senator Button know.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Hamer asked me a question concerning the Carillon. I am advised that it will not be played on the occasion of the Queen opening the Australian National Gallery for the following reasons: Firstly, the opening is to be at 9 p.m. on 12 October and will take place inside the Gallery; secondly, the Royal Military College will provide a fanfare for the opening; thirdly, the Gallery has not requested the Carillon to be played. The Department of the Capital Territory has no knowledge of whether Mr Williamson has written a piece of music for the Carillon for the opening of the Gallery or whether a request was made to Mr Williamson to do so. A clear management policy exists in respect of the Carillon. Performances of the Carillon are given each Wednesday and Sunday for the benefit of tourists and the Canberra population. Special performances are also given on particular ceremonial occasions and public holidays. It is open for inspection to the public at weekends and on school and public holidays. There is no land-line to the Woden Plaza but there is a land-line to the Civic Centre which is used to relay the Westminster chimes from the Carillon to Garema Place. In the past recitals have been relayed. However, these were discontinued because of complaints received from occupants of offices near the speakers and the poor quality of the sound reproduction.

—Earlier today I was asked a question concerning the Tranby Co-op College for Aborigines and indicated, I believe, that I had received no input from the college. That is incorrect. I have had two telegrams from Tranby indicating concern about funding. Senator Ryan said by way of interjection that she would show me certain figures. She has been kind enough to do so. We will have them studied to see whether anything in them will alter the thrust of the answer that I gave.

—Yesterday Senator Foreman asked me a question in relation to airport bus services. I am now able to provide the following information: I understand that the airlines are to withdraw airport bus services on or about 1 October. The day to day operations of the airlines are matters for their determination and are based on their commercial judgment. Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia have advised that they are negotiating with other bus operators who have expressed an interest in providing alternative services when the airline services are discontinued. They are confident that alternative services will be available to travellers requiring coach transport. TAA and Ansett have emphasised that in recent years the proportion of airline passengers utilising city coach services has decreased to a minimal level. As a result, significant losses have been incurred in providing those services.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONVENTION ON THE TRANSFER OF SENTENCED PERSONS

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I present the Committtee's report on annual reports referred to it for the years 1979-80 and 1980-81, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

PROCTEXT.PARA: As Acting Chairman of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs , in the absence of Senator Missen who is attending an Inter-Parliamentary Union meeting in Rome, I wish to table, on behalf of the Committee, its report on annual reports referred to it for the years 1979-80 and 1980-81. In tabling this report, which discusses aspects of the annual reports of a number of Government agencies, the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee is acting pursuant to the Sessional Order of 26 November 1980. Under that Sessional Order annual reports of all Government departments and authorities stand referred to the relevant standing committees of the Senate for consideration and, if necessary, for report. This report deals with the annual reports of some 18 agencies for the years 1979-80 and 1980-81. As the Committee's time and staff resources have not allowed a detailed appraisal of each report, our approach has been to assess each report in the light of guidelines set down by the Joint Committee on Publications in its 1979 report on the presentation of annual reports and to note major developments or operational problems raised by reporting agencies.

As regards compliance with the Publications Committee's guidelines, an appendix to our report illustrates in tabular form each agency's performance. Generally speaking, most agencies reported on attained a fairly high level of compliance with these requirements of a presentational nature, covering such matters as a clear statement of the legislation under which the agency operates, an indication of where the agency fits within the scheme of Commonwealth administration, the number of staff employed, a statement of the agency's budget allocation and actual expenditure, a simple organisation chart and so on.

Particularly noteworthy for the manner of their presentation are the reports of the Trade Practices Commission for 1979-80 and 1980-81. A most useful practice, which could be adopted by other agencies with great benefit, is the consolidation of suggested amendments to legislation in one section of the report rather than, as tends to happen, scatterd throughout.

The report makes three recommendations. These are on matters arising from three separate annual reports, where the Committee takes the view that issues of sufficient gravity arise to warrant the making of a specific recommendation to the Government. The first arises out of our dissatisfaction with the skimpy coverage of the activities of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General provided in the reports of the Attorney-General's Department. Although the 1979- 80 report indicates some 40 items on the Standing Committee's agenda at 30 June 1980, only eight are mentioned and none of them is discussed in detail. The activities of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General have significant impact on law reform in this country and it would be of great benefit to have a much fuller account of all items on the Standing Committee's agenda and of the stage of deliberation which has been reached in respect of each of them. Accordingly, our report recommends that the section of the Attorney-General's Department's annual report dealing with the Standing Committee of Attorneys- General should be considerably expanded. Alternatively, consideration should be given to the presentation of a separate report on the Standing Committee's activities.

Our second recommendation relates to difficulties experienced by the Commonwealth Ombudsman when paying accounts incurred by him as a result of instructing a private firm of solicitors to represent him in situations where the Deputy Crown Solicitor was already appearing for a party to the proceedings. Under Finance Direction 23/5 payment of such an account usually requires the approval of the Crown Solicitor or the Deputy Crown Solicitor and in such instances the Ombudsman has been embarrassed by the need to delay payment until he obtained an exemption from Finance Direction 23/5. Although the Ombudsman had previously sought a standing exemption from that Finance Direction as being incompatible with his statutory function, his request was rejected. In the Committee's view the Ombudsman's case for a standing exemption to Finance Direction 23/5 is very strong and we have recommended that the matter of his exemption be reconsidered.

Our third recommendation is that the Government give urgent consideration to the staffing situation in the Law Reform Commission with a view to providing the Commission with sufficient staff to properly discharge its important task of law reform. Our report outlines the drastic staffing position faced by the Law Reform Commission which, put shortly, has suffered a 10 per cent cut in its research capacity while at the same time acquiring additional functions. Such a cut must seriously impede the Commission's work program. We also draw attention to the disturbingly slow rate at which implementation of several important Commission reports is being considered by the Government. The situation is well illustrated in a table contained in the report. Having drawn attention to this problem, the Committee concludes in its report that 'in view of the extent and thoroughness of the Law Reform Commission's reports, it is difficult to think of any justification for such delays'.

The Law Reform Commission is not alone in reporting severe difficulties as a result of staffing cutbacks. The great majority of agencies discussed in the report refer to the very real problems with which they are faced as a result of government-imposed staffing constraints. These problems are often exacerbated by the additional burden of funding cutbacks. Several-for example, the Inspector- General in Bankruptcy and the Family Law Council-suggest that the situation has reached such a stage that they can no longer effectively perform the function which Parliament has assigned to them. The imposition of staff ceilings becomes farcical once it has the effect of rendering agencies ineffective, and must call into question the continuing worth of the agencies affected.

The Commonwealth Ombudsman in both of his annual reports which the Committee considered, referred to instances of disputation between him and some departments and authorities over the extent of his jurisdiction to take up matters arising out of complaints against those departments and authorities. Because of our concern we took evidence about this matter from Professor Richardson, the Ombudsman, at a public hearing on 7 September. The major problem which emerged is the inability of the Ombudsman, when faced with such a jurisdictional dispute, to take action of his own motion in the Federal Court to have the matter settled. It appears that an amendment to the Ombudsman Act to overcome this difficulty is expected soon and the Committee urges its speedy introduction and passage.

Of necessity, a report on annual reports covers a wide canvas and it is accordingly difficult to single out particular issues for mention in a tabling statement such as this. Nevertheless, the difficulties being experienced by the Trade Practices Commission, as illustrated in its sixth and seventh annual reports, give rise to some concern. Not only has the Commission suffered badly by way of continuing staff reductions, falling from a ceiling of 210 in 1977 to 160 in 1980-81, but the imposition of severe operational constraints, largely following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, has severely reduced the Commission's ability to perform its statutory functions. In summary form, these operational constraints require the Commission to be more selective in its pursuit of both consumer protection and restrictive trade practices complaints. A major effect of this selectivity will be the resolution of cases administratively rather than by litigation.

While acknowledging that court cases invariably take a long time and cost a lot in money and staff resources, the Commission points to their great advantages in influencing conduct, in settling and illustrating principles, in giving assurances to companies that wish to comply with the law that their competitors must do the same and in reflecting the policy of the Act that companies must actively avoid breaches rather than wait to deal with them after they have occurred. As Commissioner Pengilley expressed it in some 'additional comments' to the seventh annual report: 'Litigation is now of the essence of the credibility of the Trade Practices Act . . .'. It appears to the Committee that the imposition of even more constraints on the nature and level of the Commission's operations could well detract from the Act's credibility. Indeed, it must be asked at what point the sort of selectivity urged upon the Commission devolves to mere tokenism.

The Committee was not able in the time available to undertake a more thorough investigation of the matters arising out of the Trade Practices Commission's sixth and seventh annual reports. In our view, however, the seventh report in particular raises quite fundamental questions about the functions-and, indeed, the capacity to function-of the Trade Practices Commission. It is a matter of concern to us that what appears to amount to a fundamental re-ordering of the Trade Practices Act has not been achieved through legislative action but has been the product of executive fiat and purely administrative actions, and we intend to keep the situation under review.

The presentation of informative annual reports to the Parliament serves a vital purpose in keeping government agencies accountable to the Parliament and, through Parliament, to the people. The annual reports which have been referred to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, and which are the subject of the report tabled today, contain much valuable information about the processes of administration. They also point up many problems to which the Government should turn its attention. I have raised some of them in my earlier remarks. Others are discussed in the Committee's report. I commend the report to the Senate and, more particularly, to the Government, as it is in that direction that responsibility for the resolution of these matters rests. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RETAIL MARKETING SITES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chipp) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The objective of this Bill is to bring about total divorcement between petroleum companies and petroleum retail sites by 1st July 1983. The Bill is deceptively simple, which belies its far-reaching effects. In section 10 (3) of the Principal Act, I propose that the words and before 1st July 1983 be added after the word Act. The effect of this simple amendment would be that after 1 July 1983 no exceptions to the overriding section 10 (1) would be permitted and, in the words of section 10 (1), a prescribed corporation shall not operate a retail site.

The prescribed corporations are Amoco, Ampol, BP, Caltex, Esso, Mobil, Shell, H .C. Sleigh, Total and their associates. On 30th October 1978 the government announced its so-called Fife package which included the promise that oil companies would be prohibited from retailing petroleum through direct sales sites. Two years passed without government action to implement the Fife package. In 1980 I made a well-publicised statement that I would introduce a Private Member's Bill incorporating the Fife package.

Towards the end of 1980 the government introduced its Petroleum Retail Marketing Legislation, but with a crucial departure from the originally announced package. That is, the government decided that total divorcement was not necessary to achieve its objectives, and that a reduction of about 50 per cent over a two-year period in a number of sites would be adequate. Each integrated oil group was allocated a quota of site numbers. The maximum number of company owned sites allowed under the 1980 legislation was 989 for the year beginning 19th September 1981, and 401 sites for the following year. The existing legislation only goes half way. Oil companies are still involved in every level of output from production to retail sale. As the oil company sites grow individually larger, with high volume sales and low service emerging as the company-owned norm, it is highly likely that the companies will be able to command as much of the petrol retail market with 401 sites as they formerly did with 989.

The trend toward 'rationalisation' of the petrol market is continuing-less viable service stations are being closed down while the remaining stations are increasing their sales and their ability to control the market. It does not require a soothsayer to predict that this attrition will not result in the oil companies' quota of 401 decreasing. Rather, the 401 company sites would continue to frustrate the aims of the orginally announced Government package and reinforce company control of the retail market with a vengeance.

The Government's own figures, disclosed in 1980, are evidence of this trend toward 'rationalisation' in favour of oil company sites. Mr Garland, the then Minister, acknowledged that total service station numbers declined from 14,281 to 12,411 between 30 June 1978 and 30 May 1980, whereas total company operated sites increased from 578 to over 800 in the same period. Indeed, between December 1973 and May 1980, the total number of Australian service stations declined by one third-from 18,431 in December 1973 to 12,411 in May 1980.
There are three types of operation for petroleum retail outlets in the present market:
(1) Where the oil company owns the site and sells petrol direct to the public. The site is operated by a commissioned agent.
(2) Where the oil company owns the site and leases it to a 'franchisee' who buys petrol from the company and then sells it to the public.
(3) Where an independent owner owns the site, buys the petrol from an oil company and then sells it to the public.

The second groups of retailers-lessee operators or 'franchisees'-are protected under the existing legislation by certain rules which prevent the oil company- the 'franchisor'-from exploiting the retailer. The aim of these protections is to put the small businessman in a position where he can compete equally with other operators. No protection is given to the third category of retail operators, the independent owner. The theory seems to be that he owns his site and if he does not like the treatment he is given by an oil company he can change suppliers. In practice, an ill-treated independent operator is likely to be labelled a 'trouble maker' by the oligopoly and find it difficult to get sufficient supply and service from any source whatsoever.

The fact is that the continuing presence of oil companies in the retail market makes it harder for both sorts of independent operators to exist at all. The franchisees and independent owners buy petrol from the company and resell to the public. There is potential for price mark-ups here which the oil company selling direct to the public is not bothered by. The oil company selling direct can either retail cheaper or make more money from retail sales. Indeed, whereas the ordinary small business operator aims to maximise his profit, either by high volume sales or by a high margin of profit with increased services, the oil companies are not always concerned that an individual outlet be profitable. The company's primary objective is to have its refinery operating at the optimum rate of production. It is in the company's interests to ensure that retail sales correspond with optimum refinery production. Marginal or unprofitable retail outlets can be maintained by oil companies in order to boost market shares as profits are maximised within the total system.

Accordingly, there is little likelihood that the company allocation of 401 retail sites would be affected by poor market posture; an independent owner, by contrast, would be forced out of business in such circumstances. This Bill would complete the job the Government started with its 1980 legislation. Sadly, it is too late to help the thousands of service station operators who have been forced out of business since the Government first announced its intention to seek complete divorcement. But this Bill will make certain that the lessee operators and independent retailers are given a fair go in the future, that full competition is retained in the retail petroleum markets and that small businessmen are protected from the predatory pricing actions of the big oil companies.
