DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly on the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill and out of order. My colleague, Senator Walsh, who is the Opposition spokesman in this area, will speak after me and move our amendment. I will speak briefly, mainly on the determination of the States' tax sharing entitlements, as a result of which this legislation has been introduced. The Bill purports to give effect to the new per capita weights for the purpose of determining States' tax sharing entitlements agreed to at the June 1982 Premiers Conference. These weights in turn derive substantially from the inquiry conducted by the Commonwealth Grants Commission over 1981 and 1982. I have prepared a table which I believe is suitable for incorporation in Hansard. I apologise to the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) for not showing it to her. I did not realise that this matter would come on so quickly. It is a composite table showing the various existing weights, the actual relativities, the assessed needs of each State, the weights proposed and the predictions of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of the possible outcome of this weighting in 1983-84. I seek leave to have this table incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
TABLE 1: PER CAPITA WEIGHTS FOR TAX SHARING
Assessed Weights
Existing Actual Needs Proposed Possible
weights relativities (a) (by 1984-85) outcome
(a) Commonwealth Grants Commission, Report on State Tax Sharing and Health Grants 1982: Vol. 1-Main Report, Tables 7-4, 7-7.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. These new weights are to be phased in over three years commencing in 1982-83, as the Bill states. Because the changes will adversely affect South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania, there is a clause guaranteeing a minimum real annual increase for all States of about 2 per cent in 1982-83 and 1 per cent in 1983-84 and 1984-85 on top of the consumer price index rise for the capital city in each State. However, this guarantee, which will cost an anticipated $34m in 1982-83, and more in subsequent years, will not be financed by an increased Commonwealth Government contribution. Rather, it will be financed in effect by a reduction in the payments to other States within an overall entitlement of 20.72 per cent of total Commonwealth taxation revenue for the previous year. The mechanism for this nice bit of fiscal sleight of hand is the supplementary tax-sharing pool out of which the guarantees will be funded. The basic tax-sharing pool is only 20.323 per cent of the previous year's tax collections. It will be divided according to the new per capita weights as they are progressively introduced. The supplementary tax- sharing pool comprises 0.39 per cent of the previous year's tax collections and will be used first to fund the guarantees before any residual is distributed amongst the other States. Any State subject to the guarantee will receive its basic guarantee plus a share of the residual pool if its share of the residual is greater than the guarantee. Otherwise, it will receive only the guaranteed amount.

SPEECH.PARA: All this complexity essentially means that the total Commonwealth grants to the States in 1981-82 amounted to 20.7 per cent of the previous year's tax collections. The Commonwealth used this proportion, which itself is basically a matter of historical accident, as the bench-mark for the new tax-sharing arrangements. It was not prepared to spend any more than this to introduce the new arrangements, so it had to rob Peter to pay Paul. In 1979-80, the last year in which the Whitlam guarantee operated, tax-sharing grants amounted to 23.3 per cent of the previous year's tax collections. In 1980-81, grants were frozen in real terms, and declined as a percentage of Commonwealth tax collections. In 1981-82, grants were arbitrarily restricted to 9 per cent nominal growth, with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) subsequently disclosing that the States could have got 10 per cent had they bargained harder. Other additions and adjustments brought this increase to 11.4 per cent, but even some of this increase was accounted for by reductions in specific purpose grants. Under the previous formula, the increase would have been 16.6 per cent. These arbitrarily reduced grants for 1981-82 were then used as the basis for determining total allocations for the next three years of the new agreement.

The principle of fiscal equalisation as a basis of redistribution of these tax- sharing arrangements is fair enough. But it is an essential principle in a federal system such as ours that factors other than fiscal equalisation, of course, are taken into account. But the issues of what may be called horizontal equalisation between the States and vertical equalisation between the Commonwealth and the States collectively cannot be separated. The Commonwealth is to make the States bear the whole burden of readjusting to the new tax- sharing arrangements while making no new contributions to that adjustment process. This in fact means that meaningful progress towards fiscal equalisation , if that is the aim of the Government, will in fact be slow.

Unless total tax receipts grow considerably faster than inflation the guarantee will come, after two or three years, to absorb most or all of the supplementary pool. The apparent gains for the larger States may not materialise, and could do so only if the other States were to be made worse off, since there is only a fixed sum to be distributed among all the States. Each one per cent of total tax revenue implies an amount of about $400m. It would surely have been not unreasonable for the Commonwealth to divide the whole of the 20.72 per cent of receipts among the States and then fund the guarantees from its own resources. These appear likely to amount to about $200m by 1984-85, or an additional 0.5 per cent on the 20.72 per cent total. This procedure would have enabled a far more significant movement towards fiscal equalisation than that now likely. We could have made adjustments on top of that for those States that need such adjustments.

It should also be borne in mind that grants to the States are only one component of the totality of Federal-State financial relationships. These also encompass specific purpose grants to the States and Loan Council borrowing approvals. If the Government sticks to its old trick of whittling away these other allocations, some States will find themselves in fact worse off on the total equation. Recently we have seen savage cuts in specific purpose grants for hospitals and health care. Although this is part of this legislation I certainly do not want to delay its passage by going into this in detail. The States have been forced to impose higher and higher charges. The Government has cut the Loan Council borrowing programs for capital works from $1.43 billion in 1977-78 to $1 .37 billion in 1982-83-a cut of nearly half in real terms. The special infrastructure borrowing program has also declined rapidly.

Tasmania will be a particularly heavy loser from these new arrangements. It faces a fall in its per capita weight from almost 2 at the moment to 1.646 by 1984-85. In the short term, it will get some protection from the real guarantee. But what happens after 1984-85? What security is there for forward financial planning for any government in Tasmania? The whole agreement will obviously go back into the melting pot. Without the guarantee, Tasmania could be as much as $ 60m worse off by 1984-85. The other States will be not unnaturally aggrieved at having to foot this bill, as well as that for South Australia and Western Australia.

As Senator Walsh would say, we do not oppose the Bill although I believe we have an amendment to move. I think I should point out that in no way does this legislation provide the States with funds adequate to their needs nor does it adequately address the issue of fiscal equalisation if that is what we are seriously talking about. In particular, in no way does it give State Treasurers much confidence in planning for the future and it arouses uncertainties in small States like Tasmania, and to a lesser extent South Australia, about their future under these agreements. I think if we proceed with this uncertainty in the future we will exacerbate economic difficulties which the States and this country in general have faced in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Grimes for speaking when this Bill was called on somewhat earlier than I had expected. As a result I was caught in my office instead of the chamber. I shall not repeat the very good statistical assessment which Senator Grimes has given. However, I would like to make a few general comments about the Bill before moving the Opposition amendment. There are two components to the legislation which is now before the Senate-the absolute amount of money which is granted by the Commonwealth to the States and the relativities between the States of that amount of money. First of all I will deal with the absolute quantity. Senator Sir John Carrick on 27 April 1976 in reply to a question gave an absolute guarantee that payments to the States in the succeeding three years would increase in real terms by more than 57 per cent under the new federalism policy. At that time Senator Sir John Carrick was talking up new federalism with as much enthusiasm as he subsequently displayed when talking up Rundle shares. The result of both cases has been the same. Rundle shares are now selling for about 12 per cent of the price they were selling for at the time of Senator Sir John Carrick's talking up of the shares was in full flight and new federalism is dead. The Rundle project is dead; new federalism is dead. Unfortunately Senator Sir John Carrick survives as a Minister of the Crown. In real terms, grants to the States since this Government has taken office, far from increasing by 57 per cent, as Senator Sir John Carrick had given an absolute guarantee they would, have remained in some years stagnant and in some years have slowly declined. Yet Senator Sir John Carrick has the audacity to be censorious of other Ministers in other governments for alleged failure to live up to their promises.

SPEECH.PARA: Traditionally, relativities between the States, the division of whatever absolute amount the Commonwealth decides to provide, has been based on the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission with occasional or ad hoc supplementary grants to the States. For the first time, in this Bill a government has rejected the basic relativities recommended by the Grants Commission and it has done so for the basest of political reasons. The political strategy underlying the relativities which this Government has set is a desire to punish New South Wales and Victoria for electing State Labor governments. That vindictive, politically opportunistic action of this Government is the direct cause of the substantial increases in a number of State charges forced upon the Victorian Government yesterday and other increases in charges forced upon the New South Wales Government a couple of years earlier.

The obverse of the Commonwealth's punishment of New South Wales and Victoria for having the audacity to elect Labor governments contrary to the wish of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is that Queensland will be rewarded to a greater extent than the Grants Commission had recommended and the other States will fall in between. The sordid political strategy of the Prime Minister with respect to New South Wales and Victoria supplementing his vindictive desire to punish them for electing State Labor governments, of course, is that because those State governments are unjustly placed in a position where they have no alternative but to increase State charges substantially, he hopes that he can mount a campaign against the Labor Party in general pursuant to that and save Federal seats in those States which his Government would otherwise lose. Never before have Grants Commission recommendations been rejected by a government. I hope that never again will they be rejected for such base and sordid political reasons.

The Liberal Party has many firsts in addition to that. It was, for example, the first to block a Budget in the Senate. This Prime Minister was the first to establish a doctrine of ministerial non-responsibility, at least for National Country Party Ministers. Indeed, the new standard set for the first time by this Government appears to be that if Ministers are not actually in Long Bay gaol or if they have not been convicted of a gaolable offence, they are fit to remain in a Cabinet. This Prime Minister is the first Prime Minister to reject the findings of a royal commission and to attack the integrity of a royal commissioner. Now he is the first to reject the recommendations of the Grants Commission. From the day he became the Leader of the Opposition in 1975- presumably it will be so until the day he loses the next election, whenever that is held-this Prime Minister consistently has debased or destroyed the institutions which have held this society together.

As Senator Grimes said, the absolute amount granted the States under this legislation is 20.27 per cent of total revenue. It should be noted that tax forgone by the Commonwealth, tax not collected by the States, is paid for partially-to the extent of 20.27 per cent-by the States. Tax not paid to the Commonwealth is money the States do not receive because the amount granted to the States is tied by formula to total tax collections. I should like to place on record that as a direct result of the activities of people-powerful figures- in the Liberal Party the States are being deprived of revenue. One powerful figure who is well known has sold at least nine companies registered in three States to at least two different promoters over four calendar years. In one case alone the tax evaded by the sale of that company was $1.7m. Even under a government of integrity there are real problems in determining both the level of payments to the States and the relativities between the States-the division of that total payment between the States.

In 1976 and in late 1975 the Prime Minister propounded a doctrine of new federalism, the stated objectives of which were to align more closely the power to raise revenue and the responsibility for spending it. Many people, including me, believe there is a great deal to be said for that doctrine but, as always, the doctrine was sacrificed. What was stated by the Prime Minister to be a principle was sacrificed as he succumbed, as always, to short term political opportunism. Of all the damage that this Prime Minister has done to Australian society this might yet be recorded as one of the worst instances. Probably no Prime Minister in history has been in as strong a political position as the present Prime Minister was in his first term. He could have actually applied the doctrine which he espoused of tying power to raise revenue more closely to the responsibility of spending it. Any Labor government which attempted to do that almost certainly would be destroyed politically by opposition from State governments and from State based media. Any normal Liberal government would be likely to face the same problem. This Prime Minister, in his first term, had a unique opportunity to put State financial relations on a new and better basis. He had the opportunity to be a statesman. He remained a political opportunist, which he was before and which he still is. The chance was missed and, conceivably, it will never recur.

I make one point before I conclude my remarks. I do not often adopt a parochial attitude in the Senate-I think that would be acknowledged on both sides of the chamber-but I note that page 19 of Budget Paper No. 7, which is the Budget Paper that details payments to or for the States, the Northern Territory and local government, shows an estimate of the population of the States for December 1982. I note that the estimate puts the population of Western Australia 10,000 above that of South Australia. After three years of Tonkin Liberal government in South Australia the order of precedence, based on priority of the States, has changed for the first time this century. The implications of that are, among other things-I do not raise this as a frivolous matter-that next year the order of precedence will be changed in the Budget Papers so that Western Australia will precede South Australia. At Premiers conferences the Premier of Western Australia, who next year will be Mr Burke, will take precedence of John Bannon, who will then be the Premier of South Australia. The radio call signs, when established in the 1920's, again were related to precedence based on population, so that New South Wales was two, Victoria was three, Queensland was four and so on-Western Australia was six. That too should be changed to give the new status of Western Australia the recognition it is due. Likewise, the subscriber trunk dialling prefixes of 08 for South Australia and 09 for Western Australia should be reversed, as should the post codes.

I do not know what plans the Government has to deal with this situation which probably has arisen by now. The population estimates could not conceivably be so inaccurate that it will not arise before the end of this calendar year. All of those things will have to be changed if the traditional basis upon which precedence is determined is adhered to. All of that-if not all of it then certainly most of it-can be attributed to the stagnation of South Australia under its present Liberal Government.

Finally, I protest again that the relativities determined by the Grants Commission have been rejected by the Government, for the basest of political reasons. They have not been rejected before, for any reason. The direct consequence of that is that severe financial penalties are imposed on the States of New South Wales and Victoria which inevitably require those States to increase charges heavily. The Prime Minister hopes that there will be an electoral backlash to those increases which will save the seats in those States which currently keep this worthless Government in office. The strategy will fail and the Government will be swept from office. The strategy will be as dismal a failure in the long run as the grand design of new federalism was six and seven years ago. On behalf of the Opposition, I move the amendment which has been circulated, namely:

At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill deprives the States of funds necessary to meet their needs, as identified by the Grants Commission, and fails to adequately address the issue of fiscal equalisation'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Opposition will not be opposing the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 that is before us. There are one or two comments that were made by Opposition senators to which I wish briefly to respond. One comment related to the Commonwealth's refusal to accept the Commonwealth Grants Commission's findings. The new relativities were settled upon at the June Premiers Conference of this year and were based largely upon acceptance of the commission's findings. The new relativities which are ultimately to apply are the Commission's recommended relativities modified in one respect only. The Commonwealth considered that a case existed for modifying the Commission's 1982 preferred relativities in view of the Commission's assessment that South Australia and Tasmania should have a lower share of tax sharing grants on account of the above average per capita amounts paid to them under their continuing hospital cost sharing agreements with the Commonwealth. It was the Commonwealth's view that South Australia and Tasmania were entitled to those extra amounts until the year 1984-85 in view of clause 7 (1) of their hospital cost sharing agreements with the Commonwealth. That clause states that any such financial gains are not to be offset by the Commonwealth against general revenue payments to those States. Furthermore, preserving the financial gains to these two States could not be considered at the expense of the other States because the Commonwealth, and not the other States, has been the source of any such financial gain. The method of implementing the new relativities has been said to be contrary to the Commission's wishes. Further to what I have said about the hospital cost sharing arrangements, the only other aspect of the new arrangements which could be mistaken as a rejection of the Commission's findings was the decision to phase in the new relativities in conjunction with the Commonwealth guaranteeing a real terms increase in each State's tax sharing grants.

SPEECH.PARA: The new arrangements give due recognition to the magnitude of change involved for some States if the recommendations of the Commission had been implemented immediately. In fact, the Chairman of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, in his letter of transmittal, recognised that the effects on some States of an immediate shift to the assessed relativities would be quite severe. Further, it is the Commonwealth's view that the straight phasing-in of the new relativities over the three remaining years of the current tax sharing arrangements along the lines canvassed by the Commission without some guaranteed minimum growth in grants would involve arbitrarily determining the capacity of some of the less populous States to absorb the changes necessary, especially in view of the effect upon the standard and level of particular services of real term reductions in Commonwealth payments to those States. These matters were canvassed at the Premiers Conference and it was the agreement reached at that Conference which has resulted in the arrangements that are before us in this Bill.

It was also said that the Commonwealth has made no effort to assist States to adjust to the new sets of relativities. I would have to say on that matter that serious consideration was given to the contribution by the Commonwealth which would be appropriate in assisting the States in moving to the new relativities. It was considered that the Commonwealth's contribution should not only entail once again an amount of $60m made available in 1981-82 to the three more populous States in recognition of the likelihood that following the further review relativities would be adjusted in favour of those three States-now escalated to about $70m-but also should include the escalated value of the net budgetary gains to South Australia and Tasmania associated with the transfers of their railways to the Commonwealth in 1975-76. That is estimated to cost about $ 79m in the 1982-83 year.

The Commission in its report had assessed that South Australia and Tasmania should not continue to have a higher share of tax sharing grants on account of these railway transfers. It was the Commonwealth's view, however, that these benefits should not be automatically redistributed among the States but should instead revert to the Commonwealth. This additional budgetary assistance had been provided by the Commonwealth at its own budgetary expense and not by the other States. Instead of retaining this amount for its own purposes the Commonwealth determined that it could be added to the amount set aside to assist in the process of implementing new tax sharing relativities, in particular by funding the guarantee.

Some comments have been made about Victoria and New South Wales. I do not want to enter into a long discussion about them. But I do want to say that both New South Wales and Victoria are better off in 1982-83 under the new arrangements than they would have been if a review of the tax sharing relativities had not been undertaken by the Grants Commission. If such a review had not taken place the Commonwealth would not have provided a total of $60m additional assistance to the three more populous States in 1981-82 in recognition of the likelihood that the relativities would be adjusted in favour of these States. In fact, New South Wales is $20m better off and Victoria is $28m better off than they would have been if the review by the Grants Commission had never been undertaken. Furthermore, both New South Wales and Victoria are better off now than they would have been had the Grants Commission relativities, as modified, been immediately implemented and had the Commonwealth's contribution of about $149m been completely excluded from the tax sharing pool and used instead directly to assist the less populous States in their process of adjustment to the new tax sharing relativities. I know that all States find difficulties in adjusting to their own budget requirements the raising of revenue and the expenditure which is their responsibility. I think it is fair to say that at the Premiers Conferences fairly wide debate on these matters is held.

A further question which I think was raised by Senator Grimes concerns what would occur after the 1984-85 year. As I understand it the States and the Commonwealth have not yet made any decisions with regard to this, but I feel quite confident that these matters will be raised at an appropriate time so that whatever are to be the arrangements after the 1984-85 year will be put in place so that there will be the sort of certainty for planning that undoubtedly is required at the State level and, indeed, at the Commonwealth level.

The Opposition has moved an amendment. The amendment is not acceptable to the Government. It is based on a misunderstanding of the nature of the Grants Commission inquiry and report. The Grants Commission was required to examine the relative distribution of a given level of tax sharing funds among the States. The Commission did not and nor was it asked to, identify a specific level of funds necessary to meet each State's needs. Furthermore, the amendment is incorrect in presupposing that the Grants Commission's assessments were rejected by the June 1982 Premiers Conference. The fact is that the new relativities ultimately to apply are the Commission's preferred relativities modified only so that South Australia's and Tasmania's hospital cost sharing grants do not adversely affect their tax sharing grants. It was the Commonwealth's view that South Australia and Tasmania were entitled to those extra amounts until 1984-85 in view of clause 7 (1) of their hospital cost sharing agreements with the Commonwealth which states that any such financial gains are not to be offset by the Commonwealth against general revenue payments to those States. Since the principle of fiscal equalisation was fundamental to the Grants Commission's recommendations and since the new arrangements essentially embrace those recommendations, it follows that the new relativities contained in this Bill are directed at pursuing this important principle. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-by leave-agreed to:
That Senator Mulvihill be granted leave of absence for two months on account of absence overseas on parliamentary business.
Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present a ministerial statement concerning a review of Commonwealth administration which was delivered today by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

In my statement in Parliament on 21 September 1982, concerning the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, I referred to breakdowns and administrative failures in a number of areas of government administration over the last decade or so. These matters are obviously of the gravest concern to all Australians: Efficient and effective public administration is vital for maintaining the kind of Australia that we want for our children. The people of Australia have a right to expect good, honest, efficient and effective administration, and the Government is determined to take every possible step to ensure that this occurs. In each instance where there has been a breakdown in Public Service administration over recent years the Government has made an appropriate and prompt response to remedy the deficiencies that have come to notice. But the Government believes that it is vital not only to remedy deficiencies in administration as they become known but also to look more broadly at the Public Service and the demands upon it in order to do whatever can be done to prevent such breakdowns from occurring.

The general health of the Public Service, including its efficiency and management, must be a matter of the highest concern for Government. The Public Service-broadly interpreted to include departments and authorities-must be equipped with the kinds of management structures and tools which will enable it to deliver Government programs effectively to the people of Australia, and which will allow it to keep up with new technology and with changes in community and business requirements and attitudes. The Government believes there is a question as to whether the Public Service, as presently organised, has the management tools, the flexibility and the capacities to meet the challenge that presently exist and that lie ahead. Departments and authorities must be able not only to meet the demands of today, but also to anticipate the demands of tomorrow.

There are three evolutionary changes which present challenges to public administration at the present time. The first is changing technology and the so- called information explosion. The Public Service needs to be able to cope with the significant technological changes and the growth of information which have been and will be taking place, including the relevance of computer technology to public administration. Governments and their agencies must be able to be responsive to, and to take advantage of, new methods of gathering, processing and applying information. But it is not just a matter of applying new technology to growing information. It is also a matter of knowing what information is needed-and in what form it is needed-to enable departments, authorities and ministers to carry out their functions efficiently and effectively and also a matter of being able to take practical steps for satisfying these requirements.

The second challenge is posed by the increasing demands on the public sector flowing from a greater involvement by government in areas such as social welfare , health, education and national development, plus many other areas of concern to the community. The increased scope and the wider activities of government obviously enlarge the responsibilities of public administration enormously and create difficulties in relation to adequate communications, accountability and control.

The third challenge, I regret to say, arises from a deterioration in what I might call the 'business ethics' of a minority. There was a time when the administration, in its relationships with business, could assume that a high degree of trust was appropriate. The Service did not have to be geared to handle cheating on a large scale. Of course, there have always been those in the community who have been prepared to get away with as much as they can without too much regard for what might be regarded as honour, let alone the law: But in the past this has not been an element which has put significant stress on the Service itself. As recent events relating to taxation, meat substitution and health schemes show only too clearly, there are those outside the administration -and I stress that they are very much a minority-who are prepared to act ruthlessly in what they perceive as their own interests, without regard either to the interests of the community or to the observation of the law. It is that third challenge, which has been particularly instrumental in leading the Government to the view that at this time there is a need to look closely at the management tools, the flexibility and the capacity of the Service as presently organised. There have been a number of administrative breakdowns which have flowed from the Service's inability to respond speedily and adequately to the challenges posed by those who seek to behave unethically or even illegally. Those in the community who cheat on their obligations to others or attempt dishonestly to evade the law, whether by evading taxation or meat inspection regulations or any other laws or regulations, not only bring dishonour on themselves but also impose real strains on the Public Service of this country, and on the social and economic fabric which is vital to our way of life.

It is a particular tragedy that small numbers of failures by individuals who have fallen to temptation to give favours or seek favours have brought the Public Service into a degree of disrepute. The Public Service itself wants to respond to the criticisms that have been made against it. They are not criticisms that are made against the Service as a whole but the Service as a whole is touched by them. Many public servants feel that the reputation of the Service has been badly tarnished by recent happenings and that it needs to re- establish the high reputation that it feels it has earned in the past.

I would not wish what I am saying to overshadow the very solid work that is being done in the greater part of the Public Service: It is unfortunate, but inevitable, that attention tends to be focused on what is wrong, not on what is right. But I have said before and I say again now that I have enormous respect for the dedication and management skills of the Public Service, and for the people who staff it. By world standards we have a Public Service of high reputation. But the Public Service cannot live on its reputation and in particular it must meet changes with adequate administrative responses. It is clear that the Service needs to be a jump ahead of those who seek to frustrate it in carrying out its proper functions.

Both to assist in achieving this and to create the opportunity for the public to be reassured about the future of the Service, the Government proposes that there should be a report to the Government on aspects of the performance of the whole Commonwealth administration. Both through an examination of the underlying causes of major administrative deficiencies of the kind that have occurred in recent years, and through a wider examination of management skills and management structures throughout the Commonwealth Government departments and authorities, the Review of Commonwealth Administration is to be asked to examine , report on and make recommendations in relation to the requirements for an efficient and effective Public Service in Australia; and in particular to identify the demands and pressures placed upon the Public Service, and the mechanisms, procedures and management structures which are required to enable the Public Service to carry out its functions, implement government policy and deliver programs effectively and efficiently to the people of Australia.

The Review in particular should take into account the need for the Public Service to have high standards and good morale; the need for the Public Service to provide the professional managerial component of public administration; the need for the Public Service to possess management skills and to develop management structures capable of meeting and responding to the challenges of an increasingly complex business, economic and social environment; the need for the Public Service to provide constructive and imaginative policy advice, and adequate mechanisms for ensuring the effective implementation of the Government' s policy decisions; and the need for accountability of the Public Service while maintaining the concept of a non-political career Public Service based on merit, capable of providing effective support for Ministers in relation to their administrative and policy-making responsibilities.

Although the Review involves a major examination of Commonwealth administration , it is not intended that it should be a protracted one. The Government understands that in the interests of a timely completion of the Review, in some areas of concern it may be possible only to provide indications of further work that will need to be done to achieve the ultimate objective. It is not proposed that this Review should repeat the work done by the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, which was the first comprehensive review of government administration in over 50 years and had the broadest possible terms of reference. Nor is it proposed to duplicate the particular work done by parliamentary committees, by the Auditor-General, by the Public Service Board and by management consultants and others who may have examined, or be examining, particular aspects of the Service. This Review is to focus specifically on the management framework, the constraints which face public sector managers, and the challenges that they will have to confront in the future. The Government is looking for a report, from people of high reputation in their own business fields, which assesses what they see as the deficiencies, the problems and the appropriate remedies.

Mr J. B. Reid, A.O., has accepted the role of chairman of the review. Mr Reid is Chairman of James Hardie Industries Limited, Vice Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd and a Director of BHP and Barclays International Australia Limited. He was a member of the Administrative Review Committee in 1975-76 chaired by Sir Henry Bland and a member of the inquiry into the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in 1978. He has been also a member of various other government bodies and currently is Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Mr Reid will be assisted by Sir Ronald Elliott, and Professor John Rose.

Sir Ronald Elliott is a director of Brambles Industries Limited and International Commodities Clearing House Limited. He is the former Managing Director of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. Sir Ronald is also a member of the Council of Administrative Staff and a Fellow of the Australian Institute of Management. Professor Rose is Sidney Myer Professor of Commerce and Business Administration at the University of Melbourne, and since 1976 has been a consultant in my private office. All three members of the Review are obviously well qualified for the task, and the Government is grateful to them for accepting this most important role.

The Review will have full access in all areas of government administration-to see and consult with whoever they determine, whether from inside or outside the Public Service and statutory authorities. The administration will have an opportunity to explain its task and its methods of carrying it out and, also, the nature of the constraints which distinguish Government administration from the business world. People from outside the administration, with substantial and established reputations in the business world, will have an opportunity to say what they think the Public Service should be doing-and here the Review would be looking no doubt for positive and realistic guidance capable of being put into practical effect.

The inquiry will be assisted by a small secretariat, headed by Mr H. B. MacDonald, Deputy Secretary in the Department of Administrative Services. Mr Reid has indicated that he would expect to be able to report before the autumn sitting of the Parliament.

As I stated earlier and as no-one in this House would deny, the people of Australia have a right to expect good, honest, efficient and effective administration in the public sector. With the assistance of this Review of Commonwealth Administration the Government is determined to see that they get it .
REVIEW OF COMMONWEALTH ADMINISTRATION
Terms of Reference

To examine, report on and make recommendations in relation to the requirements for an efficient and effective public service in Australia; and in particular to identify the demands and pressures placed upon the public service, and the mechanisms, procedures and management structures which are required to enable the public service to carry out its functions, implement Government policy and deliver programmes effectively and efficiently to the people of Australia.
The Review in particular should take into account:
the need for the public service to have high standards and good morale;
the need for the public service to provide the professional managerial component of public administration;

the need for the public service to possess management skills and to develop management structures capable of meeting and responding to the challenges of an increasingly complex business, economic and social environment;
the need for the public service to provide constructive and imaginative policy advice, and adequate mechanisms for ensuring the effective implementation of the Government's policy decision;

the need for accountability of the public service while maintaining the concept of a non-political career public service based on merit, capable of providing effective support for Ministers in relation to their administrative and policy- making responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This statement, brought down under the letterhead of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), is a pathetic statement. It is really rather sad, if one may allow some degree of emotion in politics. I want to make a few brief comments about the statement to illustrate that point. Since this Government was elected to office there has been a lot of talk by the Prime Minister-words, words, words-about the importance of an efficient, honest Public Service of integrity. I do not need to quote to the Senate at any length the sort of statements which have been made over the years by the Prime Minister in relation to that issue. It is probably sufficient to say that in 1978 he spoke of the degree of integrity and efficiency required by his Government in relation to the Public Service. On 12 March 1978 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore the integrity and honesty of government. As long as I lead the Government there is no way known that anything less than the highest code and practice of public administration will be tolerated.

That was a promise which he said was made as a prime plank of the Fraser Government's election in 1975-on the question of restoring to the process of Government integrity and honesty and the highest standards of public administration. It is somewhat sad and pathetic, as I say, in September 1982 to have the Prime Minister, caught as it were with numerous examples of alleged Public Service inefficiencies and deficiencies, now saying that he will conduct a review of the Public Service to see how it can be improved. The terminology of the proposed review is the most extraordinary aspect of all.

I refer briefly to some aspects of the statement by the Prime Minister to illustrate that point. Of course, this Review of Commonwealth Administration in Australia arises out of the fact that this Government has been caught in numerous inefficiencies in relation to the collection of revenue. It has been exposed by Mr Justice Woodward's inquiry into the meat industry, by the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd scandal, indeed by a number of scandals which have plagued it from its inception but more recently have been revealed in a more dramatic way.

As a response, the Prime Minister says: 'Everything will be all right; we will now conduct a review of public administration in Australia'. The first point to be made about that statement is that it is just not credible. For seven years this Government has said the same thing-that it is committed and dedicated to efficiency and honesty in public administration. Why should this statement be more credible than any of the others which have been made?
I wish to refer to some of the particular absurdities. The Prime Minister stated:
There are three evolutionary changes which present challenges to public administration at the present time.

It is instructive to consider what these three changes are. The first that he identifies is changing technology and the so-called information explosion. Really, the Prime Minister displays monumental acumen in now discovering that there is a need to consider the information explosion and changing technology as a matter relevant to the Public Service of Australia. It is quite extraordinary because it was this Government which set up the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia, which has hundreds of pages of advice and information about the effects of the information explosion and new technology on the Public Service. When the Myers Committee reported to the Parliament the whole of its report was pigeonholed by this Government. Nothing has been done with regard to any of the recommendations of the Myers Committee in relation to the effects of technology on the Australian Public Service.

The Prime Minister identifies the second challenge to public administration as being: '. . . The increasing demands on the public sector flowing from a greater involvement by government in areas such as social welfare, health, education and national development, plus many other areas of concern to the community'. I take it that this is Malcolm Fraser's equivalent of Brideshead Revisited; we might call it the razor gang revisited. There is now a discovery of the growing involvement of government and demands placed on the public sector by all of these areas such as social welfare, health, education and national development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is Sebastian?

—It is probably Senator Townley. I note a lot of interjections from New South Wales senators. Perhaps they have been listening to 'Brunswick Heads Revisited'. The point I make is that in April 1981, as part of the well- recognised stunt now known as the razor gang but then pompously called the Ministerial Statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the same Prime Minister had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We intend to establish major reviews into a number of significant areas of Commonwealth activity in order to further tighten administration and achieve a more efficient and effective service.

The whole message of the so-called razor gang-which, as we said, right from the beginning, was a stunt; that is transparent now-was that Public Service administration had to be tightened up. It had to be more efficient and more effective. A ministerial council was to be established to deal with all such questions. In addition, the size of the Public Service was to be cut, certain functions were to be transferred to the States and other functions were to be transferred to private enterprise. That statement was made in April 1981. Eighteen months later the Prime Minister, in this razor gang revisited statement , talks about the increasing demands on the public sector because it is more involved in areas such as social welfare, health, education and so on. He adds that this imposes additional responsibilities on public administration, accountability and control. They are the first two challenges that the Prime Minister talks about as being challenges to the standards of public administration.
In regard to the third challenge he says:
The third challenge, I regret to say, arises from a deterioration in what I might call the 'business ethics' of a minority.

He adds that there was a time when the Administration could rely on business ethics, but now the time has come when this unhappy Administration can no longer do so. Thus, the three scapegoats for this pathetic inquiry are established-the third being a group now identified in the business community by the Prime Minister whom he was pleased to refer to a couple of weeks ago, in his electorate broadcast, as 'recipients of stolen money'. I have always taken the view that tax evasion is the ultimate development of private enterprise. I have always taken the view that government in this country is best served by a balanced development of the economy and a balanced development of government services so there is a relationship between the public and private sectors. What we have seen is an explosion of activity in the private enterprise sector in the tax avoidance industry.

Quite apart from these sorts of specific criticisms one can make of the absurd grounds for the statement being made, there is also, as I said, the element of scapegoat philosophy in this whole statement. Nothing under the Fraser Government is the responsibility of the Government. Bertolt Brecht once wrote a marvellous passage about the Weimar Republic in Germany in the 1930s. He said that the Government had lost confidence in the people; the Government had decided to dismiss the people. That could be said with validity about the Weimar Republic in Germany and it could also with validity be said about Malcolm Fraser 's Government of 1982. The Government has lost confidence in the people; the Government has decided to dismiss the people. The Government has decided to dismiss the Public Service in the sense that it is saying that these people are responsible for all the problems. The Government has decided to dismiss the opinions of Mr Justice Woodward, a distinguished royal commissioner, when they criticise a Minister of this Government. One can go through a whole range of areas in which there is this chronic inability to accept any responsibility.

I do not like to remind the Senate of these boring, sordid things but when this Government was elected after the events of 11 November 1975 it was elected on the promise and on the assumption that it would do better. Seven years on, growing older and older, the story looks a bit sad because in none of these areas has the Government done better. The economy of the country is in the worst state it has been in since the 1930s. The administration of this country has been exposed as being in the worst state it has been in for many years. One could go through a whole range of areas relating to that.

If there is to be an inquiry into public administration and public administrators are to be blamed for the manifest deficiencies of this Government , it is incumbent upon us to remind the people of Australia and this Parliament of what those deficiencies are. Of course, it all stems back to the fact that a public service can be efficient and creative only if it believes in the Ministers of the Government who are responsible for leading it, who are given the responsibility by the Constitution of administering departments, of putting forward policies. If a public service believes in its leadership then that public service will respond.

But what has happened here in Australia now that it is said that the Public Service is largely to blame for these things? Look at the reports of various Government instrumentalities about what this Government has done to the Public Service over the years. Look first of all at the Auditor-General's reports for the last two years. The Auditor-General goes through department after department and identifies inefficiencies which are a direct result of Government policy. The Auditor-General identifies in particular inefficiencies in the Australian Taxation Office, in the Bureau of Customs and in a number of other departments. Look at the reports of the Commissioner of Taxation for the last four years. One would think all of this stuff about the Taxation Office not being able to carry out its function was new. It is not new at all. The reports of the Taxation Office indicated in 1977 and 1978 that it could not do what it wanted to do about tax avoidance and evasion in Australia because it did not have the staff. In its 1978 report it said that nothing had happened as a result of its request for additional staff. Look for example, at the reports of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the effects which Government policies have had on it , particularly in relation to staff. Again there are instances of staff ceilings imposed by this Government costing a body such as the Australian Broadcasting Commission more because it has had to put work out to contract, which has been more costly. Look also at the reports of Telecom Australia, which organisation complained that as a result of the arbitrary imposition of staff ceilings in pursuit of an ideological commitment of this Government it has not been able to carry out its functions effectively and well, particularly in the provision of new telephone services in the country and outer suburban areas of the big cities of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane.

One can go through all these reports and find documentation of inefficiencies in the Public Service directly related to this Government's policies. I said yesterday that these things go to the top. They go to the top because if we are to have good, efficient and honest administration that administration needs to look to the leadership of this country to guide it. Of course that is where the failing is.

I reminded the Senate a minute ago of the sort of double-talk that has gone on over this issue over the years. Let me make the point again that when the razor gang was established last year we were promised as a parliament, and the people of Australia were promised, a continuous review of government administration. That has just not happened and if it has happened it has produced no results at all. As I said in this place yesterday, and as I say again, if one wants proof that the leadership of this country is the problem which creates difficulties right down the line in public administration, there is no better authority than Mr Peacock, the former Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Foreign Affairs, who made some very clear statements about this at the time of his resignation from this Government. In his statement of 28 April 1981, he simply made this point:

By reposing too much power in the Prime Minister, the system of collective responsibility within the Cabinet is destroyed; the responsibility of Cabinet to Parliament is abandoned; and the very democratic process is placed in jeopardy.

It is placed in jeopardy, all right; it is placed in jeopardy by the conduct of this Prime Minister. He refers in the statement put down today to the problem of cheating on a large scale developing in this country. There is plenty of evidence that the Prime Minister is the biggest cheat on a large scale in this country. I am not referring to money matters when I say that. Right from the start of this Government there has been a lack of leadership on moral issues and on issues of public probity steming from the office of the Prime Minister. We had the despoiling of conventions beginning in 1975 and now in 1982, this week, we have the Prime Minister attacking the umpire, the royal commissioner Mr Justice Woodward. Three years ago it was good enough for him to say that the Government had no choice but to accept the recommendations of a royal commissioner. Last night he was indulging himself with great double-talk about the Liberal Party being the party of fairness in Australia. Fair to whom? It has been very fair to tax avoiders and evaders over the last seven years. But in fact rorts have been tolerated and incomes of ordinary people, pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, have declined in real terms although the Government persists in trying to demonstrate otherwise.

The living standards of this country over the last seven years since the present Government came to power have gone down the hit parade every year compared with those of other countries. People are now waking up to where the big cheat is coming from. Ultimately, the Prime Minister cannot escape responsibility for the erosion of trust to which he refers so much.

A further point is the centralisation of power in the Prime Minister's own Department, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Many of the problems of the Public Service stem from that, as Mr Peacock identified in his resignation speech. What we have in the Prime Minister's Department is a mini- Public Service shadowing all other sections of the Public Service. Plenty of honourable senators will know that that is a cause of great concern in many departments of the Public Service. In a sense, if public servants want to get something done, they have to try to supplant the senior officials of their own department and get into the mini-Public Service of the Prime Minister's Department. The effects of this on morale in other departments are enormous.

I want to reiterate the points I seek to make. This is a pathetic statement. It is an illustration of this Government's absolute despair after all these deficiencies in its own administration have been revealed. It is a record which would be disastrous for any government, and it is disastrous for the process of government in Australia. We shall never do anything significant in this country until we have a public service which is working at maximum efficiency and until we have a system of government which is believable to the ordinary citizen. The system of government under Malcolm Fraser is not credible and not believable to the ordinary citizen any longer.

Secondly, we have these attempts at windy rhetoric over the years to try to paint this Government as a government of efficiency. The last such effort was the razor gang in April 1981, when the rhetoric was totally contrary to the rhetoric now put down in this statement today. Thirdly, we have government imposed policies which, in many cases, have destroyed the morale and efficiency of the Public Service. Now, after all this time, we have an inquiry set up as a sort of pre-election stunt, in case the Prime Minister wants an election this year, in which it is said, 'We are doing something about the Public Service'- just as the Government is going to do something about tax avoiders, it is said, and about recovering money by retrospective legislation, it is said; although no one believes it. These things are all being said as pre-election stunts-'We are getting the house in order. Everything will be all right in the future. The last seven years may have been horrible, disastrous and miserable for the average Australian, but we are getting things in order now and we are looking forward to a rosy future.'

If there is an election this year, it will occur because the Prime Minister knows that this country's economy is an abysmal mess and will be worse next year . If there is an election this year, it will be because the Prime Minister fears further revelations from royal commissioners about his own administration. There will be more reports on that. These are the reasons which lead to this sort of statement being made. It is a totally hypocritical exercise. It is cynical. I am sad to say that it is also abolutely pathetic. The terms of reference of the inquiry are ludicrous in the way in which they lay down reasons for the inquiry taking place at all. I do not want to say an more about it. It is a transparent sort of document. It will not wash anywhere but in the minds of a few loyal senators, from Warrnambool, or some such place, who think that everything that the great man does is still all right. But as I know from my conversations around this Parliament, there is a growing disbelief about that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur in large measure with the remarks of Senator Button. The Australian Democrats are glad that a committee like the Review of Commonwealth Functions has been appointed. We agree with the objectives stated. However, we are more than a little uncomfortable with the implication that the responsibility for recent debacles lies essentially or solely with the Public Service, and not with the Government. That is clearly the inference in regard to the appointment of such a committee. Although three distinguished men, Mr John Reid, Sir Ronald Elliott and Professor John Rose, have been invited to serve on the Review Committee, I am bitterly disappointed and I find it incomprehensible-it is an act of stupidity on the part of the Government-that no member of any Public Service trade union has been included or offered a position on this committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government talks about worker participation. It says that Senator John Siddons's Bill on industrial democracy is a step in the right direction. Yet in relation to an inquiry into the Public Service, what does the Government do? It brings in three outsiders to comment and to criticise, within a limited framework as Senator Button has suggested, and it does not appoint a person such as Mr Paul Munro, the Secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, a very learned and very able person, even to protect the interests of the public servants in the in camera sessions of the committee. I should have thought that it would be sheer common sense to say 'Let us create good will and good public relations; let us get the co-operation of the Public Service in this matter', and that that would have demanded a senior trade union official being included in the committee. But such a person will not be there.

I give one example of how a senior trade union official from the Public Service would help. When the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) came to power in 1975, he said, 'We will put a ceiling on the growth of the Public Service'. I have a political persuasion which would be similar to yours in this matter, Mr Acting Deputy President. That is, the growth of the Public Service ought to be strictly controlled and there ought to be a very strong audit on its growth. But one of the silliest things to do is to say, 'Right, there will be a one per cent increase over the next year, irrespective of what department is concerned'. I have canvassed or been canvassed by public servants in my old department, the Bureau of Customs, at airports and at seaports. They have said to me 'Senator, we have given it up. We have given it away. We are dedicated, honest public servants, trying to stop contraband coming into this country, trying to control the entry of drugs at our seaports and airports. But how can we do it? Our staff has been cut and the workload has been doubled or trebled'. They have given it away. Morale is shattered. Thats one of the reasons why we have had problems in the Customs department.

A trade unionist, Mr Paul Munro or someone similar, would be able to go to the Committee and say 'One of the problems here has been a silly act by the Government. Let us attack the problem in that way and get the view of a few officers who are a rung or two down the ladder to find out why these problems exist'. We have had relative cuts in social security staff at a time when the number of unemployed has risen astronomically. Surely that would indicate the need for more social security staff, not less. Hence, disenchantment, loss of morale and loss of efficiencyy, will finally rebound on a Minister. These are the sorts of things that I would have hoped such a committee could find out. Because of this omission, I hope that Mr Reid and his two colleagues will intimately consult members of the Public Service trade unions.

I am suspicious about the motives for the appointment of this committee, as is Senator Button. I sense a feeling of disquiet in this building at the moment. One can feel it at Question Time. Inordinately few Government senators were here for Question Time this morning and all this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many are here now?

—I am not talking about now because I am not the most enthralling speaker in the Senate and I do not normally draw a great crowd, but Question Time normally does draw a full house. I am not accusing Government senators of a lack of diligence; I just believe that there is a feeling of such hopelessness and helplessness among them that, instead of coming into the Senate for Question Time, they have decided to do something important-to open their mail or to call their wives--
—Or have a cup of coffee.

—Or to have a cup of coffee. There is a feeling of despair. One gets the feeling that the country is, if one can use a metaphor, like an aircraft-is is in a spin, totally out of control, with no one on the flight deck . I hope that it will not be interpreted that the appointment of this Committee will fix up all the ills that beset the country at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the various reports that have come down. Although they do point a finger at certain public servants they point fingers very heavily at certain Ministers. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and his Department have taken virtually no action. Similarly, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has not acted for 12 months or more after receiving advice from the Australian Taxation Office. I pay a tribute to Mr O'Reilly, the Commissioner of Taxation. From the scanty evidence that we have had a chance to look at so far and the papers that have been tabled he at least comes out of this with great credit. He has been pushing for action on tax 'avoision'-that may be a suitable word to coin. The fault in this area does not lie with the Public Service; it lies squarely with the ministry and Ministers. Does any honourable senator suggest that Mr Nixon has acted promptly or efficiently? Can any honourable senator say that successive Ministers for Health have acted zealously to protect the millions of dollars which are being ripped off by a few unscrupulous doctors? Does any honourable senator suggest that Telecom Australia is an efficient organisation? Its arrogance and inefficiency are being allowed to perpetuate by a series of incompetent, inactive Ministers who do not seem able to grapple with the problems of their department. If the thrust of the appointment of this Committee is to divert attention from the Government it will not wash with the Democrats and I am sure that it will not wash with the people.

If the general health of the Public Service-I am using words from the Prime Minister's statement-is of the highest concern to the Government, why has it taken almost 12 months to deal with the proposed Public Service Acts Amendment Bill? It has been before us for 12 months. It is urgent. It is a crucial Bill for the morale and efficiency of the Public Service. I have issued a statement containing certain amendments that I propose to move after consultation with the trade unions of the Public Service. I understand that the Australian Labor Party will move amendments for similar reasons-to improve the Bill. But again the Bill has been taken off the business sheet. It has been on and off for 12 months. It came on last week-it appeared briefly on Tuesday and now it has disappeared again. Is the Government going to proceed with it? If not, why not? This is an area in which some consequential or significant improvements in the morale and health of the Public Service could be tackled.

It is true that the challenges, as described, facing the Public Service, are great, but they are not less than those facing private enterprise. Clearly there is a need to make management structures more flexible, more responsible and more participatory. There is hardly a need to establish an inquiry to do that. For decades private enterprise has worked towards greater worker involvement in management decisions, but in this activity the Government has chosen to disregard the experience of the private sector. It is true that our society has become more materialistic and some individuals more greedy. To what extent has the Prime Minister contributed to this with his confrontationist style and the economic and social policies of his Government which have tended to make the rich richer and the poor poorer?

I agree with the statement that the Government has basically a good Public Service-it has an excellent Public Service. I had a fair bit to do with it from time to time when I had the honour of administering 10 portfolios. There are still great men in the Public Service, men such as the late Sir Alan Carmody and many others-I single him out because I was close to him and knew of his loyalty, persistence, dedication and brilliant mind. One could mention many others-Sir John Bunting is another. Men of that quality are still in the Public Service. But I do not know when they see their Ministers these days. It is a catch-22 situation. The country is facing enormous problems on many fronts. I am sure that the efficient senior members of the Public Service have propositions to put to their Ministers to cure, or at least allay, those problems, but when can they see their Ministers? I understand that there is a continuous meeting of Cabinet in this building. I believe that one started last night at about half past eight and continued through the night until about midnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder what that was about.
—I am sure that the Ministers were not addressing themselves to the basic problems confronting the nation. I am sure they would have been--
—It could have been one of about six things.

—I would have put the number higher than six. One could well ask: What are we going to do about the Costigan report? Who can we send Costigan after next? What are we going to do about the meat scandal? Will Mr Sinclair's problems surface again? What problems does Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd have in store for us? One crisis that has not even hit the deck yet-I wish the Australian Labor Party would take the initiative; if it does not, we will-is the Medibank fraud.
—We are on to it.
—I hope that the Labor Party is on to it because as far as I know there is no Minister that we can get on Medibank. I hope that that is not the only criterion--
—The PAC is handling it quite adequately.
—I am delighted to hear that. I have great confidence in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I hope that its report will hit the deck reasonably soon, at least before the next election.
—There will be an interim report in November.
—I repeat: I hope we have it before the next election.
—That is up to you.

—I understand that it has nothing to do with me, the Democrats or the Labor Party. I understand that one of the items on the agenda at last night' s Cabinet meeting was whether Mr Fraser, in a blind panic, might take the country to an election before the beginning of December this year. If that happens, the excellent work that the PAC is doing will not be of any use. That is why I suggest to Senator Watson that he expedite the work of the Committee in bringing to light the Medibank frauds. I feel sorry for the Ministers involved. I fee sorry for the public servants who must feel frustrated because they cannot get decisions out of Ministers. With Cabinet meeting almost constantly on crises , how can a public servant get a fundamental discussion with or decision from a Minister? He gets it on the run. If one starts taking decisions or asking Ministers to make decisions on the run, one gets bad decisions. Let us look at a few of the problems the Government has. I refer to the incompetence of the Australian National Line and the dreadful, catastrophic state between here and Tasmania--
—That is because it is a statutory corporation.

—In answer to Senator Watson's helpful interjection, it is still ministerial responsibility. A strong, able Minister for Transport could fix that up in 12 months. I am sure a person of Senator Waton's calibre, dedication and drive would fix up this inept body, the ANL, in a flash. I do not want to give Senator Watson the kiss of death but I wish him all the best. The rather insignificant little decision as to what sort of aircraft carrier we have to buy is also lying in wait to be contemplated. How can a government in this situation sensibly make a decision as to whether we should buy an aircraft carrier or something else? I understand from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) that we have 50,000 illegal immigrants in Australia, with suggestions that we are going to deport the lot of them. That is not a decision a Minister takes on the run; 50,000 human beings are involved. These are fundamental problems and I know from my experience that problems of this magnitude have not even been contemplated by Cabinet in the past six weeks because Cabinet has been obsessed with these tremendous trifles.

SPEECH.PARA: How did the bagman of the Liberal Party in New South Wales raise $2m in a matter of six weeks? I think that that is a fascinating question which means that we desperately need public funding of political parties in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Terrible.
—You cannot cast aspersions on that.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask Senator Townley and Senator Watson, because they are two very honest men who have never taken a dishonest dollar in their lives: Are they prepared to stand up now and give me a guarantee that not one dollar of that $2m that Mr Valder raised in New South Wales for the Liberal Party in a matter of six weeks came from someone who had benefited from a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme?
—We cannot give you that guarantee.
—Of course they cannot give that guarantee but the bagman knows where it came from and the bagman must have access to the Liberal Party hierarchy.
—Who is the bagman?

—The bagman was Mr John Valder who is in fact President, or former President, of the Sydney Stock Exchange and who is quoted as saying, honest man that he is: 'Any donation you get for a political party bears its cost'.
—Order! Senator Chipp, I ask you to ignore the interjections and address the Chair, please. I appreciate what you are trying to do.

—I try to be courteous to your friends, Mr Acting Deputy President , and they encourage me. Unemployment is reaching crisis proportions. This morning's newspaper states that in the United Kingdom one in every seven people is unemployed which means, I think, the highest level since the last Depression, or the highest level ever. The silicone chip is around the corner, threatening to throw hundreds of thousands of Australian workers out of work in the next six or seven years. We have some maniac down in Tasmania about to dam the Franklin River. We have the worst drought in our history--
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I find that most objectionable to my friend, Mr Gray. I presume Senator Chipp means Mr Gray?
—Order! Senator Chipp, the Standing Orders provide that you must not reflect on a member of another parliament. I ask you to withdraw.
—I did not name anybody.
—It was perfectly obvious to whom you were referring , Senator. I ask you to withdraw.
—If Senator Townley wants to identify his friend as the maniac, that is his problem, not mine.
—He is compounding the felony. Why don't you ask him to withdraw unconditionally or else kick him out?
—Order! Senator Chipp, I ask you to withdraw your reflection on a member of another House.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you, Senator Chipp; will you please proceed?

—I will refer to him as a man of doubtful intellectual capacity. I wonder whether Mr Gray's friend would find that offensive. This man of doubtful intellectual capacity wants to dam the Franklin River, which is clearly a Federal Government responsibility. I refer to the worst drought in our history, a nuclear fallout causing cancer and leukaemia and other forms of disease. The housing industry is in a shambles. Interest rates are at the stage where small businesses are going to the wall. The list is endless and one would well say: ' Why can't the Government contemplate these problems instead of stumbling from crisis to crisis?'

SPEECH.PARA: We agree with the terms of reference on page 4 of the submission. But we note a glaring omission-the relationship between the Public Service and its political masters and the lines of responsibility and accountability. Surely that is the weakest link disclosed by the recent scandal. The report of the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration is mentioned but the well- regarded and highly competent report of Dr Peter Wilenski, based on the New South Wales Public Service with general application, is omitted. As I have said before, we are pleased with members of the review, but again we express our disappointment that no member of the Public Service trade unions has been included. I notice that Mr Reid, who is a man of great action, has indicated to the Government that he plans to put down a report before the autumn session of Parliament. Mr Reid and his colleagues have set themselves a daunting task. I wish them luck in their endeavours.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF THE CROWN SOLICITOR'S DIVISION OF THE ATTORNEY- GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

DEBATE.TITLE: INDICATIVE PLANNING COUNCIL FOR THE HOUSING INDUSTRY

PROCTEXT.PARA: 1982 Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the report of the Indicative Planning Council so I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report indicates clearly the worsening plight of Australia's home building industry, with dwelling commencements falling off dramatically in the second half of 1981-82. In relation to South Australia, the report states:
The continuing low level of building activity has resulted in the closure of some manufacturing operations.
This has meant that many building materials now have to be supplied from interstate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of papers has expired.
—Could I ask when it is anticipated that time will be made available for these particular papers to be discussed?
—That is a question for the Senate.
—I am just asking for some guidance. Do we have any idea of when , or not?
—I am unable to answer that.
—The Minister is unable to advise and I am unable to advise.
—Will it be possible to deal with them later on in the day or is the program too difficult?

—I understand that the arrangements were made through the usual channels. I cannot say whether there is any time available later in the day for discussion of the papers. I understand that honourable senators can still give notice, by using an old fashioned procedure, that the Senate take note of any or all of these papers, if they so desire. Could I suggest that the honourable senator open up discussion with the Whips and see what can be arranged.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED FRUITS EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 September, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of the first reading of the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill 1982 to express my concern that a Minister in this place has made it quite clear on a number of occasions that he just does not understand at least part of his portfolio.
