I refer, of course, to the Min ister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick. I should like to think that perhaps he is just being poorly advised but I suspect that he just does not want to know about some issues that cause me some heartburn. I be lieve that he is guilty of making some of the most outrageous statements in this place regarding both thorium and monazite and the danger of both substances. Perhaps the only comparison I can make is with the Minister for Health in Western Australia. He seems to know as little about the subject as the Minister for National Development and Energy. Mr Jones, Minister for Mines in Western Australia, a colleague of the Minister for Health in Western Australia, Mr Ray Young, has indicated also that he knows very little about the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that when I first raised in this place the issue of monazite mined at Capel-a newspaper report was published in Western Australia-one of the senior advisers to the Minister for Health in Western Australia made a ridiculous comment. Following my statement that, because high radio activity tailings had been used as a ramp at a dairy, perhaps it was possible that milk had be come contaminated, I was rather shocked to have a very senior official in the Department of Health tell me that cows do not eat monazite. I know that they do not eat monazite. I am rather surprised that the official obviously thought that they had to eat it for their end product to become affected. The Minister did not contradict him at that time and I do not believe that even to this day he understands that we do not have to eat monazite to be irradiated in some way; nor does a cow need to eat monazite in order to have its milk affected. I am reasonably certain that Senator Sir John Carrick knows that much but I am not sure that he knows a great deal more than that.

A few weeks ago-I am sure honourable senators will recall the occasion-Senator Mason stood in this place and spoke about the safe transportation of radioactive materials. At that time he raised the issue of both monazite and thorium. A little later on that same day Senator Sir John Carrick came back into this chamber. He apologised for not having been present when Senator Mason expressed his concern in relation to these matters but proceeded to answer some of the points raised by Senator Mason. He also said that at some stage in the future we should have a full scale debate on things nuclear. I should like to think that that opportunity will arise at some stage. One of the things that he said was this:
The short answer is that thorium in itself is not an explosive material.

That statement is almost true. Thorium does need to be processed before it becomes an explosive material. I quote Professor Phillip Jennings, associate professor in physics at Murdoch University. He said:

Thorium is used in breeder reactors to produce uranium 233 which can be used in nuclear reactors or in nuclear weapons. Both the United States of America and Canada have researched this 'thorium cycle' and have pilot breeder reactors in operation using thorium as the breeding material.

So we have a situation in which monazite becomes thorium becomes uranium, for breeder purposes particularly. Therefore it can be considered to be a fuel and is recognised as a fuel. I will make this point later in my speech. In actual fact it was recognised in this country, as long ago as 1948, as being a nuclear fuel. It was banned from export because of that very reason.
The National Energy Advisory Committee, in report No. 2 entitled 'Australia's Energy Resources: An Assessment'-one presumes that this comes within the Minister's own Department-said this:

Thorium cannot be used directly as a nuclear fuel but is transmuted into uranium 233, a fissile material with characteristics similar to uranium 235. Increased demand could result if thorium is extensively used as an alternative material (instead of U238) in certain types of thermal reactors.
The report further states:

Prototype high-temperature reactors (HTGR) with thorium in their fuel elements are operating in the U.S.A. and in F.R.G. Several countries including Japan, have reactors using thorium at the planning or construction stage. The only commerical HTGR using a uranium-thorium fuel cycle commenced operation in late 1976 at Fort Vrain, Colorado, U.S.A. This reactor has a design capacity of 330 megawatts and reloads will require 3 tonnes of thorium annually. The use of thorium in other breeding systems is at an experimental stage, but the nuclear breeding characteristics of thorium and the nuclear fuel properties of uranium 233 are well understood.

I have already made the point that the Minister did not quite answer the questions raised when Senator Mason discussed those problems that he found with both monazite and thorium. Senator Sir John Carrick went on to say:
There are no exports of thorium from Australia. I make that perfectly clear. Thorium is a component which typically contains around 6 to 7 per cent monazite.

I am prepared to accept that that was a slip of the tongue but it has appeared in Hansard. What the Minister actually meant to say was that monazite is a component which typically contains around 6 per cent to 7 per cent thorium, not the other way round. But I want to repeat the first part of the Minister's statement. He said:
There are no exports of thorium from Australia.

Once again I find that that statement is not quite true. Senator Mason was talking about the export of monazite. The Minister chose to talk about the export of thorium. Whether he was deliberately trying to confuse the issue or not is something I will not argue at this stage. The point is that the concern expressed was related to the export of monazite. The Minister said that we do not export thorium. No one has claimed that we do export thorium, but we do export monazite which typically contains 6 per cent to 7 per cent thorium. The Minister also said:

Monazite exports from Australia have been permitted under the Customs ( Prohibited Exports) Regulations only when the stated use of the monazite is for the extraction of rare earth elements, a non-nuclear use.
I am quoting directly from the Minister's statement in Hansard.

I draw the attention of the Senate to an article in the Daily News on 10 August 1982. The banner line states: 'Western Australia in back-door nuclear deal'. The sub-heading states: 'A Daily News Inquiry finds a loophole in our safeguards treaty'. I do not intend reading the entire article but I will read excerpts from it. I seek leave to have the article incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can it be shown?
—No, it cannot. It is a simple newspaper report. I am sure there will be no difficulty.
—Senator, could I suggest to you that the article be passed to the Minister in charge of the Senate and you may seek leave later on.
—There are a number of statements in that article that bear repeating. For instance, the opening paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australia is selling nuclear fuel--
I stress that it is nuclear fuel-
to Europe and America through the back door.

And the Federal and State Governments say they don't know about it. Daily News investigations in Europe and Australia have uncovered the story of the nuclear fuel about which the public has not been told.
The cargoes are shipped from Fremantle through gaping holes in Australia's nuclear safeguards.
The fuel is thorium 232, which has been used in European nuclear power for more than 10 years.
In converted form it becomes uranium 233 which could be used to make nuclear warheads.
The thorium comes from the radioactive mineral sand monazite, mined at Eneabba and Capel and shipped to France.
The Western Australia companies exporting monazite are Allied Eneabba, Westralian Sands Ltd, Associated Minerals Consolidated Ltd and Cable Sands Pty Ltd.
As a little footnote and perhaps by way of rubbing salt into open wounds the articles states:
Allied Eneabba last year won a Federal Government export award for outstanding performances.

I do not know whether the public in Australia would agree that that company should have won an award for doing a back-door deal without any nuclear safeguards being applied to what can be considered a nuclear fuel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should a company use monazite when it can get uranium much more cheaply?
—Because it is a different type of fuel. That is what the honourable senator obviously does not understand.
—Yes, but it is far more expensive.

—The honourable senator can involve himself in the debate if he wants to but I ask him not to take up my time, which I suddenly find has diminished rather drastically. I understood I had half an hour in which to speak ; I suddenly find I am down to seven minutes.
—You have 15 minutes.

—I will accept that. Now that I have had drawn to my attention the fact that I have only 15 minutes I will need to be very quick with what I have to say. The two investigative reporters, Frazer Guild and Jim Maher, have brought this very important issue to the attention of the people of Western Australia. However, unfortunately things that happen in the West are not very often repeated in papers in the East.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the Minister said that there are no exports of thorium from Australia. He went on to say that monazite was exported only when the end use was a non-nuclear one. That newspaper report will show the Senate that the end use is not for the rare earth elements; the end use is to power a breeder reactor. Perhaps just briefly, to answer Senator Thomas' question, the reason, of course, is that something like 13 tonnes of thorium annually is needed to reload a nuclear power station whereas much more is required if uranium is used. That is part of the answer to the question asked by Senator Thomas.
I want to touch briefly on the aspects of health which I consider to be one of the most important-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, if you wish I can now ask whether leave is given for the incorporation of the text of the newspaper article in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Western Australia is selling nuclear fuel to Europe and America through the back door.
And the Federal and State Governments say they don't know about it.
Daily News investigations in Europe and Australia have uncovered the story of the nuclear fuel about which the public has not been told.
The cargoes are shipped from Fremantle through gaping holes in Australia's nuclear safeguards.
The fuel is thorium 232, which has been used in European nuclear power for more than 10 years.
Shipped
In converted form it becomes uranium 233 which could be used to make nuclear warheads.
The thorium comes from the radioactive mineral sand, monazite, mined at Eneabba and Capel and shipped to France.
The Western Australian companies exporting monazite are Allied Eneabba, Westralian Sands Ltd, Associated Minerals Consolidated Ltd and Cable Sands Pty Ltd.
Allied Eneabba last year won a Federal government export award for outstanding performances.
A political row is still rumbling on inside the ALP over future uranium deals with France, a non-signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
And senior officials of Euratom, Europe's monitoring agency on the nuclear industry, ducked Daily News questions on nuclear safeguard agreements with Australia.
Euratom's safeguards director is Mr William Gmelin.
When he was pressed on specific agreements between Australia and France over monazite deals, he said:
''Please, I would rather not answer without making inquiries.
''Even then I may not be able to tell you.''
But the nuclear connection is clear.
It starts in France with the giant chemical company Rhone Poulenc.
The company extracts the thorium content from monazite.
The company has been selling the thorium under strict security to West Germany for use in two nuclear power plants.
Some Western Australian thorium is also used in a reactor in Colorado the French say.
And uranium extracted from the monazite is sold to the French Atomic Energy Commission.
Monazite is a restricted export. The Federal and Western Australian Governments should know where the end product is going and its final use.
But they don't, they say.
Western Australian mine workers, rail workers and waterside workers do not know they are handling nuclear fuel.
The Minister for Mines, Mr Peter Jones, told State Parliament on May 4 that he understood there was no current use of thorium for nuclear purposes.
But last week the Daily News saw hundreds of thousands of thorium-uranium fuel elements stockpiled in a West German nuclear fuel manufacturing plant near Frankfurt.
The thorium came from Western Australia.
Three thousand tonnes of thorium have been extracted at Rhone Poulenc's La Rochelle plant, on the French Atlantic coast, since 1972.
Each year between one and two tonnes has been sold to the leading West German nuclear fuel manufacturing company, Nukem, near Frankfurt.
They make the tennis ball-sized thorium-uranium fuel elements used to power a 15-year old experimental reactor at Julich, near Cologne.
It supplies fuel for Germany's national electricity grid.
West Germany has poured $1 billion into a giant reactor which will use the thorium provided by Western Australia.
In Colorado in the U.S. the St Vrain reactor runs on thorium-uranium fuel elements made by the General Atomic Company.
General Atomic has ordered thorium from Rhone Poulenc and two American firms.
In Paris, Rhone Poulenc's marketing development manager, Mr Phillippe Poirier, said the company was under no obligation to tell Australia what thorium was being used for.
That was a matter for the Australian monazite producers and the Australian Government.
The embarrassing possibility is that the Australian Government hasn't been told .
Senior trade commissioner at the Australian Embassy in Paris is Mr Rod Hall.
He took part in negotiations over safeguard agreements 18 months ago but did not remember any mention of monazite.
''That's not to say it wasn't there. It may have been somewhere in the small print but I don't recall it,'' he said.
''It's an interesting one. You'd better check it out with Canberra.''
In Canberra, a Department of Foreign Affairs official said nuclear safeguards were ''basically primarily and exclusively directed at uranium.
Safeguards
''No one is using the monazite for nuclear purposes.''
A Department of Trade and Resources official said: ''No country has yet succeeded in using thorium as a nuclear fuel-to our knowledge.
''There is no research work being done in this area.''
The official said that for nuclear safeguard purposes ''the mineral has to be cleared by chemical analysis, country of destination, name of end user, end use and quantity.''
Close contact between the French and Australian governments over nuclear power issues makes Australia's apparent ignorance over the thorium nuclear power link all the more astonishing.
But there is no doubt in the mind of Mr Yves Coupin, director of Gas, Electricity and Coal and the Ministry for Research and Industry in Paris.
He told the Daily News: ''Nuclear safeguard agreements between Australia and France deal purely with uranium.
''We will need much more uranium from Australia and negotiations are now going on to bring this about,'' Mr Coupin said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for that consideration. I simply make the point that whilst the Minister for National Development and Energy has said that we do not export thorium and we do not export monazite unless we know that it is wanted only for its rare earth elements, we actually find in the National Energy Advisory Committee report No. 2 the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The export of minerals containing thorium compounds and alloys is prohibited without the approval of the Minister for National Development.

So in fact he has been signing documents permitting the export of this material, which is highly volatile once it has been converted, in the belief-and he is still trying to convince the Senate of this-that the export of these mineral sands is only for their rare earth elements. In response to Senator Mason the Minister said:

Thorium ore such as monazite and thorium ore residue is not subject to International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards and the export of monazite is fully in accord with Australia's nonproliferation treaty. The IAEA Australian safeguards agreement would apply to thorium only if it were concentrated as a source material.

The article in the Daily News clearly indicates that when officers of Federal Government departments were questioned they said, and I must admit that State government department officers also said, that it did not come under any international or Australian safeguards. I mentioned earlier that monazite was banned from export as long ago as 1948. This also came out of the NEAC report No . 2, which states:
In 1948 when thorium in monazite seemed likely to become important as a possible source of nuclear energy--
I stress the words 'nuclear energy'-
the Commonwealth Government banned the export of mineral sand concentrates containing more than 0.5 per cent monazite.

What we are talking about at this stage is mineral sand concentrates with 0.5 per cent monazite when in fact the monazite that is being exported contains typically, in the Minister's own words, 6 per cent to 7 per cent thorium. So we are now seeing a much more concentrated product being exported with the authority of the Minister for National Development and Energy.

As I said earlier, I have some doubts as to whether in fact the Western Australian State Government is prepared to do anything. I know darn well that the Federal Government is not prepared to do anything. Honourable senators will remember that in February this year I raised the problems that were being experienced with the high level radioactivity tailings from monazite mining in the town of Capel. At that time, in a question in this place, I was informed that it was not a Federal Government responsibility-it was a State Government responsibility. When I got back to Western Australia and I found the situation that had occurred there, I immediately, because it was a radioactive substance and because we are constantly being told that things nuclear come under the Federal Minister, sent an urgent telegram to the Minister requesting that the least that he could do was to have members of the Atomic Energy Advisory Committee visit Capel to establish what could be done in the best interests of the people who live there. The Minister responded that it was purely a State matter.

I believe that in the short time that has been available to me I have established that what we are talking about is not just monazite and not just thorium but a potential nuclear fuel for which we as the Federal Government are responsible. If the Minister for National Development and Energy adopts the same attitude as the Minister for Health in Western Australia, who is rapidly becoming known as the Minister for dangerous substances, all I can say is that the people of Western Australia as well as the people in the rest of this country will have to start applying a great deal of pressure to make sure that this Government comes up with the answers to which they are entitled. The answers should not be hidden away as they are-a fact that has been established by Ernest Sternglass in his book 'Secret Fallout-Low-level Radiation from Hiroshima to Three-Mile Island'. I would recommend that every member of the Senate take this book home and read it, except that I have the only copy available from the Parliamentary Library. It is worthwhile reading. I certainly suggest that the Minister for National Development and Energy should be the first to read it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is timely to make a constructive contribution on the subject of taxation. In that spirit I wish to take this opportunity of a first reading debate to speak on the potential of consumption expenditure as an alternative taxation base to income. Recent parliamentary debate on the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-the Costigan report-and recent media debate on retrospective taxation have again raised the whole question of the inequity of Australia's taxation system. This inequity was largely the subject of my first speech in this place a little over one year ago. I pointed to the disadvantage of the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer vis-a-vis the self-employed. I pointed out that this resulted from the emphasis in Australia on the taxation of income. Most forms of tax avoidance, therefore, rely on minimising income, as defined by the Income Tax Assessment Act, and accumulating wealth through a different channel, either capital or some other non-taxable or reduced-taxable benefit. From the very simple family partnership through to the most sophisticated scheme, that is the purpose. As a result, taxation of income has very much become a taxation of wages and salaries with an inequitable burden being placed on the PAYE sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Additionally, most forms of tax evasion involve non-disclosure of income. Perhaps the most significant area is in what is referred to as the cash economy. Morally, the recipient of goods or services obviously should not accept a 'lower price for cash' arrangement. However, it is difficult to condemn a PAYE taxpayer for doing so when he is already being inequitably treated by the system. In fact , he is, of course, simply compounding the problem. The evader particularly benefits because of the overemphasis in our system on income tax as compared with the majority of taxation systems in the Western world. A step in the right direction quite simply is a better balanced tax system with less emphasis on income tax.

In February, in relation to last year's sales tax Bills, I argued the need for greater indirect taxes and less direct as a means of combating both tax avoidance and evasion. I said I would prefer a comprehensive indirect tax such as a value added tax but would support an extension of our more narrow indirect wholesale sales tax. The problem last year was that there were not corresponding reductions in income tax and therefore the legislation was not correcting an imbalance. This year with an increase in sales tax there have been reductions in income tax, and this restructuring I applaud. It is, however, only a start.

The Budget also aimed to strike at the cash economy with a commitment from 1 July 1983 for a system of deducting at source an amount of tax in respect of certain payments for labour and services. It may reduce some evasion, not avoidance, and if I am right in saying that the cash economy thrives on small payments by parties who do not make those payments in the course of business, it might not be very successful. The discussion paper referred to in the Budget asserts that evasion is concentrated in certain areas, in particular industries, and that identification which is still going on will be published as soon as the examination is complete. I await that publication with interest. It will in no way, however, redress the bias in the system towards income tax and the damage thereby caused which I have more fully detailed on other occasions. Perhaps it is time for more dramatic change.

Professor Peter Groenewegen believes that whatever the theoretical justification for a progressive income tax, its practical implication and operation has left it beyond repair. Writing in the Australian Financial Review in June of this year Groenewegen had no doubt about the state of the personal income tax system. He said:

My diagnosis of the problem is that the personal income tax is so sick in this country that it is beyond recovery. The patient's illness was induced, if I may continue the metaphor, because it was overworked.

If, indeed the personal income tax is so sick as to be beyond recovery, what alternative direct tax could be used? A number of major overseas studies undertaken in recent years have examined the feasibility of a direct consumption expenditure tax as an alternative to, or to operate in tandem with, existing systems of progressive income tax. It would be a comprehensive tax on consumer expenditure. In other words, the people would be taxed on what they consume or take out, not on what they produce or put into the stream of production of goods and services.

The concept is not new. It was supported by Lord Kaldor in his work 'An Expenditure Tax' in 1955 as more equitable and more efficient than income tax and not nearly as difficult to administer as often thought. He saw its history commencing with Hobbes 'Leviathan' 300 years ago, taken up by John Stuart Mill who saw income tax as a discouragement to thrift and enterprise and supported by such economists as Alfred Marshall, who saw it as a Utopian goal, and Irvine Fisher. It received revised interest when the United States Treasury put before Congress in 1942 a proposal for a progressive spendings tax as its principal suggestion for war finance. It was tried in a limited way in Ceylon and India but actual experience under modern conditions has been absent to date. In fact, Professors R. Musgrave and T. Musgrave in 'Public Finance in Theory and Practice ' were able to refer to it as 'still a new and exciting idea'.

It remained in the wilderness of taxation theory principally because it was considered too difficult a system to implement. Three major reports, however, have questioned that assumption. The United States Treasury report 'Blueprint for Basic Tax Reform' in 1977 and the United Kingdom's Institute for Fiscal Studies report 'The Structure and Reform of Direct Taxation' chaired by Nobel laureate, Professor Meade in 1978 both suggested that such a tax would be a feasible and desirable alternative to income taxation. At the same time, a study prepared for the Swedish Government Commission on Taxation, without reaching a final position, recommended that the Government continue the investigation of the expenditure tax as an alternative to income tax.

In Australia, no such examination of the feasibility of implementing expenditure tax has yet taken place. Rather, proposals regarding taxation of consumption have remained locked into the consideration of indirect tax options. The failure of the existing system calls for a serious examination of alternatives, including expenditure tax. Under an expenditure tax system, taxation would be levied when the consumer utilises his income by consuming it. How then is income consumed calculated? Income would include the taxpayer's ordinary income received in the form of wage or salary, proceeds from the sale of assets, dividends, interest and loans. From that sum would be deducted purchases of investment assets such as shares or government bonds, outlays incurred in the earning of the taxpayer's income and net savings undertaken in that year. The net amount remaining would constitute the consumption expenditure or income consumed-that which the taxpayer has withdrawn from the pool of common resources-and would be liable for tax.

Many advantages are claimed for the expenditure tax. First, unlike most common consumption taxes which are indirect in their incidence and may reduce the relative tax burden of the wealthier sections of the community, expenditure tax is direct and, therefore, can be made more, less or just as progressive as our current system of income tax. Second, as the expenditure tax has a broader base, the income is treated more equally than under a progressive income tax. Income consumed and therefore taxed could, for example, have derived from capital assets. All consumption is taxed equally, irrespective of its origin. As such it is argued that the operation of the expenditure tax would lead to less distortions and complications than in our current income tax system. Third, contrary to income tax, expenditure tax maintains its neutrality in times of inflation as it automatically taxes real values of consumption expenditure--

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it do to inflation? Would you take that up?

—I will take that up later. Fourth, the advantage most commonly cited in favour of expenditure tax is that saving is encouraged by being excluded from taxable consumption. Thus the double taxation of, say, savings bank accounts is eliminated. This, it is said, would enhance the possibility of increased personal and corporate savings enabling a greater flow of funds to financial institutions to be used for housing finance and investment activity. It is argued that it could help the social service system in that it helps those saving to help themselves. A growing income would enhance one's ability to provide for a time of retirement, illness or unemployment. Furthermore, because the tax treatment of investment and saving decisions is the same, a choice between different forms of investment and savings remains uninfluenced by considerations of tax effects, thus increasing taxation efficiency. I ask honourable senators to contrast that with the different taxation effect under our current law of, say, investment in a superannuation fund as opposed to a bank account.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifth, it is argued that expenditure tax would counter tax avoidance. No form of general tax would fully eliminate avoidance schemes, but as I indicated earlier, a high proportion of avoidance derived under income tax arises from the difficulties of distinguishing income and capital items or from using tax shelters such as companies and trusts. Under an expenditure tax regime such opportunities would disappear. Sixth, personal income tax has an inevitable bias against fluctuating incomes. Progressive expenditure tax would not penalise the receipt of a large lump sum by, say, an author of a bestseller unless he spent his earnings all at once. So long as earnings were kept in the form of savings and only drawn gradually and steadily over a period, marginal rates could be kept quite modest.

Finally, it is argued that as a policy instrument an expenditure tax is a more effective means of implementing desired economic policy objectives. It would effectively govern levels of private consumption. Increases in expenditure tax rates would have the desired effect of increasing public revenues and encouraging private savings. It is said that income tax would require much greater rate changes for the same effect and that it has a less certain effect on consumption levels. Obviously, the system must have disadvantages or at least perceived disadvantages not to have been introduced at least in the more adventurous tax planning nations. One major and immediate difficulty would be that of educating the taxpayers as to the way in which an expenditure tax system works. It would require a different kind of thinking, especially as taxpayers have gained considerable familiarity with the workings of income tax. Professor Lodin suggests that the greatest difficulty in implementing an expenditure tax would be:
Getting the taxpayers to arrive at a proper understanding of the tax effects of , above all, their consumption behaviour and to take account of these effects in their economic planning.

There would be difficulties and problems in the operation of an expenditure tax. Imputed consumption such as housing and home grown food would have to be examined to determine whether it should form part of the tax base. An appropriate averaging scheme may be necessary in the case of housing so that prohibitive tax burdens are not imposed at the time of purchase. Similar considerations apply to long life consumer goods. How would outlays on education be classified? Would they be classified as consumption spending or investment spending? How would gifts and bequests be treated? Some argue that the definition of 'exempt saving', locating the boundary between consumption and investment, raises as many complexities and difficulties in drafting as exist in the distinction between capital and income. Nevertheless, from the point of view of equity, efficiency and as a policy instrument, a switch to expenditure tax appears to have much to offer as an alternative to our present income tax system . Evidence now appears to be mounting that its administration would not be nearly as difficult as first thought. Professor Groenewegen has urged those interested in tax reform to:

. . . base their decisions on a careful evaluation of the current tax system and an even more careful examination of the consequences of the alternatives on the basis of the most recent research available.

In the case of Australia that research, as I indicated, is not available. In this country there has been no significant study on the feasibility or desirability of such a tax. The present tax crisis is evidence that it is time to break away from conventional tax ideology and to broaden our tax vision. For the longer term future of taxation in this country research into expenditure tax would provide a desirable addition to the armament of the tax reformer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —An hour or so ago Senator Chipp was speaking in the Senate and he drew attention in a general way to the state of confusion in which the Government finds itself, partly because of the many reefs and shoals that seem to beset it at the moment-largely of its own making, I might say-but also I believe because of a certain lack of will, a lack of ability, by the Government to perceive what the problems of the country are and to try to do something about them.

SPEECH.PARA: In this first reading debate on the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill 1982 I want to draw attention to a subject I have mentioned before and which I think is very important; that is, the close association between the energy problems of the country and its unemployment problems. In other words, I wish basically to bring forward the thesis that if unemployment is to be controlled it will not be done by encouraging people to be trained in industries and occupations which are already overcrowded; it will be done by looking at new areas of activity and industry which are to the public benefit and, by doing that, making work for some of the people who are at present unemployed. This is not an original idea; it is being done in so many countries overseas that it worries me intensely that the Government of Australia has not yet got around to considering it as a serious proposition. I suggest that the Government, if it really wants to get back the goodwill of the people of Australia and to re- establish some faith in the processes of Government, should get to work on something like that, it should look at what is going on overseas, read the lessons and do something which would indeed-this has been proven; it is not just hypothetical-get many thousands, perhaps hundreds of thousands, of Australians back to work. Indeed, as is happening in some countries, we might even get to the stage where there is virtually a labour shortage. It seems to the Australian Democrats that the Government is seeing the future through a telescope that is well out of focus-a myopic one-and that, as a result, its view is very vague and indistinct. It does not see any of the long term problems of the country and because of that it naturally does not see any solutions.

At the moment we are lulled into a false sense of security by the apparent world glut of petrol. I think all of us who appreciate the situation at all well understand that this will not last. It will be only a matter of a few years before we run out, in spite of the glut in production. The amount of petrol still underground is not increasing; it is diminishing rapidly. Every day that passes reduces the amount of oil that can be taken from our major field in Bass Strait. It is significant that the major rundown in production is only too likely to coincide with a crunch in the world supply situation towards the end of the present decade. If we want to do something about that we must do something now because of the lead times that are required to get that sort of industry into operation. For example, it takes some five years to get a methanol plant into operation. I think it will be much too late if we allow things to drift on until the end of the decade without doing anything about those matters.

The Government is failing lamentably in this whole energy field. It persists, for its inscrutable reasons-I believe they are inscrutable-in involving itself more and more deeply with the discredited, uneconomic and dangerous nuclear power industry which we, of all countries, could very well do without. I think all Australians should be asking themselves what the reasons are. What reasons of money and influence determine this perverse policy of the Government? Why is it so concerned with only that area of energy? Why is it that so much money is being put into that area? The fact is that nuclear energy, and the manufacture of small, dirty atomic bombs of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki type, are very closely associated. Most of the countries now building so-called peaceful reactors-the ones which have not cancelled their orders-want them, not for power but to derive plutonium to make bombs. It is worth once again stressing the point that it is much easier and quicker to breed plutonium in a modern power reactor than it is to breed it in a fast breeder reactor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which countries are you talking about?

—I have a list of them here. They are: Argentina, Libya, Pakistan, South Korea, South Africa and the Philippines. Every one of them, as the honourable senator knows, is a notable democracy! I am being sardonic, of course ; they are not. Every one of them is a repressive and dictatorial regime. It is an open secret-they have admitted it-that virtually their nuclear power structures are there to provide weapons. When they do that we will have a miserable future of regional wars throughout the world, in every area in which these things are used.
—How is Australia placed?

—The honourable senator is speaking next. I will let him take up the matter then. I ask him not to take up my speaking time, if he does not mind. In the United States there is now a much wider and better vision. I was there some months ago and I was greatly reassured to find an almost general renunciation of nuclear power, which now is widely seen in that country as dangerous and completely uneconomic. I also found there a genuine practical effort to turn to other means. While there-I think Senator Jessop also had this experience-I visited the world's largest solar power station, Solar One, in the Mojave Desert, 50 miles east of Los Angeles. Its operations are automated and computerised to the extent that its needs, including maintenance, can be met by a staff of three. I think the point has to be made that solar technology has become very much more feasible in only the last few years because of the tremendous increase in microchip technology. It is now possible to automate these devices to an extent that was not before thought possible, and to do it much more cheaply than was previously the case. While the sun is shining-it does 10 hours a day on average at that location as it is a desert location, of which Australia has many-Solar One produces 12 1/2 megawatts of electricity, and on this daytime running it can provide enough power for some 6,000 households, which is quite good. At night a thermal storage unit comes into operation so that during that critical peak period in the evening the station retains surplus heat in the storage unit and goes on producing something like 7 1/2 megawatts during that peak period for the first four hours after the sun has set. That unit consists of nearly 7,000 tonnes of rock and sand and a quarter of a million gallons of a type of oil specifically developed as an efficient power exchanger.

SPEECH.PARA: A second and similar power station is being built nearby by a private enterprise corporation which is so confident that it has already contracted-I stress that it has already contracted-to supply solar power to California's major supply authority, Southern California Edison, at a lower price than power generated by burning fossil fuels. That is a notable breakthrough in the world. It is one which exists; it is there for everybody to see. It is private enterprise and justified purely in those terms. At that place I saw on the drawing boards, for other parts of the United States, plants of that type of up to 120 megawatt. In other words, they are beginning to approach in a single solar plant the sort of thing we so stupidly, as Senator Chipp said, are thinking of building in South West Tasmania. The technology is there; it is there for us to learn from. It is economic.

In Hawaii I found wind power being studied seriously. It is actually in use in many small-scale applications such as businesses and cattle ranches. I visited the largest of these generators, which is a joint National Aeronautical and Space Administration and Department of Energy project, which generates 220 kilowatts of power. It has functioned very successfully and, interestingly enough, operates most of the time quite automatically, without the need for any staff whatsoever. Plans are now in preparation for a much larger facility to take advantage of the trade winds in Hawaii-a wind farm of 20 machines which will produce a total of 80 megawatts. Here again it is comparable to this disastrous dam which is planned for South West Tasmania. The Government has those lessons there for it. The question has to be posed again: Why does it not do something about it?

We know, as I said earlier, that we are going to run out of our native oil in the Bass Strait field within a foreseeable time-not too much time. When that happens, especially if there is a world crunch, it will have the most severe effects possible on both the Australian standard of living and the level of unemployment. The troubles that we have now will pale into insignificance compared with the problems we would have if world affairs reached a stage in which a single shot fired one night in Riyadh, the capital of Saudi Arabi, created an Iran-type revolution. If that happened in three or four years time, when our own crude oil supplies will have run down, we will be in very serious trouble indeed.

We wait in vain for the North West Shelf contract, to sell gas to the Japanese, to be concluded, but as yet, there is no sign that it will be. Should we not go back to the idea, proposed by Sir Mark Oliphant and others, of using our young unemployed in a vast imaginative project-such as that which Roosevelt implemented under the New Deal in the United States of America to pull America out of recession-the building of a pipeline across the continent to bring gas to the eastern States where probably it could provide fuel for many decades, if not centuries?

Could we not consider again doing what many other countries such as the Soviet Union, New Zealand and others, are doing-provide a plant to convert natural gas to methanol. This is an established technology. It is well known. It is not even expensive. It is a fact that methanol, produced as a petrol extender from such plants, would be cheaper than the present landed cost of Middle East crude. As more and more people understand that fact, it will be very difficult for the Government to apologise for its inadequacies and failure in that regard. The public will come to realise that we could have had a petrol extender which would have spun out our own resources in a major and practical way and would have been cheaper than what we would eventually be forced to buy.

We are already facing problems related to electricity supplies in many regions. These also must become worse as every year goes by; we know that. We had the problem earlier this winter and we had it last winter also. In the long run the only answer can be a determined effort to move towards conservation and the use of renewable energy resources. In this regard, I was quite alarmed to read a report in the Canberra Times of 26 August which quoted the Secretary to the Department of Science and Technology, Dr W. J. McG. Tegart as saying, in a paper to a chemical and physics congress in Canberra at the time, that the percentage of Australia's primary energy consumption provided by renewable resources was likely to fall slightly between now and the year 2000 from a present figure which he assessed as 4.5 per cent. If this is so, it is certainly regrettable, and completely out of tune with what almost every other nation in the world is doing. It is also a direct result of current Government policy not to encourage the use of renewable energy resources. The Government is condemned by its own words.

In the last Budget the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Energy Technology, the Division responsible for renewable energy resources, had its budget cut, in real terms, by 2 per cent. At the same time the CSIRO's Division of Energy Chemistry, the Division responsible for nuclear energy research, had its budget increased in real terms, so that the provision for combined nuclear energy research by that Division of CSIRO and by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission has been increased by 2 per cent, in real terms, for the coming year. I cannot understand why the Government feels it must continue this perverse promotion of nuclear energy while cutting back on research in the most vital area of renewable energy resources. I do not know whether Dr Tegart included in his figure of 4.5 per cent the very considerable energy contribution now being made in Australia by the use of solar hot water heaters. I suspect that he did not, since the resources he mentioned were said to be mainly hydro-electric power, fire-wood and bagasse.

The real point is that a quite slight change in Government policy would greatly increase the use of established technology in the solar hot water area. It would reduce not only our dependence on non-renewable resources but also would provide thousands of new jobs. This has been demonstrated over the last three years in California, where the Solarcal program established by Governor Brown on 3 May 1978 provides a State and Federal tax credit of 55 per cent of the cost of the installation and upkeep of solar hot water heating systems. Householders obtain a refund of 55 per cent of that amount. This has led to an enormous increase in that industry in California. By the end of this year the Solarcal Council expects that there will be 200,000 solar hot water heaters and 150,000 solar space conditioning installations in California-a tremendous leap. By 1985 this program is expected to save 15 per cent of the oil and gas which California would otherwise have imported. The other point is that California, a society comparable with our own-with 20 million people and much the same geographical conditions-expects to employ about 30,000 people at all levels of skill and experience. That does not take into account the downstream results which would occur, of course, in the metals area-an area in which we need new industries. Why does the Government not go forward in that regard? It could obtain from the California Energy Commission a well thought out and completely researched document which would prove beyond doubt that it is cheaper to subsidise such developments than it is to build new power stations using any other form of generated electricity. Conservation is the answer that the world needs. That can be seen abundantly clearly. It is why I despair so much of the Government. It seems to have an inability to see even the obvious things and do something about them. If such a scheme were introduced in Australia it would not only dramatically increase employment but also would increase it at an even rate throughout society in all Australian cities and towns, not only industrial centres. The building and installation of this established technology-solar hot water heating-is a local labour-intensive industry. It would also start a trend towards renewable energy which we all know must come, if we are not to take the strange lemming-like view which the Government has towards nuclear power and eventual deprivation of society through unemployment.

I believe that the Government has accepted with deep gratitude an alarming and discreditable tendency in the Australian community to tolerate massive unemployment. It is part of the 'I'm all right Jack' mentality. We have the bizarre situation that although we have probably, all up-including those who do not want to say that they are unemployed-well over half a million unemployed, and women; those who are actually employed are well enough off. That is my final point. We can afford to do these things in society. It is only a government that does not have the guts or will to do so that is our problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August this year in the Senate Senator Walsh responded to an address by Senator Crichton-Browne on the subject of the Queensland sugar industry and the potential for growing sugar in the Ord River area or Western Australia. I responded immediately, on the run as it were, to some to the more outrageous things that Senator Walsh had said on that occasion. This is the first opportunity that I have had to respond in any detail and with the indulgence of the Senate, I seek to do so now.

SPEECH.PARA: I regularly visit Kununurra. It is an important part of my electorate, in its extreme north-east corner. I know a considerable number of people in that area. I also regularly meet with the people employed by the Department of Agriculture in that area. Some very dedicated people have been working there for many years. Also, many farmers went there in good faith when cotton was being produced quite successfully. Since the failure of cotton production, through no fault of their own-it certainly was not predicted by anyone involved-these people have found themselves in dire straits. Virtually anything will grow in the Ord River area, but since the failure of the cotton industry, the region has not been self- supporting. Some of the crops that can be grown in the area include sunflower, rice, wheat, sorghum, melons, ground nuts, soya beans, bananas and other tropical fruits, All of these will grow very well but most, if not all, suffer from high freight costs, lack of a profitable export market, cheaper competition from other Australian markets or pure economies of scale.

I can understand the concern of the Queenslanders in the Senate about the potential of the Ord River sugar industry. I genuinely believe the Ord has the potential to be a much more efficient producer of sugar than have the existing areas of Queensland and north-east New South Wales. I do not blame the existing sugar producers for trying to maintain their cosy monopoly. I would probably try to do the same if I were in that situation, but I find it very hard to believe that the senior Australian Labor Party senator from Western Australia would try to condemn the attempts by the State Government and the people who live in the Ord River area to establish this new industry. Is it any wonder that Western Australia is represented by only four Labor senators? If they continue to adopt this attitude of condemning any potential new industry for their State, they will be forever restricted to that number, at the most. We have here a senator with a farming background-one of the few members of his party in this place who have any knowledge of farming whatsoever. To give him some credit, I guess he is the only Labor politician I know who, if he belonged to another party, would feel very much at home in that very important body, the 'Society of Modest Members'.

Senator Walsh is doing all he can to prevent his own State of Western Australia from creating a new industry, an industry that I believe would not need any taxpayer support if everything went well and would certainly need a lower level of taxpayer support than many of the other industries that are established in this country and which the Opposition repeatedly says need more support. I separated two issues from the early part of Senator Walsh's address. It was typical of the bitter, negative and emotional addresses that he normally makes in this place, so identifying two important issues was rather difficult. The first issue I found was that he said that the Queensland sugar industry is an ailing industry. The second point was that the Western Australian Government was irresponsible. He actually used words like 'sloth' and 'illiterate', as well as 'irresponsible'.

Can the Queensland industry be ailing if it has increased its production steadily since 1963 by a rate of 5 per cent a year? In 1963 it produced 894,000 tonnes of sugar and I understand that now it produces about 3.4 million tonnes. The sugar industry itself expects to produce five million tonnes by the year 1990. Can that be an ailing industry? Can it also be an ailing industry when it negotiates a shorter working week with its employees with very little argument at all, as happened recently? Even Senator Macklin, who also spoke on 19 August, admitted that just a few months ago international sugar prices were at their second highest level on record. I suggest that that cosy monopoly is about to be broken. I suggest also that some of the benefits will flow to Queensland. Perhaps then its industry will modernise some of its old sugar mills and reduce what I believe to be a high level of capitalisation. I happen to believe that monopolies are bad for any industry.

In regard to the second point, the irresponsibility of the Western Australian Government, I was three years old when a royal commission recommended that the Ord be classified as an area suitable for irrigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you remember it well?

—I do remember it well. I doubt whether any members of the present governments or either the Premier of Western Australia or the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Malcolm Fraser) had any part in the decision in the early 1950s to build a diversion dam, or even in the 1960s decision to build the main dam. I do not believe that anybody in those two governments had any part in those decisions. History can be the only judge of whether those decisions were correct. It is totally futile to try to make politics out of those two decisions . The fact is that we have a dam and we must try to make the most efficient and best use of it. Since the establishment of the Ord River irrigation system, successive State and Federal governments, both Liberal and Labor-I stress, both Liberal and Labor-have maintained their support for the Ord. Is it not typical of the Australian Labor Party to condemn the east Kimberley area to government dependency now, yet in July of this year, during the North Province by-election, all the Labor spokesmen supported a sugar industry there. Is that not amazing?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh issued a challenge during his address. He issued that challenge to the Prime Minister, to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and to the honourable members for Leichhardt (Mr Thomson), Herbert (Mr Dean) and Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). It was the typical scattergun approach that he tends to use. I think it is more relevant that a challenge be issued to the present honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, and also to Mr Brian Burke, the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia, to Mr Ernie Bridge, the member for Kimberley, and to Mr Peter Dowding and Mr Tom Stephens, the members for North Province. I think they should be asked to say where they stand on a sugar industry for the Ord River area and where they stand in relation to what Senator Walsh and Mr John Kerin have been saying on this issue.

I suppose the parliamentary Labor Party in Western Australia will continue to ignore Senator Walsh, as it usually does. What an embarrassment he must be to it . However, I think the people in the Kimberley area have a right to know where their member, Mr Campbell, stands on this issue. Is Mr Campbell going to help the area, which is a very important part of his electorate, by speaking out against John Kerin and Senator Walsh? Will he do that? I suspect not. I suspect he will continue with his normal track record and condemn and try to frustrate every attempt by the State Government of Western Australia and by the Federal Government of Australia to improve the situation and the living conditions of the people who live in his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to all the other industries you started up there- millet, sorghum and the others? They have gone down the drain.

—I am sorry that the honourable senator came in here a little late. I did list the reasons why all the other areas of production tried have failed. When Senator Walsh said in his address that the figure of 20 tonnes of sugar per hectare should be discounted he was being selective again, in his usual way. He chose not to tell us that the average yield in some years has been as high as 26 tonnes to the hectare. He also failed to tell us that in all the calculations made by the State Department of Agriculture the figures have been discounted to accommodate the obviously higher figures that can be attained in a trial of this size. He also failed to mention that the trials conducted in the last four or five years in that area have been full scale commercial size trials , so the discounted figure used by the Department of Agriculture, discounted down from the conservative 20 tonnes per hectare, is a realistic figure. It has been discounted to between 70 per cent and 80 per cent, which I think is an extremely reasonable and realistic depreciation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh also questioned the Department of Agriculture's figures on the infrastructure costs of establishing an industry in the Ord. I suggest that neither he nor I are in a position to challenge those figures. If Senator Walsh has those figures available I would like to see them. He again chose to ignore that sugar technology has advanced a great deal since the mills were built in Queensland and north-east New South Wales and that the Ord sugar industry would have the advantage of this new technology. I close by saying again that the people of the Kimberleys have a right to know where their Federal member stands in relation to the sugar industry in the Ord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have almost been goaded into talking about sugar. I will certainly tell Senator Thomas where I stand in relation to sugar growing on the Ord. In fact, it had been my intention to say something along those lines when Parliament resumed. I remember that just before the Parliament resumed the honourable senator was in Queensland peddling his story about how we should be growing more sugar in the Ord. I do not know how he got a stamp on his visa to get out of the place. I think I might come back to sugar at some stage and tell the honourable senator a few home truths about the sugar industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Strange as it may seem, the Senate is actually debating the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill. Because it is a Bill that the Senate is not able to amend we can speak on matters relevant or irrelevant to it. I mention that because sometimes people who take the time to read Hansard wonder why we talk about things that are not related to the Bill. I suppose sugar is a bit closer to dried fruits than the matter I am going to raise, but even the matter I raise will have something to do with the sugar and dried fruits industries.

I would like to mention something that was outlined in the Budget and the effect that it is having on a great number of people and industries throughout Australia. When the Budget was brought down, the full impacts of some of the measures in it were not immediately felt or were not immediately evident to some people. However, since then the details of many of the parts of the Budget which on first blush did not look too bad and are now causing alarm to many people. We spoke only yesterday or the day before about increased rates of sales tax. Some people felt the brunt of those almost immediately, or within a few days of the Budget. There was the imposition of new sales taxes on items that did not previously attract sales tax. This is causing a lot of alarm. There is another matter on which I shall not dwell, which is causing alarm to many people, especially elderly people. That is the tax on bank transactions, which we have promised will be introduced from 1 January next year. We do not yet know the full details of this, but people are sufficiently concerned to be worried about it.
The main point on which I want to concentrate is the new policy in relation to excise on deisel fuel. On August 17 we were told in the Budget Speech:
Exemption of excise duty on diesel fuel is allowed at present for all use off public roads.

So up until 17 August the only people who were paying excise on diesel fuel were those who were using it on public roads, which meant that a great number of consumers throughout Australia were not paying the excise at all. But we were also told in the Budget Speech that this exemption had proved difficult to administer so as to prevent abuse. Because of that, the Government decided to throw the baby out with the bath water. It said:
As from tonight, all diesel fuel will bear the full rate of excise duty, irrespective of its end use.
Of course, there were some exceptions. The Government said that it would-

introduce a system to allow users to claim rebates of this excise in respect of certain categories of off-road end use-broadly, domestic use, hospitals, nursing and convalescent homes and in the agricultural, mining, fishing and forestry industries.

So those industries or people who work within those categories using diesel fuel will be able to have a rebate of the excise that they pay. Despite the rebates for some users, many users will still pay the excise whereas they were not paying it previously. Because of that, I and, I am sure, many of my colleagues on both sides of the chamber have received many complaints from those who will now have to pay the excise.

I suppose that it is worthwhile to outline what this excise is. It is 5.155c a litre. But to be added to that is an extra 1c a litre, and that 1c a litre will be used to fund the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. I think that program probably has to be funded because of the paucity of funding that has been provided by the Federal Government up until now for roads. But that 1c brings the total amount to 6.155c a litre. One of the glaring examples where this has to be paid where it has not been paid previously is the State Government railways. In my State of Queensland, the railways will be forced to pay about $11m a year extra to the Federal Government because they now have to pay excise for diesel fuel. They must pass on these costs. There will have to be increased fares and increased freight charges.

I am surprised that this matter got through the Government parties when one of the partners in the coalition is the National Country Party. It will have a big effect on country areas. If freight rates are increased, this will affect country areas the greatest. What is ironic and what really galls the Queensland Railway Department and, I suppose, all other railway departments throughout Australia, is that part of the excise that they will be paying will be going to road funding. It just seems like something out of Alice in Wonderland when the Queensland Railway Department will now be paying about $2m a year to road funding throughout Australia. This additional impost of 1c a litre is to be increased next year to 2c a litre, so from then on the Queensland Railway Department will be paying about $4m a year to road funding.
One of the reasons why it was decided that railways should not be an exempt category was outlined in the Budget Speech. The Treasurer said:
The concession--
That was the concession that excise did not have to be paid by those who were not using the diesel fuel on public roads--
also ensures certain competitive advantages, for example, rail transport as against road transport.

I wonder whether the Government really thinks that there is any competition for some rail transport in Queensland. Can we visualise that all of the copper, the lead and all the other minerals from Mount Isa which are transported to Townsville would come by road rather than rail? There is no way in the world that road transport would be used. Similarly, it would be almost impossible to take all the coal from the coalfields of central Queensland to the eastern ports if one used road transport instead of rail. But one of the reasons why the concession was withdrawn from railway departments was said to be the competition between the two modes of transport.

The total bill for all of the railways throughout Australia is not known, but I calculate that the State railways will probably pay about $30m to $35m a year to the Commonwealth Government in excise on diesel fuel. I should like to give some figures on the diesel fuel consumption of the railways throughout Australia. They will give a clear indication that my calculations are correct. Queensland railways use 180 million to 200 million litres of diesel fuel a year. I could not get a more precise figure than that. I was told that the amount used depends upon the amount of traffic in a particular year, and 180 million to 200 million litres seems to be about the consumption. New South Wales railways inform me that they use 213 million litres a year, so the railways there will also be paying about $2m now and about $4m later on, just for road funding, in addition to the other excise on the diesel fuel. In Victoria, about 80 million litres are used; in Western Australia it is about 58 million litres; and in South Australia it is 10 million litres. It should be remembered that in South Australia all country services are a Commonwealth responsibility, and in Western Australia there are extensive private railways to which I have not referred.

I shall leave the matter of the State railways there, but I should mention that there are some other areas about which I have received considerable complaint because people will now be paying excise on diesel fuel whereas they did not do so previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bakeries.

—One such area is coastal shipping. This has a great effect on Queensland. Many areas in Queensland are serviced by coastal shipping, but now they will have to pay excise on the diesel fuel used. Local authorities are worried about what this cost will mean to them. I had a complaint from a brickworks which is using a lot of diesel fuel. The increased cost is considerable. That extra 6.155c per litre will result in extra costs for the brickworks and I presume that these will have to be passed on. This will mean extra home building costs and again the consumer will have to pay. I had a complaint from a person who has a dry cleaning establishment. He said that the additional cost to him will be considerable. I will read his comments because I think that honourable senators should understand the problems that these small businesses are facing. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: To my knowledge the Dry Cleaning Industry has always been entitled to the Diesel Fuel Rebate for Diesel used solely for steam raising. I believe that the withdrawal of this entitlement as announced in the Budget on the 18th August, 1982 is most unjust.

The increase (6.155c per litre) coupled with the increase of 2 1/2 per cent Sales Tax on all items used by the industry will necessitate dramatic increases in prices to the consumer. As our prices are forced to rise consumer resistance increases, volume of work decreases. Consequently employees may be stood down and the community will have to pay greater unemployment benefits.

The writer of the letter went on to make other points but I will leave it at that. However I will highlight some of the problems that were mentioned in those two paragraphs. The person who owns this dry cleaning business pointed out that there is a great increase in the cost of the fuel that he will use. An extra 2 1 /2 percentage points in sales tax will be levied on any of the items used by the industry. He also points out that because the volume of his work will decrease, he is liable to stand down employees and we will have a greater pool of unemployed. I wonder, when I read such statements, whether the Government thought through all of the consequences of what would happen when it imposed an excise on diesel fuel. People who use diesel fuel did not even have an inkling that this was about to happen; so they did not have an opportunity to change to an alternative fuel if that was available.

I could talk at length about where increased sales tax is having a disadvantage . A moment ago Senator Macklin mentioned bakeries. I think that we have all received representations from the tourist industries. I would like the Government to take stock of what it has done, have a look at the sorts of industries that are going to be disadvantaged by this policy change and see whether it can redress what it has done to some of these industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Sessional Order the debate concludes at 2.15 p.m.; I do not have much time left. So that that arrangement can be put into effect, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Documents Concerning Straw Companies and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980
Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Senate take note of the paper and statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak for 20 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the circumstances that is very gracious of the Government and I appreciate it. The documents tabled yesterday were damning enough for reasons that I will summarise in a moment but they would be even more damning if they contained all the items for which the Opposition asked and not just a politically sanitised selection of them. I remind the Senate that of the 22 documents or sets of documents that were sought in my Notice of Motion No. 168, we have received only eight. Of those 22 documents, 14 were in the form of opinions or advice of one kind or another but only three of those kinds of documents have been tabled. Whether there is any credible basis for the denial of access in respect of those documents is something that I will deal with in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The documents that have not been supplied are set out in the amendment which has been circulated in this chamber and I will not spend time going through them . They are set out in a slightly different order. They deal with the Brinsden Q. C. opinions, the Traill and Lockhart opinions and so on. They include all of the documents that were on the list in my notice of motion plus one additional item, No. 12 on the current list-the report of senior investigation officer Todman which was inadvertently omitted from my notice of motion. It is a document which has been referred to in the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I am sure that it is a document with which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) would be well familiar and on which the Government would have had an opportunity to form an opinion.

It is clear that although many other documents are missing from the purportedly complete file that we have been given and in respect of which we may well need, after considering these matters over the next few days, to move yet further motions-I refer to replies, attachments and enclosures, the existence of which is revealed by the main documents in the file in question-there are two main categories of missing documents. In terms of what we are asking for previously they are these: In the first place what is missing are opinions, mainly from distinguished Queen's Counsel, which in the view of Mr Costigan were persuasive arguments for the adequacy and availability of existing legal remedies. The second class of documents which are missing covers opinions, memoranda of advice and documens of that kind which, in the opinion of Mr Costigan, were inadequately argued statements of the case against the availability of such legal remedies. When one sees that, of all the hundreds of pages of documents that have been tabled, those are the kinds of documents to which we have been refused access, it becomes very obvious indeed that the Government has something to hide. It is already obvious that the Government is profoundly embarrassed by the revelations that do appear in the documents that have already been tabled. Those documents reveal a number of very embarrasing things which I will briefly attempt to summarise.

Firstly, as far back as July 1977 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the then Treasurer and Sir Phillip Lynch were aware of Slutzkin type tax schemes involving sales of companies with current year profits. Secondly, as early as January 1978 the Treasurer, Mr Howard, knew enough about pre tax profit stripping to propose legislation for the 1978 Budget sittings to combat it.

Thirdly, the documents reveal that on as many as 18 separate occasions, between 20 February 1978 and 12 November 1980, the Commissioner of Taxation pleaded with the Treasurer and the Government to take urgently needed legislative action against company stripping or bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Fourthly, they reveal that there was extensive and very frank and detailed correspondence between the Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer and, to a lesser extent, the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), in relation to the problem of bottom-of- the-harbour or straw company tax evasion which shows that the attempts by those Ministers to invoke section 16 secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act in their defence was no more than a cynical ploy to avoid accepting responsibility. There is an extraordinary amount of detail as to the nature of schemes and the nature of particular kinds of stransactions which appear in these documents, and the section 16 excuse is revealed starkly in these documents for the nonsense that it is.

Fifthly, the documents reveal that at no stage prior to the introduction of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 in November 1980 was any serious consideration given by the officers advising the Treasurer and the Federal Commissioner of Taxation to the question of the adequacy of existing law as a basis for prosecuting tax avoiders. There is no evidence whatsoever in any of the numerous minutes or accounts of meetings of that informal interdepartmental committee which was established from mid-1978 onward to deal with these matters and to advise the Treasurer about legislation-not one iota of reference-until the end of 1980, to the adequacy or otherwise of the existing law.

Sixthly, the documents reveal that in direct conflict with the Treasurer's public statement on 27 June 1982 no advice as to the adequacy of existing law was given by those officers to the Government before the decision to proceed with the new legislation was made. Seventhly, there was a delay of seven months between the Treasurer's request in December 1978 and the advice he finally received from the Attorney-General regarding one very central and important aspect of the proposed new legislation, that seven month's delay being until the Attorney-General finally got around to replying in July 1979.
Eighthly, the documents reveal that the despair of the Federal Commissioner of Taxation, Mr O'Reilly, reached the point were by November 1979, in his letter on 7 November, he said:
Unless something effective is done along the lines proposed, we may almost as well not bother with anti-avoidance legislation.

Ninthly, the documents reveal that the primary cause of these delays was the Treasurer's craven weakness in the face of pressure from his own Liberal back bench, from Liberal Party supporters in the business community and from the Government's own appointed taxation advisory committee and his complete inability in the face of opposition from those quarters to show the necessary political leadership to steer through this urgently needed-in the Government's own view-legislation before the taxation problem got out of hand.

Finally, the documents reveal that at the end of the day the Government's own advisers, despite all the neurosis about the evidentiary effectiveness of the new provisions that they were drafting and where the onus of proof and so on should reside, retained enormous doubts about the efficacy of the law that they had so laboriously, over a period of nearly three years, drafted. That is revealed in the memorandum that was in fact tabled originally in this place on 4 December and which appears in these documents. At the very end of the memorandum in question, which is covered by a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation, the officers in question say:

Even with the enactment of the present Bill, which is addressed directly to countering these activities, it can be expected that the evidentiary burdens on the prosecution in proving its case beyond reasonable doubt will prove to be very substantial indeed.

So we have a revelation in these documents that the Government's officers in the Australian Taxation Office, the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and all the other areas that were consulted, retained grave doubts as to the efficacy of the 1980 legislation upon which they are now hanging their hat. Of course, that may be one reason why there have not yet been any prosecutions under the 1980 legislation, even though we now know that there are at least nine cases in respect of which substantial evidence exists to justify such a prosecution, as revealed in the Estimates Committee hearings.

So on all those fronts the Government has found itself embarrassed by what is actually in these documents. Now, in addition, for it to be nakedly revealed that during the period in question the Government had strategies open to it under existing law-that it could have actually prosecuted under existing law but it did not; that it could have run civil proceedings to recover the taxes in question but it did not; that it did have well and cogently argued opinions and memoranda from leading counsel and others saying that such proceedings could proceed; that it did not have well and cogently argued opinions and memoranda arguing the contrary, just a series of bleating ex post rationalisations from senior officials to justify their inaction-for all of that now to be nakedly revealed, as it would be if the documents we are seeking were now to be tabled, would really drive the last nails into the coffin in which the credibility of the Government on this issue now lies.

It is no wonder that the Government does not want the truth to come out. It is no wonder that the Government has sterilised and sanitised these documents to the extent that it has.
