It is no wonder that it has tried to create by this snowstorm of largely irrelevant documents the impresion that it was engaged in a frenzy of activity, struggling with difficult, almost intractable, conceptual problems during the nearly three years that were involved in drafting the new legislation.

We are not satisfied with the claim that these documents have already been scutinised by the Solicitor-General. We are not satisfied about the filtration process that has, on the Government's own word, already taken place. As I will say again in a moment, the Solicitor-General is an officer whose legal ability we very highly respect. I am on record speaking about his ability and no doubt I will be quoted to that effect in a speech later in these proceedings. Let me tell the Senate why I am not satisfied-I believe and hope that the majority of honourable senators will not be satisfied-with the process of sanitisation, of sterilisation, of filtration that has occurred so far with the process that is described in the tabling statement on page 2 about the Solicitor-General's personally examining each of the documents in question and advising the Government that certain of them should not be tabled on the ground that public disclosure would be harmful to the administration of justice, in some cases would cause harm to those who may be prosecuted or proceeded against or to the cause of the complainants themselves, the further point being made that the injury would not in the Solicitor-General's view be avoided by excising names.

This is the basis on which the sterilisation process, the editing process, has so far proceeded. Why are we not happy with that? Let me tell the Senate why we are not happy. In the first place it is the case that the Solicitor-General, on the evidence of the ministerial tabling statement, has not confined himself to the application of the single criterion that he was requested to apply in the terms of my motion; namely, prejudice to any pending criminal or civil proceedings. He has clearly taken into account or been asked to take into account other criteria; namely, the impact of public disclosure on the general administration of justice or the impact of disclosure as far as the position of individuals is concerned. I do not know, we do not know how much weight was given to those criteria as distinct from the criterion of prejudice to pending proceedings. I do not know, we do not know, what other unstated criteria, might in fact have been applied.

My second point is that to the extent that the Solicitor-General was applying and properly applying some criterion of prejudice to pending proceedings, it has simply not been explained how that prejudice is likely to occur in relation to the documents that have not been produced. It has not been explained how that prejudice is greater in respect of the untabled documents than in respect of those documents that have been tabled, many of which obviously refer to particular cases, including the Perth case, and many of which obviously refer to the general legal strategy which may well now lie behind any such attempts that might be made to engage in legal proceedings.

The third point is that, to the extent that it is claimed that the release of these documents would be harmful to individuals and to the extent that the Senate might be minded to treat that as a relevant criterion although it is not one that was set out in the terms of my original Order of the Day, it has simply not been explained how individuals could be harmed if their names and other identifying characteristics were removed, as was readily accepted to be appropriate in the Order of the Day and as has in fact been done in respect of a very large number of the documents that have been tabled.

The fourth reason why we do not accept the censorship process that has gone on so far is that to the extent that it is implicit in the claim made by the Government purporting to reflect the views of the Solicitor-General that the documents that are being totally withheld cannot be sanitised or cannot be partially edited and the whole document must be withheld from publication, it has simply not been explained how it is impossible for these documents to be partially edited in a way that it was not possible for other documents that have been produced to be partially edited. In other words, there is no evidence whatsoever as to the basis on which it is claimed that the process in respect of the documents which have been totally withheld could not have been done in exactly the same way as it was in respect of those documents which have in fact been put on the table.

So we say this: The filtering job that has been done has not been done in a way with which the Senate can now rest content. We believe that it can be done only by someone who is totally independent of the Executive Government and yet in whose competence and experience to make these kinds of judgments about prejudice the Senate can have full confidence. On Senator Harradine's suggestion we accept that the appropriate person to make this judgment, to perform this editing process, is Mr Costigan himself. If the Government might be minded to say that it is inappropriate for Mr Costigan to perform this role or if the Government might be minded to say that Mr Costigan should not be doing this consistently with his charter, I will simply ask the Government whether it takes that view about getting Mr Costigan to investigate the affairs of Mr Horgan, which it has been very keen in the last 48 hours to confer upon him as yet another particular mantle that he is to wear, appropriate to, consonant to, the general terms of reference that he is exercising. Obviously the task here to ensure that prosecutions will not be prejudiced by anything that goes on to the public record is one that Mr Costigan is enormously well-equipped to perform, totally familiar as he is with these particular documents and, presumably, totally committed as he is to ensuring that those who have been in breach of the law will be brought to justice.

We make it clear, finally, that we make no suggestion whatsoever that the Solicitor-General, Sir Maurice Byers, is in any way politically biased in the judgments that he may have made about the status of these particular documents. I do suggest that he may have erred on the side of caution in protecting information, in protecting documents in the hands of the Executive Government of the day. He may have erred in this respect on the basis of his well-known personal views about the proper extent of Executive privilege, the proper extent to which Executive information should be made available to the public. It will be recalled that Sir Maurice Byers, as Solicitor-General, took a very strong view on this particular issue, which he stated to be one of principle, at the time of the loans affair in 1975 when he was brought before the Bar of the Senate to give information, which he refused to do on these grounds. In taking that position in 1975, he did not go without significant criticism from the Opposition benches for the very strong view he took as to the extent to which these matters ought to remain outside the public domain. Simply, I suspect, by his attitude and by the very rigorous censorship process which he seems to have applied with respect to these documents, he is, I believe, simply being consistent with the attitude he took on that occasion.

I believe it is appropriate for someone totally outside the apparatus of full time Executive Government, someone who is not an officer in any sense, statutory or otherwise, of this Government, to perform this particular task. It is only by the documents in question being looked at, by a process such as that, and those documents, after they have been filtered, and screened, being put into the public domain so that we can see for ourselves in particular the quality of the Crown Solicitor's memoranda and letters of April 1979 and late in 1980 and the quality of the legal opinions that were in circulation about the extent to which legal action could be taken, that we will be able to make a responsible evaluation as to where the real blame lies for this extraordinary debacle in the history of Australian public administration. I move:

At end of motion add 'and that there be also laid on the table the following additional papers relating to the consideration by the Government of possible legal action against those participating in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, subject to:
(a) the deletion from such papers of the names and identifying characteristics of individuals to the extent necessary to satisfy the requirements of s. 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and

(b) the editing of such papers by the Royal Commissioner, Mr Costigan, in consultation with the Crown Solicitor, to ensure that no material is published which might prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings against those involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes:
(i) Opinion of Mr Brinsden, Q.C., provided to Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, December 1974 (Costigan report, p. 35).
(ii) Opinion of Mr Brinsden, Q.C., provided to Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, June 1975 (Constigan report, p. 36).

(iii) Any document containing the opinion of Mr Gleedman, Mr O'Sullivan or Mr Massie of Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office regarding possible prosecutions arising out of the ''bottom-of-the- harbour'' scheme discussed in chapter 3 of the Costigan report, Volume 1.
(iv) Opinion of unnamed Sydney Q.C. provided to Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in early 1976 in relation to Norfolk Island matter (Costigan report, pp. 40-41).
(v) Report of police investigators into Perth matter, November 1976 (Costigan report, p. 43).
(vi) Opinion of Lockhart, Q.C., supplied between 1976 and 1978 to Sydney office of Deputy Crown Solicitor (referred to on Nationwide 1.9.82, and in Senate 7.9. 82).

(vii) Advice from counsel (unnamed) provided to taxation head office, and comments from Deputy Crown Solicitor in relation thereto, in respect of company stripping case reported in April 1976 (Treasurer's Press release 27.6.82, pp. 14 -15).

(viii) Advice from Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor to Sydney Deputy Crown Solicitor in 1977 regarding a ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' case referred by Sydney to Perth (referred to on Nationwide 3.9.82 and in Senate 7.9.82).
(xi) Memoranda written by officers of Sydney Deputy Crown Solicitor in response to Perth advice (referred to on Nationwide 3.9.82 and in Senate 7.9.82).
(x) Opinion of Mr Traill, Q.C., in July 1978 (Costigan report, p. 76).
(xi) Advice by Crown Solicitor to Australian Taxation Office in April 1979 ( Costigan report, p. 64).
(xii) 18-page report of senior investigation officer Todman to Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in mid-1979 (Costigan report p. 66).

I seek leave to move a motion to discharge an order of the day from the Notice Paper.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That General Business, Order of the Day No. 168, be discharged from the Notice Paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this month the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union exposed some sections of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth as being, at the very least, inept and inefficient, and at the worst, guilty of encouraging, simply by doing nothing, certain illegal tax evasion schemes. The documents that are before us today-a set of documents which do not bear a great deal of resemblance to the documents that were asked for by the Senate some weeks ago-chronicle an equally sorry saga of dithering, timidity and stalling by Ministers and some departmental officers. In addition, the talkathon and the paper war which developed between the years 1977 and 1980 reveal a rather unfortunate rivalry between some departments, notably the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department and the usual conflict of opinion, of course, that exists whenever more than one lawyer gets involved in anything.

SPEECH.PARA: The documents consist of a series of not-always-legible letters, minutes, memoranda, opinions, Press releases and so on, in more or less chronological order. They were not, unfortunately, the easiest of pieces of paper to find one' s way around or to get information from. The documents do, however, outline collectively a story of burgeoning tax avoidance at best, and evasion at worst, interspersed with some plaintive cries from the heart of the Commissioner of Taxation complaining about staffing inadequacies. The papers demonstrate just how long government decisions can be prolonged by ministerial dithering, by Cabinet jitters, by understaffed departments, by requests for outside opinion after outside opinion, by government actions, which varied in this case from requesting urgent action for legislation to deciding to introduce that legislation on the last day of a session, so that it would have to lie around for a while for discussion-all of which simply allowed by default the development of a massive tax evasion industry and the formation of a situation costing the Government, and hence the taxpayers, what the Commissioner of Taxation indicated were millions of dollars per month. And all of this, despite the fact that as has already been pointed out, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the then Treasurer, Mr Lynch, as he then was, knew at least as early as 1977 of the schemes.
In a letter to the Treasurer, dated 13 February 1978, the Commissioner of Taxation makes the point:

. . . that the Prime Minister has recently expressed a renewed interest concerning a number of current tax avoidance practices that last July were drawn to his attention by an individual outside the Government.
Indeed, it was expressed by the Commissioner on 20 July 1977 that:

The Prime Minister has asked that the documents be examined most urgently. He has expressed the view that, if the schemes are correctly described, appropriate amending legislation should be introduced into Parliament at the earliest possible date.
Unfortunately for the Commissioner of Taxation, he felt constrained somewhat by what he pointed out as being the fact that:

We are spread very thinly with officers who have the necessary background and aptitude to develop anti-avoidance and other tax legislation. Any attempt to take on too much at any one time can be counter-productive.

Nowhere following his comment of that date has there been any indication that action was taken by anybody at all to provide more staff and, indeed, more specialised staff. In fact, of course, as we all know, the razor gang acted at some stage to cut down the number of staff in the office of the Commissioner of Taxation, to what end we are already aware.
By May of 1978 the Commissioner of Taxation was questioning the legality of the schemes under existing law. He said:
. . . I am led to suggest that what is needed is the creation, under the tax law , of a criminal offence of company or trust stripping so that the company or trust cannot meet its tax liability.

In making this suggestion I mention that officers have been pressing the Crown Solicitor to investigate whether prosecution action could be taken under the Crimes Act or the Companies Act against people involved in two cases of 'straw company' evasion. Despite the possibility that such prosecutions may be able to be launched I think that a specific taxation offence of the kind indicated should exist.

But concern at the increasing number of such schemes had reached what could be determined panic proportions in the Taxation Office. On what looks to be page 125 of the document, in which the page numbers are in the most extraordinary sequence, reference is made to straw companies. This comment is made:

In some of the trust schemes referred to above the trustee may be a $2 private company and may not have sufficient assets under its control to pay the tax. This touches on a now-serious problem encountered in other contexts involving the inability to collect outstanding tax payable by companies.
In a growing number of cases-the taxation office in Adelaide alone has reported 30 of them--
This, I might add, was on 24 May 1978--

profitable companies have been acquired by promoters and stripped of their assets, in what amounts to an informal liquidation, leaving no funds in the company by the time it is assessed to pay the tax clearly payable by it. In the meantime, the profitable operations of the stripped companies have been continued by other companies.
The people who are made owners of the stripped companies are themselves men of straw.
In fact that reference to the T. S. Eliot poem may be continued when we realise that the whole thing has in fact ended not with a bang but with a whimper. The document continues:
If legislation imposing tax, and legislation to counter tax avoidance, is not to be frustrated by such evasion--
And the Commissioner underlined the word 'evasion'--
it may be necessary to introduce an effective penal sanction against people who employ these techniques . . .

Accordingly, it is further recommended that officers of the Attorney-General's Department and the Australian Taxation Office be asked, as a matter of urgency, to examine this matter and, if found appropriate, to draw up proposals for the introduction into the income tax law of an appropriate criminal offence against stripping of companies and trusts to evade payment of tax that is legally due.

That matter of urgency was raised on 24 May 1978. Despite the increases that were referred to in that memorandum, the urgency apparently expressed by the Prime Minister in July 1977 had diminished somewhat by the middle of 1978 when the Commissioner was constrained to write in a memorandum to the Secretary of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs:

Submission No. 2290 of 6 June 1978, agreed that officers of this Office, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs examine as a matter of urgency the problem of tax evasion through '' straw'' companies and trusts, and prepare, if appropriate, a Submission on the question of introducing into the income tax law an appropriate criminal offence against the practice. Ministers have directed that any implications that there may be for company law be taken into account.

The fact that the Submission has been before Ministers for some time does not, in my view, detract from the urgency of the matter. It is important that there be the speediest examination and resolution of the problem. Legislation to counter tax avoidance schemes and arrangements will be of limited effectiveness if ''straw company'' evasion is not checked in some way.

By October 1978 the Taxation Office had, as expressed in its memorandum, 'drawn up draft legislation as an aid to firming up our thoughts'. Questions of the onus of proof were being raised, as were definitions of 'director', 'knowledge', 'actions', and things like 'aiding and abetting' and 'conspiracy to defraud'. While the lawyers argued about these, officers of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department were apparently circling somewhat warily around each other to the probable detriment of a speedy solution to the problem.
By November 1979 there was still doubt about whether existing legislation was adequate to prosecute and the Commissioner was attempting to soothe troubled Ministers by pointing out:
. . . while the words are different and the proposed tax measures more elaborately drawn, those measures do not in principle break ground that the company law has not already touched.

Why the Minister should still have been troubled, in view of the comment a year earlier from the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, is beyond my comprehension. This point was made in that comment of 16 November 1978:

The evidence that is disclosed in the draft Cabinet submission indicates that a very serious fraud on the revenue is being carried out through straw companies and trust tax evasions and that the potential for more wide spread abuse is also very real. There is, therefore, an urgent need for an effective deterrent against this form of abuse.
Yet, at least some of the Ministers still appeared to have been troubled by what form the legislation was to take, who was to be challenged under it and what definitions were to apply.
In 1979 the Commissioner made this further point:

I continue to receive indications from our State offices that the problem of ' straw company' and 'straw trust' evasion is already very serious and is growing. It is my considered advice that the situation needs to be remedied urgently and with stern measures. I accept the opinion of the Crown law officers that the evidentiary aid would generally assist the prosecution case although I do not underestimate the evidentiary problems that will remain. Those problems have to be weighed against the consequences for a person who is convicted and there is something in the view that people will be reluctant to risk gaol or the heavy fines proposed once the Government has expressed in legislation its resolution to stamp out these practices.
As late as 7 November the Commissioner had written a particularly strong letter on tax evasion to the Treasurer which said in part:

I am gravely concerned to hear that there may be some question about going ahead with the planned legislation on this matter, the nature and level of penalties proposed being, I understand, a source of difficulty for some of your colleagues.

He then went on to make a series of points which emphasised the criminal and fraudulant nature and the extent of and the cost to the Government of the activities. Yet, the Government lurched on, often appearing at times to be taking one step forward for every two steps it took backwards. Therefore, instead of legislation being passed in the Budget session of 1979 the matter was referred to the Taxation Advisory Committee which consisted, for the most part, of accountants. I am not arguing that those gentlemen had anything to hide or that they were other than people of absolute integrity. But they certainly must have had at least some interest in the outcome of any tax avoidance legislation that was passed. As they appeared to be involved with companies they could not have avoided being asked by their clients about the best way of at least minimising their taxation. It is almost impossible to avoid asking what those accountants who made up the Taxation Advisory Committee should have been expected to produce which could not have been done at least as well by the combined forces of the Taxation Office, the Treasury, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department. One's concern, if one had been moved to ask that question, would have been proven justified by the comments made on the outcome of the TAC inquiry by the Australian Taxation Office in June 1980. Points 43 and 66 of the memorandum indicate some disturbing elements. Point No. 43 states:
The Committee's--
That is the TAC--
alternative would, even in the areas it purports to cover, not offer an effective solution.
On its face it is only a partial one.
Several pages further on paragraph 66 states:
The draft Bills--
That is, the draft Bills put forward by the TAC--

do not attempt to address themselves to tax avoidance in any form. They are not aimed at Slutzkin-type arrangements-arrangements under which tax-paid company profits are liberated tax-free to vendor shareholders.

For something like six months there had been a delay while the Committee looked at the whole problem of tax avoidance and evasion. It then came up with recommendations which did not even face up to the problem which they had been asked to look at. The overwhelming evidence contained in the papers before us indicates that for a variety of unspecified reasons the Government has been stalling over, first, the introduction of questionably necessary legislation and , secondly, its implementation. Indeed, I point out that, at least so far as I am aware, no prosecutions have been made under the new Act in the two years since it came into effect.

Some comment, if not actual criticism too, must be made of the Commissioner of Taxation, who appears, on the surface at least, to have been somewhat too ready to accept the advice of the Crown Solicitor without questioning it and/or too timid to instigate any sort of test case on the information he already had of the existence of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The question remains: Why did it take the Government so long to crack down on a scheme or a series of schemes which were costing the taxpayer so much in lost revenue? It has been put to me on a number of occasions in the past week that the Government should have some moral duty, if it ever gets around to collecting that lost money, to hand it back to the people who suffered in the first place, that is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob raised a question on that.

—I am glad to know that some other South Australian is thinking clearly. There ought to be some way in which the Government can return to pay-as -you-earn taxpayers the money they were forced to provide to supplement the lack of money coming from tax avoiders. The answers to the questions about why it took the Government so long to do anything can be obtained only through the tabling of the documents that the Senate asked for originally, 14 or so of which were not included in the hefty volume before us. They were not included on the rather cautious reasoning of the Solicitor-General that they may impede future prosecutions. I put it to the Senate that surely it is not beyond the combined forces of all concerned to sanitise the Government's dirty linen sufficiently for the missing papers to be brought before us without ruining the outcome of whatever future prosecutions the Government manages to find the energy to undertake. Surely we can find a dry cleaner who is acceptable to all sides of the chamber and who can quickly delete those parts of the still outstanding documents which may inhibit future prosecutions so that this whole unsavoury affair can come to a swift and, one hopes, satisfactory conclusion in the very near future.

SPEECH.PARA: If we do not get those documents and if the Senate cannot make up its mind through the provision of written evidence from the Government about what has been going on since these schemes were first mentioned as far back as 1973, our only real alternative is to take the rather drastic step of calling before the Bar of the Senate those public servants who may be able to tell us what has been going on. That is an action which is, as I said, drastic and one which my party certainly would be loath to support. Nevertheless, we may have to resort to that action in the last instance because of some squeamishness on the part of this Government. It is certainly a move not to be taken lightly. It is for that reason that we support the Labor Party's amendment to the motion. We hope that the Government will act in accordance with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is reviewing those documents which have been tabled in response to Senate notice of motion No. 47 concerning straw companies and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980. In reviewing those documents, which have been in the hands of honourable senators for only a short 24 hours one finds that already, partial though they be, the Australian public has come to its own conclusions as to what those documents reveal. In the headlines of today's Press throughout Australia-the same can be said of the electronic media-revealed in the most graphic form are the conclusions of the most able political commentators in this country on the contents of those documents. What has been suspected by the Australian people for so many years has been definitively, though not finally or fully, revealed. In the Australian Financial Review one reads the headline 'Extraordinary Government History of Inaction'. In the Sydney Morning Herald one reads the headline 'Government inaction on tax lurks dates to 1977'. On page 2 of that journal another headline states 'Cabinet blamed for delay in tax bill'. In the Australian, hardly the most radical journal of left wing politics in Australia, one reads the headline 'Moves on tax cheats blocked by ministers'. Finally in the Daily Telegraph-I am giving only a sample of headlines-today's headline states 'Tax scandal: PM knew five years ago'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the most damning and comprehensive indictment of the monumental lethargy of this Fraser Ministry in the face of the tax rip-off of the last decade. It has gathered force under the lethargic patronage of this Cabinet led by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). What is important to note in the documents-this had been adverted to in those headlines to which I have referred- is that, whilst the Australian Taxation Office itself may take some comfort from the vigorous letters written by Mr O'Reilly, it is quite clear that the Ministers responsibile for protecting the revenue and for enforcing the laws of the land were derelict in their duty. Not only is that revealed but also, for the first time, it is revealed that the Prime Minister failed to take those adequate robust steps which should be expected from the leader of a country whose revenue is being defrauded to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars- a matter in respect of which he had some information back in 1977. Let us not forget for one moment that we are talking about the defrauding of the revenue to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars by those people engaged in tax avoidance schemes-those social parasites and tax bludgers who, because of their activities, required the ordinary Australian PAYE taxpayer to bear a much larger tax burden year after year than should have been the case. The evidence is extremely clear from this documentation. The Ministry at no time sought to invoke the existing law against conspiracy to defraud the revenue. Everything proceeds on the assumption that the existing law was inadequate to lay prosecutions or somehow to recoup the moneys involved. It is quite clear that it is not the existing law that was inadequate but rather the Ministers whose task it was to stop the defrauding of revenue and, as I said, to enforce the laws of the land.

There was no evidence at all as I looked through these papers-I scanned them but briefly-to back the claim of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that Government advisers had thoroughly examined the adequacy of existing law. Indeed, these documents substantiate what was revealed in the proceedings of Senate Estimates Committee A, namely, that the bureaucracy and the Ministry were quite content to put to one side any possibility of successfully undertaking prosecutions in the belief that legislation ought to be drafted to deal with this defrauding of revenue. But would not one expect that if the Ministry really believed that existing law was inadequate it would take steps of absolute and extreme urgency? The most effective haste could be imagined in order to stop these social parasites and tax bludgers from walking away with millions of dollars and denying to this country, this great democracy, those funds which are necessary to facilitate our Government's programs. I speak now as an Australian and certainly not in a party political sense. Instead, one finds a chronology of events which are revealed in this document which causes one to despair.

In mid-July 1977 the Prime Minister wrote to the then Treasurer, Sir Phillip Lynch, who is now languishing in a hospital bed, no doubt to the great relief of this Government when we are dealing with this series of debates, pointing out that urgent steps needed to be taken. But there is no evidence at all of the Prime Minister following up this initial letter. In fact, the first request of the present Treasurer, Mr Howard, to the Cabinet for draft legislation to deal with the problem does not emerge until 12 months later in mid-1978. It is not until October 1979 that Cabinet's initial agreement was obtained to the imposition of criminal sanction. No wonder one gets a cry of despair from Mr O' Reilly, the Commissioner of Taxation.

I take the liberty to repeat much of the content of the letter from Mr O'Reilly , because of its importance in the chronology of events. In a letter dated 7 November 1979, Mr O'Reilly wrote to the Treasurer:

I am gravely concerned to hear that there may be some question about going ahead with the planned legislation on this matter, the nature and level of penalties proposed being, I understand, a source of difficulty for some of your colleagues.
May I make these points:
These activities are criminal in nature and fraudulent-they are not merely an aspect of tax avoidance.
That is the considered opinion of the Commissioner of Taxation. He continues:
The potential of the practices, if left unchecked, is such that legislative action against tax avoidance (including revision of section 260) could be largely to no avail.
This activity is occurring on a large scale daily.
The activities of one promoter are then detailed. The Commissioner continues:
The above figures are but part of the story-in many cases it is futile to even raise assessments.
He stated, in relation to one particular scheme:
It is costing over $1m. per month already and one person merchandising these scheme boasts that his clients will be 'saving' $5m.-$6m. per month.
He makes the very good point:
White collar crimes in other areas of Australian law are punished by imprisonment.
He concludes:

I repeat that the only way to curb white collar crime-of which these practices are an integral and costly part-is by imposing criminal penalties and the threat of gaol. Unless something effective is done along the lines proposed, we may almost as well not bother with anti-avoidance legislation. I say that advisedly.

That is a considered statement of the Commissioner of Taxation to his Minister on 7 November 1979 and yet one has to wait 12 months to find legislation titled the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act being presented to this Parliament and passed into law. Can anyone doubt when regaled with that saga of ineffective ministerial surveillance of the work of the bureaucracy, that behind that chronology of timidity and behind that revelation of an absolute lack of will on the part of the Fraser Ministry lies the fact that at all times Mr Howard was looking over his shoulder at his own back bench members, who themselves were looking over their shoulders at the various members of the Liberal Party who were benefiting from those schemes, as has been adequately and exhaustively revealed in these chambers? There is no doubt that it is the association of the Liberal Party Ministry with those who were taking advantage of these schemes to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars week after week, month after month and year after year which provides the answer to the question of why it should have taken four to five years for effective legislation to be passed by this Parliament in order then to enable effective prosecutions to be undertaken.

The Labor Party has taken the step of ridding itself of that group of painters and dockers who, in their affiliation with the Labor Party, could have brought that great party into some disrepute in the public mind. But there is no doubt that the connections of the Liberal Party with those who benefited from these schemes is far more extensive, far more pervasive and, indeed, riddles the whole of that political organisation in a way which explains the lack of robust activity by the Ministry in relation to these matters until the political pressure led by the Labor Party nationally and by Mr Cain in Victoria in particular when he came into office, became such that steps had to be taken.
I particularly wish to speak in this debate in order to support the amendment moved by Senator Evans, which calls for the tabling of further papers. That amendment reads:

. . . that there be also laid on the table the following additional papers relating to the consideration by the Government of possible legal action against those participating in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, subject to:
(A) The deletion from such papers of the names and identifying characteristics of individuals to the extent necessary to satisfy the requirements of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and

(B) The editing of such papers by the royal commissioner, Mr Costigan, in consultation with the Crown Solicitor, to ensure that no material is published which in his opinion would prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings against those involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

I have foreshadowed a slight alteration to the wording which will be moved by my colleague, the shadow Attorney-General, in a few moments. They involve only some three or four words which strengthen that attempt by the Senate to obtain for itself the fullest possible range of documents to enable it finally to come to what is already a conclusion available to it-namely, the ineptitude and lethargy of this Government in following up tax avoidance on the huge scale of which we are all aware.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government could, of course, ignore the resolution.

—The Government would ignore this further amendment at its peril because it would then be saying that the Senate-which owes much of its character and status to its oft asserted claim to be a chamber whose review of the activities of the Executive can take place in a manner not possible in the House of Representatives- could not be fulfilling its role. That claim has to be substantiated by action in the face of Executive hostility. If honourable senators on the other side of this chamber refuse to join in support of this amendment in a way which prevents this chamber from carrying out that function which Senator Lewis has spoken most passionately about as the Senate's proper function, namely, the review of the activities of the Executive in a fair, impartial and a ruthless way, if need be, they reveal themselves as the creatures of that Executive. The Senate has a particular role, formalised in many committees, of scrutiny of the activities of the Executive, and that is what this amendment is all about. We should not be frustrated impeded or prevented from carrying out that task by the Government's refusal to table the very documents which lie at the heart of the question.
—What if it does? What will the Labor Party do then?
—I will remind the Government, amongst other things, of Senator Withers's statement of 9 July 1975 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is up to the Government to produce the necessary information which will clear its name or which will condemn it. I put to the Senate that the Government has a duty to produce full disclosure, not selective tabling of documents.

There one has in the clearest terms from the then Leader of the Government the obligation on a Government to respond in the fullest possible way to the request of the Senate for the tabling of those documents which will allow it to form its fullest opinion. I repeat what Senator Withers said:
I put to the Senate that the Government has a duty to produce full disclosure, not selective tabling of documents.

Here we have such a selective tabling. Here we have a refusal to table, not documents which are only barely relevant to our inquiry, but documents which lie at the very heart of the matter, the most relevant documents of all-those which contain the opinions of learned counsel as to whether the law which existed before the passage of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was adequate. They go to the heart of the charge against this Government that it failed to marshal all of the vast resources available to it to combat this fraudulent denial of moneys to the Treasury.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) said that that analysis of the documents that were missing was stupid. If he can show that in some way my understanding of the importance of those documents is dense and stupid, so be it , but I doubt whether he will be able to convince the Senate that that is the case. As I say, the Senate is not asking that every file be ransacked and brought into this chamber, or every piece of paper that is barely relevant to the issue. It is merely asking for those documents which are absolutely crucial, absolutely vital and which absolutely go to the heart of the matter-that is, those documents which relate to the understanding which the Government could have had available to it of its ability to undertake prosecutions under the then existing law.

I am not surprised that the Minister finds this embarrassing, because at Question Time he found himself unable to tell the Senate whether the Special Prosecutor could undertake prosecutions in relation to matters arising before the passage of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. Therefore, his understanding of the Government's willingness to deal with these matters, even now, is defective. The documentation reveals a total history of defective understanding by the Government, from the very beginning of what is possible by way of prosecution. As I say, it starts with the Prime Minister and the effort then becomes bogged down in a mire of bureaucratic in-fighting and a total lack of political will on the part of his Ministry.

There is only one way in which this matter will be finally resolved to the satisfaction of the Australian people. The full tabling of the documents will enable the Senate to come to some conclusions. But the final resolution of this matter, the final robust dealing with it by a government committed to ordinary taxpayers being able to pay tax honestly, knowing that those on a much higher income are also paying their fair share of the nation's revenue, will only come about with a change of government and with the placing on the Treasury benches in the House of Representatives of an Australian Labor Party government led by Mr Bill Hayden. I assure all who are listening, all who read Hansard and all those representatives of the public who are in the gallery today that only as a result of the election of a Labor government will we finally have a fair and equitable tax system in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to delete the word 'might' which appears in line 3 of paragraph (b) and to substitute the word 'would'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found much to commend in Senator Tate's address to the Senate except for the rather emotive statement he made in the last part of his speech about the return of a Hayden government, which he said would do something about tax measures. Members of the Australian Labor Party last night did nothing about tax measures when it had the opportunity, during consideration of the sales tax Bills, to nail the Government and to ensure that it gave some recognition to the burden that its imposition of indirect taxation would impose on ordinary working men and women throughout Australia. It had that opportunity. Senator Walsh was in charge of the legislation, but that one man slum did not even give the Senate the opportunity to nail the Government, as he should have done. Instead, he chose to embark upon his usual snide, ironic, untruthful remarks about other honourable senators in this place.
—Order, Senator! That was a reflection on a senator. I ask you to withdraw those remarks.
—I withdraw.
—I raise a point of order. I thought that the bulk of what was said was unobjectionable. Mr Acting Deputy President, I assume you were objecting to the use of the word 'untruthful'.
—Yes, and the use of the word 'snide' also.
—As long as it was that. We have before us-
—I understand that there were other unparliamentary terms, to which I have not referred, in those sentences-which, in any event, the senator has withdrawn.

—We are dealing with a motion that we take note of the papers that have been presented to us in the paper termed: 'Documents tabled in response to Senate Motion No. 47 (given 7 September 1982) concerning straw companies and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980'. To that motion an amendment moved by Senator Evans seeks further documentation and asks that such documentation be so edited as to take out any material that would prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings against those involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I am anxious, of course, to ensure that that proviso be maintained. I would even go further: I hope that in some way, before this motion is proceeded with, it could be couched in more general terms, rather than specify only bottom -of-the-harbour schemes. I hope that it will use the more general term 'tax evaders'. Therefore, I propose to support a proposition which would include such words as I first indicated in respect of this matter on 8 September 1982. Honourable senators may recall that on that occasion I indicated that I would support the tabling of certain documents, with the following proviso:

SPEECH.PARA: And with such papers edited by Mr F. X. Costigan, Q.C., in consultation with the Crown Solicitor, so as to delete from the papers any material which would prejudice any future prosecution of tax evaders.

Obviously, the material that is currently before us includes tax evasion schemes other than the so-called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I believe that it would be possible to extend the amendment that is currently before us to ensure that all tax evasion schemes would be included, and the perpetrators of those schemes would be denied any unnecessary advantage as a result of the tabling of these documents.

Let me place in perspective the debate at this moment. On 25 August 1982 the Senate debated a motion moved by the Opposition calling for the resignation of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard). On that occasion I had no information available to me, nor was any documentation placed before the Senate, to convince me to vote for that motion. I therefore voted against the motion and it failed. On 7 September 1982 a proposition was advanced that certain documents be tabled in the Senate. I was disposed at that time, and am still disposed, to support the proposition for the documents to be tabled. I insisted at that time that they should be edited in the manner that I have mentioned previously in this speech. I still support that viewpoint although I suspect that members of the Opposition may now be wanting to obtain retrospective evidence for the decision that they made on 25 August 1982. I am not in a position to know what exercise influenced them in their decision, nor do I criticise them for taking that particular stand at that particular time. They may have known more than I knew. However, I am in the position, as an Independent senator, of having to judge matters on their merits as they come before the chamber. It is a strange quirk of democracy that one has to listen so intently these days to the debate in this chamber in order to make up one's mind .

TALK.START.PARA: —You might be allowed to join the Democrats.
—It certainly imposes a great burden on one's time.
—On one's eardrums, too.

—Yes, on one's eardrums. I could not at that stage go along with the proposition and I believe, probably because the Opposition is engaged now in attempting to obtain some retrospective proof, that it has already shot its bolt by reason of the fact that it did move that motion prematurely on 7 September 1982. As I said on that occasion, part of that motion was not premature. I would have gone along with the censure of the Government. A reading of the documents now before the Senate shows that the Government ought to be censured. But at that time I was not prepared to go along with the calling for the heads of Senator Durack and Mr Howard. As I say, I believe that probably the Opposition put the cart before the horse and maybe it has shot its bolt. Maybe that result will never come about.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that we can discuss these matters and these papers in a vacuum. We have to refer to a previous debate that has taken place today. If I am not out of order-I am sure, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you will pick me up if I am out of order-I say that I believe these documents show that certainly failings within the Public Service have highlighted the problems that the Government and the taxation revenue were faced with at that time. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has suggested that the way to overcome this is for a thorough investigation of the Public Service. I remind the Senate-as the Senate has not been previously reminded, as I understand it-that such an examination did take place in early 1976 and the person who was chosen by the current Prime Minister to undertake the examination was none other than Sir Henry Bland. He was the man appointed to what was known as the Administrative Review Committee. Also on that Committee was none other than the person who is now proposed as the Chairman of the new inquiry, Mr John Reid-an eminent industrialist and businessman.

I hazard a guess that had the recommendations made by the Administrative Review Committee, presided over by Sir Henry Bland and on which Mr John Reid, Mr John Taylor and Mr Gerald Gleeson served, been followed then maybe a number of the problems with which the Government is now faced would not have emerged. Of course that is guesswork. Maybe it is informed guesswork, but let me say this: The report of that Committee was never made public. I would certainly like to see-I am sure the Government would not allow us to do so-the report of that inquiry made public. Sir Henry Bland was a man who, over many years, gave service to successive governments. He was a man who was asked by the Prime Minister to perform certain functions when the Liberal Government was elected in 1975. He performed those functions to the best of his ability and in fact he did so with the accumulated knowledge and experience that he had obtained in the Public Service in Australia over a great number of years.

As I mentioned, I hazard the guess that had the recommendations of the Administrative Review Committee been implemented then we may not have been faced with the problems with which we are faced at this time. Again I emphasise that that is only a guess because I have nothing firm to go on. The report has not been presented to us by the Government and therefore we really do not know with any degree of hindsight whether or not that would have been the case. Only the Prime Minister and a number of his close Cabinet colleagues know that. But it is interesting to note that the very person whom the Prime Minister has now chosen to head up the new inquiry was a member of the Administrative Review Committee.

I believe that the people of Australia would be interested to know what is contained in the documents which the Opposition motion now seeks to have tabled. Why would they like to know that? I think they are entitled to know the thrust of advice that was available to senior public servants and to the Ministers at that time. They are entitled to know whether, on a reasonable assessment of that advice, certain action should have been taken. My only regret is that the Opposition did not move this motion before it chose to include in its motion of 25 August 1982 the calling for the heads of two Ministers. But that is water under the bridge. It is important, however, for the Senate to pursue this request. How it will be enacted and how it will be accomplished are matters for determination by Mr President or by the Executive Government. Because of circumstances beyond my control, I have not been in a position to seek information-a position chosen, of course, because of circumstances that arose last night-and to know precisely how this particular measure is to be enacted. The amendment says:

. . . and that there be also laid on the Table the following additional papers relating to the consideration by the Government of possible legal action against those participating in bottom of the harbour schemes, subject to . . .
Then it goes on to refer to section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and, in paragraph (b), the sanitisation procedure.

However, who will ensure that these papers are laid upon the Table? Once the motion is passed, will the executive Government get in touch with Mr Costigan to relay to him the Senate's decision, or is this task to be performed by the President of the Senate? These are the questions that ought to be answered before a vote is taken on this matter. There are those two questions. As to the first, I am happy to support the amendment moved by Senator Evans provided that it involves and includes all tax evasion systems. On the second, we must be clear about who is responsible for the implementation of this motion or the amendment to the motion when it becomes a resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you allow me to answer by way of interjection, Senator?
—Yes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Odgers's Australian Senate Practice says on page 585:

INTERJECT.PARA: Upon a motion being agreed to for the tabling of papers, the Clerk transmits a copy of the resolution to the responsible Department.
If the Minister in charge of the responsible department fails to comply, the machinery relating to contempt of the Senate then comes into play.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. Senator Evans obviously would know more about the particular opinions here than I would, and whether they relate to schemes other than bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The motion specifically zeroes in on bottom- of-the-harbour schemes, but if there were, within those opinions, certain advice which may be prejudicial to a prosecution or legal proceeding against tax evaders of another kind, perhaps we ought to broaden that a little way, and I would support the amendment in those circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a debate today which, in the main, has focused on the amendment moved by Senator Evans with respect to the production of additional papers, which amendment replaces a notice of motion which he withdrew during his speech and of which he gave notice some time ago. I indicated to the Senate on the day that that notice of motion was given, or on the day after, that the Government had determined to take an open approach on the disclosure of documents and that it intended to produce documents freely, limited only by the question of prejudice which might occur if certain documents were tabled. Time was sought to give the Government a chance to go through the relevant documentation and to respond to the motion. There was, I think, agreement to that course, the caution being put down by Senator Evans, on behalf of the Opposition, that he did not want undue delay, for reasons which I accept, for both political and practical purposes.
—We also reserved our right to challenge particular documents.

—Yes. There is no suggestion of bad faith in that sense. If there were some peculiar inference to be drawn from my remarks which gave rise to that , it was accidental. As I indicated, the Government's wish and, in particular, the wish, I think it fair to say, of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was that there should be openness in this area so that what had actually happened could be assessed. The matter has been approached on that basis.

SPEECH.PARA: When I uttered the word 'stupid'-and I thought that I was speaking very sotto voce-during Senator Tate's speech, it was not that I was accusing Senator Tate of being stupid, but rather that I thought that at a particular point of his argument he was putting a stupid argument, because he accused the Government of having engaged in a selective tabling of documents when in fact what has always been sought, as I understood it, by the Opposition, and what is sought even in the amendment before us today, is a selective tabling of documents, the selection being based on the agreed position that there can be documents with respect to which disclosure might prejudice legal proceedings. I understand that whilst there is a difference between the Government and the Opposition on the degree or the point of detail, there is no argument between us on the proposition that there ought not to be disclosure which would be of assistance to those who might otherwise be subject to prosecution, or indeed, to pick up a point made by Senator Harradine, other legal proceedings or prosecutions going beyond the question of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I make that explanation about my use of the word 'stupid' because I have a healthy respect for Senator Tate. I just thought that on this occasion he was using an argument which really overlooked the basic thrust of his own party's request in this area, which is for a selection of documents, the exclusions being based on some method of determining which material should not be published in order to avoid prejudice to the conduct of legal proceedings.

The speeches made this afternoon have almost suggested that too much has been tabled. In between accusations of inadequate material, there have been accusations that a great deal has been put down that is, perhaps, not helpful. I can only say that it is most unusual for a government to have put before the Parliament and hence the people of Australia such a wealth of material going across a fair period in a significant area of government administration and an area in which it has been subject to robust criticism by the Opposition. The material includes advice offered by the Taxation Office to the Government, correspondence between Ministers, draft Cabinet submissions, and material which even on, I think, the most generous interpretation of what might have been contained in the fullest possible freedom of information legislation would not generally have been available. The fact is that there has been very wide disclosure because the Government appreciates that there is a public interest in seeing the totality of the scene.

I remind the Senate that the dispute before us this afternoon is a dispute which involves the question whether there should be even greater disclosure, in the light of the advice that the Government has received that the material could be prejudicial. I should like to refer to the statement put down by the Treasurer because he there explained the basis of the exclusions which were made by the Government. I think that it is necessary to go into that matter because I think that there was some misunderstanding on the part of Senator Evans in part of what he said about the basis of the exclusions. The Treasurer said:

The third batch consists of three legal opinions. The Solicitor-General has considered that counsels' opinions and other legal advice referred to in items 2 , 7, 12, 13, 14, 16, 19, 20, 21 and 22 of the Senate resolution should not be tabled on the ground that public disclosure of the contents would be harmful to the administration of justice. He personally examined each of the documents in question.

Senator Evans made something of the point that the Treasurer had said that there was an exclusion on the basis that the contents would be harmful to the administration of justice and I think he said that he saw that as too broad an exclusion and not as one necessarily going to the question of prosecution. I go on to quote the Treasurer because there is a more definite explanation of what is meant by those earlier words in his statement. The Treasurer went on to say:
He has stated that, in his view--
'His' means the Solicitor-General's-

harm would be caused both to those who may be prosecuted and to those who may be proceeded against civilly, or to the cause of the prosecutor or civil complainant. In many instances both sides would be injured. That injury would not, in his view, be avoided by exercising names.

We have a clear statement that it is the view of the Solicitor-General that harm could be caused in a number of ways, either to those who may be prosecuted and those who may be proceeded against civilly or to the cause of the prosecutor or civil complainant and that there was a possibility of injury to both sides. That is a serious matter and I understand that, in the broad, it would be accepted by honourable senators from all parts of the chamber as being an appropriate reason for not producing the documentation. The issue is a narrower one and that is the question of whose opinion should be accepted by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a difference between harm to individuals and prejudice to proceedings.

—I think the words are quite clear. There could be injury to the legal cause of those who are engaged on either side of either the prosecution or civil action involving taxation matters. I think the basic query is one as to whose advice should be taken by the Government. My view that that is the basic dispute is strengthened by the amendment which Senator Evans has made this afternoon. It is an amendment which, in a sense, has left me not quite without instructions but certainly arguing on a brief which is not quite the brief which I had when I entered this chamber. What is now to be excluded, if the motion is carried, is not material which might prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings but material which would prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings. The effect of that is to say that there should be a narrower exclusion because there has to be certainty that there would be prejudice.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, I think that is far too strong a test to place on whether or not the documents should be produced. I would have thought that to achieve that degree of certainty requires a degree of prescience which even a Solicitor- General, an ombudsman or the Royal Commissioner might find difficult to produce. I think it is far too generous a suggestion that only material which, in the opinion of some eminent legal person advising the Government and the Senate, would-not might-prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings should be withheld. I question whether in that form the motion ought to receive the support of the Australian Democrats and the Independent. Presumably, since it is moved by the Opposition spokesman, it certainly has the support of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Jesuits would be proud of you.

—I find it rather flattering for the honourable senator to throw in the fact that Jesuits would be proud of me, because I am only a Christian Brothers boy. We lack the sophistication and sophistry which are sometimes attributed to those who have the more intellectual training that can be achieved at the hands of Jesuits.
—Not sophistry, but casuistry.

—I accept that correction. I say seriously to those who come into the chamber to listen to the arguments-Senator Harradine has recently classified himself as being in that camp; that may equip him to to be a Democrat because they certainly proudly claim that during their early period in this chamber they intended to listen to what was said-and who are still open-minded enough to listen to the arguments that are being put forward in this debate that to suggest that any material should be published unless, in the clear opinion of some eminent legal person, it would prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings is a bad approach and I really believe that it should not be supported by the Senate. For that reason alone I believe that the amendment moved by Senator Evans should be rejected.

SPEECH.PARA: I also pick up the point which was made by Senator Harradine. I adopt it and support it. The amendment as it is put forward is far too narrow. It requires us to withhold only documents which would prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings against those involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. There are, of course, other areas of tax avoidance which are picked up in some of the opinions which have been sought. For that reason, again I believe that since the Senate would not wish to see prejuduce to either civil or criminal proceedings in any of those cases, we should not accept the amendment which has been put forward by Senator Evans. I go back to the Treasurer's statement because part of it is relevant to the point that I have just made. The Treasurer stated:

The Government has decided that it should accept the advice of the Solicitor- General on this matter. I believe that there is no other proper course that the Government could follow, even though the opinions, if they were able to be tabled, would show that counsels' opinion were not all 'one way' on the availability of adequate and effective legal remedies in the cases that they related to. Thus, the opinion of counsel referred to in item 2 of the Evans motion advised that there was insufficient evidence to warrant criminal proceedings on a charge under section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act.
He went on to say:
The Lockhart opinion referred to in item 7 of the motion--
It now has a different number because we are speaking to the amendment as amended and not to the original notice of motion--
while it advised of reasonable prospects of success, recognised the difficulties inherent in establishing a charge of conspiracy to defraud or similar charges.

The Attorney-General pointed out to that Senate on 7 September 1982 that this opinion did not relate to a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. He also referred to the question of further action being taken on this case and made the obvious point, now confirmed by the Solicitor-General, that the opinion should not be tabled.

The position is that the Senate faces a situation in which the Solicitor-General , the second law officer of the Commonwealth, has advised the Government in the terms which I have laid before it. Who is the Solicitor-General? The Solicitor- General is, of course, an independent statutory officer who, under the Law Officers Act 1964, is given very considerable statutory independence. I was pleased that on this occasion Senator Evans was careful not to suggest that the Opposition was throwing doubts on either the political or professional independence of the Solicitor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or his legal ability.
—Or his legal ability. So it is common ground in this place that we have a person who is politically independent, statutorily independent, has high legal ability--
—Political independence in a party political sense. Don't slide.

—I am not trying to slide in this speech. I believe that the assistance that I am getting from Senator Evans is of no help to me or the Senate. I was not trying in any sense to gloss on the points which have been made. I remind honourable senators-I am sorry that we do not as yet have Hansard for the early part of this afternoon's debate-of the care that Senator Evans took, unlike in some of his earlier comments in this discussion, to be quite clear that he was not casting doubts on the ability, the position or the independence of the Solicitor-General. Today he certainly did refer back to what he saw as the view of the Solicitor-General on matters of Executive privilege and so on. He referred to some historical events in which some members of this chamber were involved in 1975. But the fact is that we have a person who, by statute, is given independence and is given the function under section 12 of the Law Officers Act to act as counsel for the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, or the Commonwealth itself and for a Minister or an officer of the Commonwealth and so on. The position of the Solicitor-General is clear and established and, in the view of the Government, establishes him as the appropriate person from whom to seek advice, advice on which this Government is going to have to act and advice which is going to affect, in the end, the conduct of prosecutions for which this Government will again be held responsible in the ongoing interest which has been taken in the development of this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the Government is aware that a number of honourable senators have made suggestions as to who might be involved in vetting the material. I have not spoken directly with the Attorney on this matter for reasons which will be understood. Over the last week or so he has not been available to talk about business matters. But I have checked and been advised by the Department that the Attorney, in company with a senior officer of the Department, did have a discussion with Mr Costigan on 10 September in light of the suggestion which at that time had been made by Senator Harradine that he would move that the papers be examined by Mr Costigan in consultation with the Crown Solicitor. I am advised that in that conversation Mr Costigan said that it would be outside his terms of reference and that in any event it would not be appropriate for him to carry out such a role. I was not privy to that conversation and I cannot give any more detail to it than that. But that is the basis upon which I understand--

TALK.START.PARA: —The investigation of Mr Horgan was also outside his terms of reference.

—That is a matter on which I am not in a position to advise the Senate finally, as I said this morning, but that may well prove to be the case. But the fact is that, quite apart from the question of the terms of reference, the advice which I received through the normal departmental channels is that Mr Costigan was saying not only that it was outside his terms of reference but also that in any event it would not be appropriate for him to carry out such a role. Therefore, the Government has gone to the Solicitor-General who has all of the qualities that we have just been talking about.
—He identified nine of these 14 documents in his report. He identified them.

—It is one thing to identify the documents. It is another to provide the opinions to government of the sort which are sought in this amendment. I simply say to the Senate that that matter was raised following a suggestion made in this place, with the result that I have just indicated. For the variety of reasons that I have expressed, the view of the Government is that this amendment is not appropriate. I believe it is extremely important to the Australian community, and of course to the Government, that the dealings in these matters should be both expeditious and effective. We now have the legal advice from the Solicitor-General that there is a possibility of prejudice if these documents are produced in the way that is sought. I believe that on that basis it would be wrong for the Senate to place its judgment above that of the Solicitor-General, and to endeavour to impose a solution in a situation where the Senate will not be held responsible for what follows, but the Government will. I believe that it would be quite improper for this chamber to try to exercise power in the way that it has over and above the opinion which has been put before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I address my remarks very seriously to those honourable senators who are capable of making an independent judgment. I accept that all honourable senators in the Australian Labor Party, for reasons that are right and proper according to their light, are incapable of making their own judgment on this matter once a firm decision has been taken by the party; we know that none of them is going to cross the floor. But I ask the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine to consider very seriously the risk of prejudice that could occur if material which informed those who might be involved in prosecutions or civil proceedings of legal views, both positive and negative, of the prospects of success and so on was disclosed. I ask that the amendment be opposed and that the material which has already been submitted be accepted as the adequate response to the Senate's original request.

There is one other point. Senator Evans, just before he spoke, drew my attention to a matter which I had already had drawn to my attention, namely, that item 12 in his amendment represents new material in terms of its not having been mentioned in the original list. That of itself might not be thought critical because clearly the Government has gone through a great deal of additional material and produced what is thought to be relevant to the spirit of the request originally made. However, on this occasion I have been unable to get clear instructions on the precise status of this document in the terms in which it is described; that is, being the 18-page report of a senior investigation officer Todman to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in 1979. Of course, it may well be that that is a report which directly impinges upon aspects of cases which could be involved in prosecutions. I simply do not know and in opposing this motion I do so on the basis that I take no final stance on that particular request on behalf of the Government because I think I will need to obtain more information. I have been unable to get it in the time available since this debate commenced. I only sought advice at that time. I ask the Senate to reject the amendment moved by Senator Evans and I hope that that course will be followed. I do that, by way of reminder, on two bases: Firstly, the substitution of the word 'would' in my view greatly increases the risk of having material brought in which might prejudice a prosecution or civil proceedings. By definition, that must be so. Secondly, because in the view of the Solicitor- General it would be or could be detrimental to prosecutions or civil proceedings .

I do not want to say very much on the broader issues which were canvassed with less intensity in the debate. However, I wish to remind the Senate that in looking at the material, it is important to look at the totality of the material and not merely to try to dive into the heap and to find one narrow area in which one can say 'we find real cause for complaint'. This morning I answered a question from Senator Evans on a particular segment of delay. I am happy to concede that it is open to any honourable senator to raise any particular area which is disclosed by these documents and to seek further information. I suspect that I will not be as fortunate on every occasion to be as appropriately briefed as I was this morning on the particular point raised. This morning I was able to respond immediately. But the point I really wish to make is that the totality of that documentation demonstrates the point that I mentioned this morning at Question Time. In the years with which we are concerned-which are fundamentally the years of this Government because as Senator Evans is wont to say the failures of the previous government after all occurred over a relatively brief period in the field of trying to do something about tax avoidance-if one looks at the areas in which this Government has been operating, one finds not a single line of inquiry on a single taxation problem but a whole range of inquiries across a great range of taxation schemes which were being devised in the community, many of which posed a substantial threat to the revenue and some of which I understand the Opposition would say are of more significance, or were of greater significance in terms of revenue lost, than bottom-of-the-harbour schemes which we made criminally punishable in 1980.

In the past the Government has included material in Hansard which sets out the various things which were tackled during the life of the Government. I wish to refer quickly again to that because it demonstrates the context in which these matters were occurring. It was not a context in which nothing was happening. It was a context in which a series of things were happening across a series of fronts in the general area of trying to prevent the leakage of revenue through tax avoidance schemes. It would not be useful to the time of the Senate to read this list. Rather, I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a list of tax avoidance legislation which has been implemented by the Government over the years 1977 through to 1982 as an indication of the breadth of the activity which has taken place at the bureaucratic level, at the political level and, indeed, here in the Parliament at the legislative level, in an endeavour to stamp out what all of us agree has been an anti-social level of tax avoidance which has been no good for the country and no good for those who have been paying their full share of taxation.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust that the Senate will reject the amendment moved by Senator Evans and that it will accept that considerable effort has gone, both at the bureaucratic and the political level, to tackle the problems that we are concerned about. However, I would like to say that in voting on this amendment one is not voting on a motion which endorses the Government's every act in the tax field. What we are voting on is an amendment which suggests that there should be some action to publish further material unless it would prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings. I believe that is a serious step that the Senate should not take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek to accommodate a query raised by Senator Harradine and reiterated by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in his reply. It relates to the text of paragraph (b) of the amendment. I seek leave to delete the words 'bottom-of-the-harbour' and substitute the words 'tax evasion and avoidance' at the end of paragraph (b). I believe the point was well taken by Senator Harradine and by Senator Chaney. The amendment was ill-drafted in that sense.
—What words do you want to delete?
—Delete the words 'bottom-of-the-harbour' and substitute the words 'tax evasion and avoidance'.
—Wherever occurring?
—It occurs twice.
—It is in the preamble.

—The preamble, I think, is all right because anything that does not deal in some way or other with bottom-of-the-harbour issues would not come within the frame of reference of this amendment. What the honourable senator was concerned to do was to ensure that nothing was put into the public domain which could prejudice prosecutions in other classes of tax avoidance or tax evasion cases. I think that is a point well taken. I think the amendment was ill-drafted to the extent that it did not accommodate that point. The amendment now reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings against those involved in tax evasion and avoidance schemes.
Leave granted.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Evans's amendment as amended) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
