DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED FRUITS EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent weeks the Senate has been discussing, correctly so in my view, criticisms about the Executive Government's role in the collection of revenue-in other words, the degree, the magnitude, of wholesale tax evasion and tax avoidance. I think it is a matter of regret that yesterday Senator Austin Lewis suggested that we were wasting our time debating these sorts of matters when we ought to be dealing with matters associated with legislation. In the other House this afternoon I heard a Government speaker defending the Government's role in the whole question of tax evasion and tax avoidance, suggesting that in fact the Government was defending the principles of parliamentary democracy. As we would understand parliamentary democracy parliament itself has the role to exercise some power over the Executive Government. That precisely is what the Senate has been seeking to do. We just happen to be in that rather fortunate position of there being a majority of senators who are prepared to play their correct role of exercising some jurisdiction over the deficiencies in the Executive Government in respect of tax evasion and tax avoidance. We have been looking at bottom-of-the-harbour schemes . We have been looking at asset stripping and trust stripping exercises which show the complete deficiency in the role of the Australian Taxation Office as a result of this Government's lack of attention to introducing strong enough legislation and regulations that will force every person liable to pay his due portion of tax to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be relating my few remarks this afternoon to a matter that has been brought to my attention and which has operated in the post-war years; that is, the 30 of the 33 years in which we have had conservative governments since 1949. It has even been suggested that some of the deficiencies that exist are as a result of the Whitlam Government, for three years, not being able to rectify these matters. But over all of the post-war years there has been a great variety of weaknesses in the taxation legislation. A case which has been brought to my attention officially in my capacity as shadow Minister for home affairs show how tax havens exist and are countenanced and permitted by the inactivity of the Fraser Liberal-National Country Party Government.

I want to take the opportunity today to give an outline of one of the many ways in which unscrupulous and ruthless operators, people who are in positions of so- called trust, power and influence-the sorts of people who are close to the conservative parties of this country-can and do manipulate their affairs and shirk their responsibilities to the ordinary taxpayers of Australia. As a result , the ordinary average citizen of this country pays a larger share of taxation. It is my view that as a result of these sorts of schemes which have been permitted to operate, because of the attitude of this Government, the average taxpayer is paying something like $32 a week more than he should be.

Let us take a look at the operations of a certain John Terence Brown, late of Sydney but more recently a resident of Norfolk Island. John Terence Brown was admitted as a solicitor in 1972 but sold up his practice in 1980 and moved to Norfolk Island where he continued to do legal work as well as becoming a member of the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly and, until recently, a member of the governing conservative executive in that area, a trustee of the Norfolk Island Art Gallery and a Director of Norfolk Island Airlines. So he is part of the establishment, he is part of the atmosphere which this Government tolerates.

In the financial year 1979-80 a certain company by the name of Holding Rubber Products Pty Ltd, registered in Victoria, made a substantial profit and was liable therefore to pay tax on this profit. The company decided it did not want to pay that tax, that it wanted to keep the money due to the Australian Government and the Australian people for its own use. A chain of quite remarkable events then took place which put into motion the processes to strip that company of its assets, to avoid the payment of the tax due, to line the pockets of the people involved in this bald-faced dishonesty and finally to consign the company to the bottom of the Pacific Ocean-not the bottom of the harbour but the bottom of the Pacifc Ocean.

The first step was to sell the company's assets to another company. For this purpose a shell company was found which took over the assets and became Holding Rubber Products (Victoria) Pty Ltd. This company also retained the tax liability . Two days after this transfer John Terence Brown was appointed a director and on the same day various sums by way of loans and journal entries were passed back and forth in order to pay off the original shareholders in the company and place the remaining funds in the hands of the prime mover in the scheme-that is, after some debts were paid off, an amount of $1.6m was placed in the hands of John Terence Brown. At this stage, however, approximately a quarter of a million dollars disappeared and it has not yet been uncovered despite court actions to try to establish what happened.

The next step in this elaborate scheme was to lend the $1.6m asset to a certain Wharton Finance Ltd and to change the name of Holding Rubber Pty Ltd to Fermoyle Pty Ltd. Of course, the laws of this country permit this sort of procedure to take place. It was only because of the activities of the Corporate Affairs Office in Victoria that some of these facts started to unfold. Wharton Finance repaid the loan to Fermoyle which then made a so-called donation-heaven forbid- to the Norfolk Island Art Gallery of that same amount. The Norfolk Island Art Gallery used that donation to repay a loan supposedly taken out to buy works of art. Thus, the amount was once again returned to Wharton Finance. I will talk about the Norfolk Island Art Gallery in a moment.

The key to all this paper shuffling was the provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act that allows such a donation to be made a taxation deduction. In my view it is criminal that the Government permits this sort of behaviour and legitimises it. This effectively reduced the tax liability of the original company to nil and placed the profits of the original company back in the hands of the original beneficiaries without the liability of paying tax. The way this donation was achieved was a particularly extreme example of abused trust. It indicates the degree to which individuals in high places-educated people and people who are part of the establishment-are able to get around the laws and the decent honest practices of this country. The Norfolk Island Art Gallery, of which the same John Terence Brown, a solicitor from Sydney and a member of the Legislative Assembly, is a trustee, had to agree to this donation, had to agree to its being used to buy virtually worthless paintings and had to agree also to put a totally unrealistic astronomical value on those paintings. He had $1.6m to buy paintings which he could have bought for $600, $6,000 or any amount one likes. He then claimed that they were worth $1.6m.

The major manoeuvring having been completed, it was then necessary only to sweep the remains under the carpet. That is what he set out to do. In fact Fermoyle Pty Ltd, the company with the tax liability, was put into voluntary liquidation. The same John Terence Brown-this shows the guile and the deceit of individuals who are trained in law to protect the community and how they are able to use the laws for their own benefit-then appointed himself as the liquidator of the company. There is just no limit to the brazen way in which such people use the laws of this country. This liquidator then proceeded to lodge liquidation declarations with the Corporate Affairs Office in Victoria, declarations containing brazen untruths in order to cover his dishonest intentions. This is the type of dishonesty that exists and is taken advantage of by persons of this pathetic calibre in Australian society.

In my view these are matters which fall within the area of tax evasion but unfortunately, because of the legislative way in which this Government makes tax collections, they fall within the area of tax avoidance. This is what is going on in business and legal circles tens of thousands of times. It is a feature of the way in which tax operates in this country. This parasitic underworld-that is all it can be described as-with a legal framework, a legal front, is the burden that ordinary taxpayers of Australia have to carry. They have to carry the main tax burden. That is the principal reason why 53 per cent of all national revenue collected by the Federal Government comes from the PAYE section of the community . Of course, according to the document, nothing is done either by the Australian Taxation Office or this Government to rectify this sort of malfunction of the whole tax system.

Legal action was required and a judgment, delivered on 7 May 1982, set aside the liquidator's role in this whole process in order that there could be some justice and determination of the matter concerned. This indicates how absurd it is for this Government to claim that it acts on behalf of all the people of Australia. I am certain that if we were able to look at the whole tax structure and at the way the Australian Taxation Office functions-I am not criticising the Australian Taxation Office, unless, of course, it has failed to advise the Australian Government of the sorts of lurks and perks that go to make up the way in which the tax system operates-we would find a deficiency; we would find that the Government has failed to carry out its proper obligations with respect to tax revenue.

I was somewhat disturbed to find, on the very day after the Treasurer (Mr Howard) returned from his sojourn overseas, that he stated that deficiencies existed within the Australian Taxation Office. As has been said in the debate generally, the Government is attempting to shift the blame away from itself and onto sections of the Public Service. It matters not whether it is in the area of tax, the medical fraud, the Department of Primary Industry, the Australian Dairy Corporation or the meat inspection scandal; the Government clearly is trying to make the Public Service and its senior officers the scapegoats. In the particular case to which I am referring-the Australian Government was aware of this case because it was party to some of the proceedings-the Government was aware that John Terence Brown was using Norfolk Island as a haven. Where is the legislation it should have introduced into this Parliament to close off those sorts of loopholes? Mr Brown, not only with respect to this issue but also with respect to other issues, is involved in tax matters on Norfolk Island. That is the reason he and many of his colleagues live on Norfolk Island. I do not have time to talk about the tax haven that exists in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Again that is an area which comes within our jurisdiction.

In due course the Opposition will be seeking to bring to the public's attention the means by which unscrupulous wealthy people-people who have considerable assets and profits-are using the loopholes and the weaknesses in the laws of this country, whether they be State or Federal laws, for the purpose of robbing the Australian people of due revenue. As a result, extra revenue has to be raised from the PAYE area and by way of indirect taxes. We expressed strong views about that a year or so ago.

The result of this breakdown in public morality is that revenue that should be available to be spent on the areas of social security, child care, education and funds to the States to carry out their proper responsibilities is reduced. Tax revenue has been lost as a result of the deficiencies of the Fraser Administration. On this occasion it is clear that it is not only the big but also the small taxpayers that this Government has indicted.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT INDUSTRY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 21 September, on motion, by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Senate take note of the statement and papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts of the meat inquiry are as follows: The Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry was set up on 12 September last year to investigate allegations of corruption arising from the discovery of horse and kangaroo meat in Australian beef exports. Among other things, Mr Justice Woodward was specifically asked to report on whether allegations were made to any Minister about malpractice in the meat export trade , and importantly-I quote from the terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whether such allegations were dealt with in a manner that was adequate and effective.

It is a fact that on 11 February 1980 Mr Bert Kelly, then the Liberal member of the House of Representatives for Wakefield and a former Minister, went to Melbourne and met Mr Nixon. Mr Kelly presented Mr Nixon with a report, commenced in 1978, on the problems of the dual inspection service for meat. It is a fact that Mr Kelly used that occasion to advise Mr Nixon of the widespread corruption and skulduggery in the meat industry. Allegations of bribes to meat inspectors, threats, blackmail and theft of meat were among the allegations passed on by Mr Kelly to the Minister. What did the Minister do, having been advised by a reputable witness as early as February 1980 that there was something rotten in the meat game? According to Mr Nixon, he discussed it with Dr Gee, the head of the Bureau of Animal Health in the Department of Primary Industry. The Bureau of Animal Health has responsibilty for supervision of the export inspection service . Dr Gee then discussed the matter with Mr Landos, the executive officer of the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems. Dr Gee apparently satisfied himself that there was no hard evidence of any malpractice and reported that back to Mr Nixon. Mr Nixon then let the matter rest.

The question arises whether the Minister's limited action was good enough. Was that an adequate and effective response to Mr Kelly's allegations? Clearly it was not. Not only with the benefit of hindsight but also clearly for an industry of that importance and on such a sensitive matter, the Minister having been given information by a reliable witness who was conducting an inquiry into the meat industry for a slightly different purpose, the Minister's response was not good enough. The conclusion of Mr Justice Woodward is that Mr Nixon was culpable . In paragraph 8.45 of his report he states:
I have carefully considered the Minister's role in this matter, having due regard to the responsibility attributable to senior departmental officers, the heavy workload which Ministers accept . . .
He concludes the paragraph by saying:
In spite of these considerations, I am bound to record my view that the Minister did not deal with these allegations adequately and effectively.
The judge goes on to say of Mr Nixon in paragraph 8.46:
He says that he can recall Mr Kelly saying that it was a pretty 'shonky' industry . . .
In paragraph 8.47 he says:
The possibilities of such action should have been fully investigated; instead it was assumed that nothing could usefully be done.

These questions, among others, leap out from those paragraphs: Why did Mr Nixon not investigate the matter further? He had an allegation of widespread corruption and blackmail from a responsible source. Why did he not investigate it fully? Why did he not himself press Mr Kelly for details of his allegations? Why did he not ask his departmental officers to follow them up? Why did he not press his departmental officers for full written details of the allegations and/ or ask Mr Kelly for written details of the allegations? He did none of those things. Mr Nixon merely made cursory inquiries and let the matter rest. Is it too much to ask that a Minister should have shown the will to get to the bottom of the matter, to satisfy himself fully that the allegations were without foundation? Mr Nixon did not.

The consequences of his sloppy and half-hearted administrative effort are that it was left to an inspector in the United States-the only circumstance which could be more embarrassing than that would be for someone in the Middle East to discover that pork was labelled as beef-to discover, to Australia's acute embarrassment, that a meat substitution racket was taking place. Because of that a billion dollar meat exporting industry has been placed in jeopardy. The damage that this negligence has caused will continue for many years. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) attempted to defend Mr Nixon on three dishonest, shameful grounds. The first of those techniques was that of selective quotation. The Prime Minister quoted the first sentence of paragraph 8.39, which states:
Insofar as allegations were reported by the Department to Mr Nixon, I do not consider any criticism can be levelled at his handling of them.

That says that the allegations were passed on to him by the Department. That does not refer to the allegations passed on to the Minister by Mr Kelly. The Prime Minister dishonestly presented that quotation in a context which purported to refer to Mr Kelly's allegations. The Prime Minister should have quoted the following sentence from the middle of paragraph 8.44:
Anyone who had previously assumed that by and large, Commonwealth meat inspection was functioning well, ought to have been jolted out of complacency by what the Kelly Committee had to say.
The Prime Minister did quote the following sentence from paragraph 8.48 concerning the Minister and his advisers:
They seem to have given all their attention to the central issue dealt with by the Committee.

That is the Kelly Committee. In other words, the Prime Minister was trying to show that Mr Nixon was dealing determinedly with other matters in hand. But the Prime Minister quoted only a portion of that paragraph. The whole paragraph reads as follows:

Thus neither the Minister nor his senior advisers took any substantial steps to look into the questions which had been raised by the Kelly Committee. They seem to have given all their attention to the central issue dealt with by the Committee-the question of a single inspection system-and hoped that any problems of corruption or abuse of power would right themselves in due course. In the event, of course, they did not.

The second leg of the Prime Minister's spurious defence of Mr Nixon was his attempt to set himself up as a better judge of the evidence than Mr Justice Woodward. The Royal Commissioner took 11 months to weigh the evidence and to form his view. The Prime Minister took a maximum of two days-a weekend-in between consulting a disinterested party, to it, Mr Anthony, the National Country Party leader, as well as Mr Nixon himself.

As a result of the Prime Minister's action, the standing reputation and basis of royal commissions are under threat. What judge will now risk serving on a royal commission, knowing not only that his findings will be peremptorily dismissed but also that his personal competence and/or integrity will be impugned? All this, from a Prime Minister who in 1975 used to talk piously about accepting the umpire's decision. Will the public believe the Prime Minister and his Country Party advisors or will it believe Mr Justice Woodward of the Federal Court?

The Prime Minister's action in declaring Mr Justice Woodward's judgment suspect has raised another matter. It will be remembered that for many years Mr Justice Woodward was the head of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Will the Prime Minister, having now discovered that Mr Justice Woodward's judgment is not only suspect but also wrong, order a review and the overturning of all security decisions made by ASIO while he was its head? If Mr Justice Woodward's judgment is so bad in this instance, is the Prime Minister suggesting that it was bad in other instances? If so, what does the Prime Minister intend to do about it?

The third leg of the Prime Minister's spurious defence of a worthless Minister was to attack Mr Kelly. One wonders whether there is any depth to which this Prime Minister will not sink. Is there nothing that he will not do to save the Country Party? The standards of this Government and of its performance are in total disarray. The standard now is one of casting around for a scapegoat. We have had the Royal Commissioner scapegoat, the Public Service scapegoat, the police scapegoat and now the Kelly scapegoat-anybody except the Minister who is responsible. The new ministerial standard is one of finding someone else to carry the can. The plain truth, shown again as before, is that the Prime Minister will not, for whatever reason, take disciplinary action against Country Party Ministers. I wonder for how long the members of the Liberal Party in this place, in the other House and outside, will tolerate that double standard. Decisions on the future of Ministers are made according to whether they would be good for the Cabinet, whether they would damage the Government politically, rather than on any standard of ministerial responsibility or integrity.

Also, the standards keep changing. Senator Withers, who I regret is not in the chamber, would be more conscious of that than anyone. On 15 August 1978, Mr Fraser said in the House of Representatives regarding the McGregor report and its consideration by senior Ministers:

We had no doubt that our first and foremost responsibility was the maintenance of the high standards of propriety set and maintained by this Government. We were of the view that we had no option but to accept Mr Justice McGregor's report and accepting it had inevitable consequences in respect of the finding of impropriety.

Of course, what that meant was that Senator Withers got the sack for making a telephone call. The final irony is that the urgers surrounding Mr Fraser and telling him to sack Senator Withers were senior National Country Party Ministers Nixon, Anthony and Sinclair. For how long will the Liberal Party tolerate those double standards?

On the subject of ministerial responsibility, in the last couple of weeks we have heard quoted, ad nauseam, what the Prime Minister said about that in 1972: That, of course, if a Minister was aware of maladministration in his Department and did nothing about it he should resign. But he said also that if there were a serious blunder in the department, even if the Minister were not aware of it, he should still resign. That was his view, in 1972, of ministerial responsibility. In 1982 Senator Durack said that a Minister should not resign unless he were personally responsible. That is a million miles from the Fraser view of ministerial responsibility as expressed a decade earlier, but even on the Durack test, Mr Nixon should go. He was personally responsible. He was told of blackmail, bribery and corruption in the meat inspection service. He did nothing , yet he stays. Time and again new standards are dreamed up and then blown away by the fierce wind of prime ministerial cynicism. The only constant for this Government is that the Country Party is never guilty. There is no standard or doctrine of ministerial responsibility beyond that. The Prime Minister said in his 1975 election speech:
What can be done immediately, and must be done, is to establish-for the first time in three years-sound and honest management of Australia's affairs.

If another Opposition leader were to repeat that today and to substitute 'seven' for 'three' it would be, to use a word much favoured by the Prime Minister, appropriate. I wonder whether this man, the Prime Minister, this now self- appointed judge of the evidence before the Woodward Royal Commission, realises what he is doing in a constitutional sense-in the sense in which that word is used to describe all the conventions and practices under which we operate? Do all the Liberal Party members of Parliament endorse what the Prime Minister has done? He has now set himself up to judge the evidence and findings of a royal commission on the basis of a weekend's reading, as one who takes an interested position in consultation with others who are an even more directly interested position. He puts himself above the assessment of a distinguished judge who took months to sift the evidence, having first heard of all of it, and who had no vested interest in the outcome. This is the Prime Minister, who, last year, proposed to the Premiers that Mr Justice Woodward should head an inquiry into industrial relations. He now attacks Mr Justice Woodward, as he attacked Mr Kelly. All this from the man who talks about propriety, whose lofty arrogance, he seems to imagine, marks him as a man of principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here is what Ellicott said about Woodward when he was appointed head of ASIO.
—I am indebted to Senator Tate for drawing to my attention what Mr Ellicott said about Mr Justice Woodward when he was appointed head of ASIO. Mr Ellicott said:

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously the personality of the person is tremendously important. The Government, as did the previous Government, has confidence in the capacity of Mr Justice Woodward to bring to bear in this organisation those attributes which are obviously necessary. They are not always attributes which are essential to the judicial function. This position requires a great deal of practical common sense and a good administrative capacity. These are gifts which His Honour has demonstrated he has in the experience that I think all of us have had with him.

As I said earlier, since by prime ministerial assertion it has now been decreed that the judgment of Mr Justice Woodward is not to be trusted, will the Prime Minister review all the security decisions taken by ASIO when Mr Justice Woodward was its head-security decisions which would have affected the careers of people and about which those people themselves were not even told? Are not the implications of that very serious? The Prime Minister asserts that the judgment of Mr Justice Woodward is suspect and wrong. If the Prime Minister is to be believed, there should be a reassessment, by someone who is competent, of all the security decisions made by ASIO while Mr Justice Woodward was its head. I would not like to hold my breath waiting for the Prime Minister to respond to that.

Judges, by convention, do not enter into public debate-for very good reason. But is this judge supposed to stand by mutely and take this prime ministerial denunciation of his findings-a denunciation, I repeat, based on a hasty weekend reading of the report by an interested party and in consultation with even more deeply interested parties? The judge may well decide to do so out of respect for his profession and the now sure knowledge that he will still be around when Malcolm Fraser has gone. Public servants were once expected to act almost anonymously through their Minister, and the Minister took responsibility. Do the new Fraser rules mean, for example, that the Crimes Act will have to be amended to let public servants disclose information which they need for their defence, or are we to expect a class of people to remain defenceless-an idea which is totally at variance with existing law and custom? If this is to go on we shall have to rethink our entire system of public administration. I understand that the Prime Minister's latest stunt, an inquiry into that matter, also fell rather flat on its face in the House of Representatives today.
In conclusion, there is only one alternative-to clear this Government out. It has run its course. The Liberal Party can then purge itself of this man and he can retire to brood on his sins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to discuss the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. I hope to concentrate almost totally on that report and on the propositions, recommendations and actions that have come out of it. I was interested to hear Senator Walsh talking of the role of the Royal Commission and in particular of the Royal Commissioner. As is normal in this chamber, Senator Walsh generally confined himself to personalities and not to the real issues. Surely the Royal Commissioner is capable, as is any human being, of making a mistake, of having evidence that is perhaps not entirely accurate put before him. Mistakes he may make may be related to that.

SPEECH.PARA: I presume that Senator Walsh makes the assumption that it is totally wrong to query any conclusion arrived at by the Royal Commission. That assumption is not entirely capable of substantiation. The great bulk of the Royal Commissioner's findings and recommendations to the Government have been put into place or are in the process of being put into place. The mere fact that in one or two cases a differing view from the judgment of the Royal Commissioner is taken is not extraordinary-far from it. It might well be a perfectly normal reaction to a proper measure of vigilance over the reports on an important industry such as the Australian meat industry, or indeed of any other industry.

The Royal Commission, the report of which the Senate is discussing this afternoon, arose on about 13 August 1981. It was appointed as a result of the revelation in America of adulterated meat or, more accurately, I believe, horse meat found in that country having been imported from Australia apparently as boneless beef. There is no doubt at all in the mind of the Government or in the mind of the Australian population that the investigations of this Royal Commission and the great mass of its conclusions and recommendations make a very valuable contribution to correcting the faults that have developed over many years. Many of those faults developed purely as a result of human weakness, I suppose. Often those sorts of faults are not revealed until a chance incident occurs. These has been some concern-I put it at least as high as that-about the royal commissioner's handling of the report of the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems and, more particularly in that case, of the references and reflections that are made on the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon.

In this sort of discussion where we are taken into the field of personalities, be they inside the Parliament or outside, there is always some measure of emotionalism. I suggest to the chamber that, irrespective of whether a Minister for primary industry is a member of this Government or a member of an ALP government, it is almost crazy to imagine that he would have any involvement with anything that would be significantly damaging to an industry in Australia such as the meat industry. The meat industry, which was the subject of this inquiry, represented in Australia a total production value in 1981 of something like $3.2 billion. It has an export earning capacity of no less than $1.3 billion, a capacity earned by finding markets, very often with significant difficulty, in no fewer than 60 nations around the world. To imagine that that sort of circumstances, that sort of industry, could be threatened with the full knowledge and cognisance of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) is almost a crazy assumption.

This industry not only represents those statistical matters in the Australian context but, more particularly, it also involves itself with a large range of employment, from the basic livestock producer, through to the transport industry , the abattoirs, the processing works, and ultimately the transport of the exported commodity to other countries. Likewise, the industry, through its research and breeding capacity-it is a famous industry in both those fields-is of great significance to Australia's trade relationships and her contribution to the economies of many countries around the world, in particular, the countries to our immediate north. The Minister himself, in this circumstance, has a deep- seated background in the very industry under discussion. I mention these matters to highlight the fact that it appears to be a ridiculous assumption that a responsible Minister in this country could in any way involve himself in circumstances which would denigrate the capacity of an industry such as this.

The history of this Royal Commission-I look at it only briefly-began as a result of the horse meat incident of August 1981 in the United States of America . I want to recall that the reaction to that circumstance was immediate, quite dramatic and absolutely effective. So it needed to be. The product itself, in Australia and in America, was impounded and the works that were involved were closed down. We can all well recall the public outcry that followed the revelation of sales of horse meat instead of beef in the United States of America, bearing an Australian brand. It was an outcry which began in the livestock industry itself, in the producer field, but which spread, I believe, to every Australian. It was likely that that would be the case because our reputation as Australians was at stake. We in this country need to develop, probably more than anything else at this time, a significant pride. The circumstances that surrounded the outbreak of this problem were indeed seen as a reflection on the reputation and the pride of every Australian.

As a result of continuing the rapid action taken by the Minister and the Government on that occasion, there was established the Royal Commission whose report we now discuss. That Commission was established and in place within one month of the actual occurrence in America. The Royal Commission headed by Mr Justice Woodward was appointed on 12 September 1981. Its area of investigation included the administrative arrangements of the export meat industry and an investigation of malpractices, of allegations over 10 years, and whether those allegations were properly dealt with, and any illegality or corruption that may have been found in response to those allegations. The report of that Commission was brought down on the 17th of this month.

After substitution had been revealed, the Commissioner commended the Department and the Minister on the efforts to which I have just referred; his further suggestions and recommendation were already in train. Many of his recommendations had been implemented and most of the others were under close consideration and probably close to implementation. Substitution naturally relates to inspection, and that is where in this chamber, in our discussion, and where the Royal Commissioner himself came basically in contact with the Kelly Committee, whose investigations were concerned with the matter of meat inspection. That is one of the great problems that relate ultimately to the substitution circumstance, because inspection in this country has to this point been a dual inspection system which has been very costly and very cumbersome, and from many points of view totally unacceptable.

Yet there is an absolute case for the Federal control of export standards and export licences. Similarly, the States, with their concern for their own sovereignty, to this point at least, have insisted on being involved in the inspection of meat. It is to be hoped that in the not-too-distant future a solution will be found to this very great problem, because there is no shadow of doubt that the quality requirements of our competitors around the world, not only in primary industry but also in secondary industry, are extremely high. Australia must meet-I believe that it will meet and is meeting-the challenge of those standards. Only by meeting that challenge will we successfully compete in an ever more competitive world.

It was in November 1978 that the Minister for Primary Industry appointed the Kelly Committee to look into the problem of meat inspection and to come up with a strong recommendation for its solution. Mr Kelly exhibited a very great determination to come to a conclusion and finally came down with his recommendation for an Australian meat inspection service, which was to be a single service which would overcome and replace the dual service under which we had laboured for so many years. I want to make it abundantly clear that when that recommendation was brought down by the Kelly Committee in February 1980, the Minister concerned, Mr Nixon, took then, as he has taken since, every possible means of establishing the recommendations of that Committee. I believe that about seven or eight meetings of the Australian Agricultural Council have occurred since that time and the question of establishing an Australian meat inspection service has been in the forefront of consideration. Of course, the ultimate implementation of such a system needs the total and absolute co- operation of all the States, and that is where the problem lies basically at present.

I refer to the comments of Mr Kelly in the passage of his report where he referred to 'bribery and corruption' and to 'minor skulduggery'. He reiterated that the Australian Meat Inspection Service was the ultimate objective and the main area of his inquiry. He believed that these other matters were on the periphery of his investigation. When pushed for evidence he repeatedly advised the Minister, as did other men who were involved with the inquiry, that there was no specific or hard evidence. There was nothing of a specific nature available from Mr Kelly or any other member of his Committee that would warrant the establishment and continuance of police investigation.

Basically this is the answer to the constant suggestion that the Minister for Primary Industry failed to respond. He certainly did respond. he sought that the Director of the Bureau of Animal Health, Mr Gee, follow up these suggestions, these allegations, vague though they may be and although they were described as not being capable of being put together as hard evidence. In spite of those things the Minister had his Director follow those suggestions and propositions as far as it was humanly possible to do. Mr Gee came back to the Minister several times and on every occasion he confirmed that in his view there was no way in which the matter could be followed through to a prosecution or even to further successful investigation. There were no names, no addresses; there were no hard facts on which an investigation could continue.

As I said earlier in the day, Mr Kelly's main thrust was the meat inspection problem. The Kelly report was not a confidential document. it was around for 18 months without even a question being asked. The Royal Commissioner said that if, in April 1982, he had been reporting his findings-he would have reported that there were no problems in the meat industry. That is an extraordinary thing to say and it reflects on the whole problem that confronted the Minister and the industry. A further three months of intense investigation was needed to uncover some meat inspectors and even some police who were involved in the problems. There were no cases of species substitution of meat before late 1979. There is no mention of meat substitution in the whole of the Kelly report and no evidence of Mr Kelly raising these matters with the Minister. As I read the report the only matters that were raised with the Minister were matters referring to perks, cheap meat and this type of circumstance which, of course, has been acted upon severely and against which all sorts of controls were written into the rules and regulations.

I think that in fairness we should remind ourselves of what the Minister did in the face of the revelation and concern that occurred in August 1981. As I mentioned earlier, he deregistered a whole range of establishments. He instituted forthwith spot checks in all States of the Commonwealth. He increased security and surveillance in the whole meat industry. Within a matter of days a new system of security seals was in place. Within days a task force to co- ordinate the wide sampling and species testing of meat was also in place. Police investigations were intensified. All these things happened within a matter of days of the revelation of the circumstances that surfaced in America in August 1981. Penalties were increased to a very significant level-up to $100,000 or five years gaol or both-for the illegal export of meat. There were new security controls in cold stores, transport and containers. An outside consultant was appointed to review the whole meat industry situation. A special meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council was held on 4 September 1981.

The quick result of all this activity can be seen in the fact that no less than 24,000 tonnes of American beef were released to the American market on 4 September, some three weeks after the original finding of meat substitution on the American mainland. Some $40m worth of meat was released into the American market. That is evidence of the effectiveness and strictness and speed of the action taken by the Government, the Minister and his Department in the face of the revelations to which I have referred.

I will refer for one moment to the Export Control Act 1982 because it is relevant to the discussion this afternoon. That Act was brought down in March 1982. It established strong, decentralised control and management. It sought stronger compliance and investigations by the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. It seeks to raise the calibre of the inspection staff. These are matters that finally have to be agreed to by unions and State governments as well as the meat industry. They are matters that clearly will increase the effectiveness of control over his important export industry.

The Commissioner said: 'I have no doubt that the industry has never been more free of malpractice than it is today.' Further, he said that 'in consequence of the strong reaction of the Minister and the Department, and the establishment of the Royal Commission itself, the current level of malpractice is lower than it has ever been.'

Lest we become too emotionally concerned it is also worth while to remember that in the American meat industry the average rate of rejection is 0.5 of one per cent. Over recent years the amount rejected from New Zealand has been 0.3 of one per cent, from Australia 0.2 of one per cent and from Canada 0.8 of one per cent. I am not suggesting that we should not become better-of course we should; but on those grounds over recent years Australian meat compares more than favourably with other meat imported into the United States. I refer again to some of the words of the Commissioner. He said:
There is no evidence to suggest there was any illegality or corruption by any Minister or official in response to any allegation of malpractice in the meat industry.
Finally, he said:
Generally Ministers have been adequate and effective and the Department has acted well under the Minister's instructions.

I hope I am building up a proper case that suggests that the Minister, with the knowledge that he had-that is all anyone can move on-acted responsibly, that the Department and the Australian Government reacted to a great problem with speed and efficiency and with effect.

I now refer to the meeting on 11 February 1980, referred to on many pieces of paper, between the Minister and Mr Kelly and his committee when Mr Kelly presented his report to the Minister, a report which was tabled on 27 February that year. A number of confusions have become widespread about that meeting. In the first place, it was a meeting specifically to present to Mr Nixon the report on meat inspection and the recommendations of Mr Kelly. Clearly, in such a circumstance that would have been the predominant area of discussion. As the time of that meeting has been stated and confirmed to have been about 20 minutes , it is unlikely that a great deal of time could have been spent on other allegations. There were suggestions-no more than suggestions-of malpractice in a number of peripheral areas. Mr Kelly described them in a number of ways, none of them seriously, mostly in his inimitable whimsical manner. Although they were proven to be at that time incapable of being developed into hard evidence or into circumstances that could be followed up with any real hope of success, the Minister charged the Director of the Bureau of Animal Health to follow those suggestions, those implications, and to see whether indeed any form of real useful evidence could be established that might develop into a proper base for prosecution.

I close my remarks by saying that the meat industry incident and its solution have proven the need for absolute vigilance in this great industry. Our capacity for that vigilance has been assisted by the report of this Royal Commission. It has equally been identified that the Minister involved sought to do his job, as indeed it should be done, with speed, with accuracy and in a comprehensive way. The result has been the rehabilitation, if one likes, of an industry that was at least momentarily severely threatened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are discussing the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. The vast bulk of this report deals with the range of allegations that have been made in recent times in relation to practices within the industry. Although very little has been mentioned of these malpractices, it is worth remembering that they are the essential feature of the report. I will detail the types of problems that were in the industry and which were raised in the report. They were species substitution; local connivance in overseas malpractices; substitution of local for export meat; false descriptions of age, quality and cut; misuse of Government stamps; false statements of slaughter dates; forgery of transfer certificates; failure to obtain export documents; forgery of export documents; corruption of Government officials; pet food in smallgoods; illegal knackery operations; breaches of knackery operations; failure to dye meat and deliberate mis-descriptions.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the tally of problems that were detailed in this report. On any description, I think that list is certainly one that must give any government in charge of the various government instrumentalities concerned with the meat industry pause. I do not believe that it can be shrugged off as lightly as the Government has done. Later in my speech I will come to the matters involved with Government and ministerial responsibility. But I wish to concentrate briefly on those aspects of malpractice which I have just detailed. They are indeed a list of problems that have threatened the existence of a billion-dollar industry. It is not possible to suggest that those practices occurred and at the same time to suggest that no one should take responsibility.

What is undisputed in the report-Senator Scott reaffirmed this-is that the report has some trenchant criticisms of the Department of Primary Industry and of the Australian Federal Police. It is not only Mr Nixon who is concerned in this matter but also Mr Newman. If one took the bulk of the report to weigh up which of those two bodies received the most trenchant criticism, it would certainly not have been the Department of Primary Industry, but rather the Australian Federal Police, which falls under the portfolio of the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman. Although many of these allegations were referred to the Australian Federal Police at no stage did the police undertake diligent investigation. Indeed, Mr Justice Woodward said that very little attention was paid at the various stages to the allegations referred to them. At one stage he allowed them to be let off the hook on the basis that the Department may not have pressed one set of allegations in an urgent manner. I suspect that in that case the onus falls back on the Department. But on balance I think that the Australian Federal Police must take a large amount of the responsibility for what resulted from not investigating the allegations that had been made.

Unlike Senator Scott, I think that one cannot be too sanguine about the activities of the Department of Primary Industry even after the allegations were referred to it and after they became public. The Department, in its final submission, refers to itself and its activities as proving to be inefficient, costly, poorly managed, overstaffed and in many respects corrupt. At that point Mr Justice Woodward said that he could not but concur. Surely within the report we do have a listing of gross maladministration, gross practices, corruption, forgery and a range of other activities that are serious and would be serious in any industry. They are serious in this industry because of the delicate nature of the United States market, which is our major source of exports. I think that in this case one must pause and seriously consider such a report being handed down by a royal commissioner.

I do not believe that it is possible to say of a royal commission report that anything in it is necessarily true. Such an assertion, I believe, is absurd. One must take a royal commission report in the way that one takes other detailed inquiries, even of the most eminent kind. One must take the evidence that they present, the cogency of their arguments, the marshalling of their facts and the connection of their conclusions to their premises. But I think if one reads Mr Justice Woodward's report into the Australian meat industry, in as unbiased a light as one can manage, one must be struck by the fact that in this report there is considerable attention to detail and that a considerable attempt is made by the Royal Commissioner to link the evidence in a reasonable way to his conclusions and to his recommendations. Indeed, unlike the Costigan Royal Commission on the Acitivites of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, Mr Justice Woodward allows himself only one brief moment of levity, when he refers to the trembling inspectors who may 'find fault with the work of a large and perhaps excitable slaughter man with a knife in his hand'.

The report maintains a thorough and, I believe, consistent and logical argument from start to finish. I think it is on that basis and on the basis that the Royal Commissioner presumably is acting under his charter in a manner in which he has been directed, that one cannot brush aside the comments that he makes about ministerial responsibility. Of course, one would expect a government as beleaguered as this Government to approach this particular report in a much more political way than it has approached other royal commission reports in calmer times. I think the example has been oft quoted of the way in which Senator Withers was treated in the royal commission report that brought down the findings of some impropriety on his part. Surely the reasons for the Government' s differing approach on this occasion lies in the sensitivity of the Government at this time. That is not to be wondered at and it should be taken into account when considering its response to this royal commission report.

I think it is very difficult for anybody who wishes to stand outside the mud- slinging that has gone on to weigh up in an impartial way what the Royal Commissioner has said about ministerial responsibility and what the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has said about ministerial responsibility. I think we must take it that the Prime Minister is seeking to defend one of his senior Ministers at this particular time for reasons other than those raised in this report. I do not think anybody in Australia would be surprised that that is the case. However, I think it goes beyond that when the Prime Minister seeks to call into doubt the points that the Royal Commissioner has made in this regard. I do not see them as an essential item in this report but I do see them as an important item in the report.

I refer to the point that Senator Scott discussed at some length, that is, the report of the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems. In fact, in the first speech that I made in this place in relation to meat last year, I discussed at some length the Kelly report. It is not true, as the Prime Minister has said, that to the best of his knowledge no attention had been paid to the Kelly report. That is not correct. I will, however, accede to the fact that the Kelly report was about meat inspection. Mr Kelly, in his comments since the report was put down has said in his own defence that he is a single minded person and that, indeed, what he was about at the time was to look at meat inspection. However, there are a number of comments that must be made in this regard. Mr Kelly, at the time he met the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) made comments other than those that went into the diary. He made comments to other people, some of them in this chamber, about the problems that he had uncovered. I quote a section in the report taken from a minute sent to the Acting Secretary of the Department. It is a record of the meeting between Mr Kelly and the Minister. The section states:

The Committee in meeting the Minister last week expressed strong views as to the 'sordid' nature of the meat industry and meat inspection. Particular reference was made to examples of graft and the misuse of inspector power, both by DPI and State inspection staff and to the poor reputation that the DPI service has in too many quarters of the industry.

It has subsequently been stated that there was not sufficient evidence available in hard form to do anything with these allegations. I suggest that these allegations are of a very serious nature in an extremely important industry and that the Minister did have an obligation to follow them up. It is not sufficient to say that the Committee did not have hard evidence. The seriousness of these allegations should surely have prompted the Minister to go to Mr Newman and seek the support of the Australian Federal Police for a thorough investigation of matters at that time to see whether hard evidence could be uncovered. Surely that is the nub of the Minister's job. It is said that hard evidence was not uncovered by a committee which was looking at something completely different. But it had turned up, as part of its investigation, some serious allegations. One would not have expected the Committee to have that hard evidence. But one would certainly have expected the Minister to put in train a thorough investigation of the matter by the Federal Police. That investigation did not take place. There is no evidence of a thorough investigation by senior departmental officials of the Department of Primary Industry into those allegations. I say again that those allegations are of a serious nature. As Senator Scott has already stated, the inspection system is at the heart of our export trade. Allegations made about corruption within the inspection system must have given pause to anybody. This could have extended further.

It seems to me too, judging from the evidence obtained by Mr Kelly, in his investigation, that it is unlikely that an investigation as thorough as the one conducted by Mr Kelly, which even Senator Scott praised, would not have turned up some quite considerable problems in the inspection system, ones which surely ought to have been followed up at that time. What we have to examine in relation to this and other problems the Government has raised is ministerial responsibility. The Government's doctrine eventually must be seen to be one under which a responsible Minister in no way can be held responsible. That, I suggest, is an absurd doctrine-a doctrine which will not serve this country well in the future.

The Australian Democrats do not believe that the Westminster system of ministerial responsibility can be called a fair system. One is not interested in whether ministerial responsibility is fair or otherwise. What we are talking about is that somebody finally has to accept responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —The buck has to stop somewhere.
—I agree that the buck has to stop somewhere, and that is not necessarily a fair thing. I think the Prime Minister spelt it out in very clear terms in a statement in 1972, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: They ought to be aware of all major matters and, therefore can be clearly and directly responsible for them.
But if a major blunder occurred in a department of real importance to Australia and if the Minister were unaware of it, that Minister should accept responsibility . . .

That seems to me to spell out what most people at that time believed we were talking about in terms of ministerial responsibility. It is not good enough for the Government to say 'Well look, he did not know', or 'He did know', or 'He tried to do this', or 'He tried to do that'. The arguments are not about individual failings or otherwise. Indeed, the new doctrine put down by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that a person should resign only if there have been individual failings is the one exception made in the Westminster system, when this consideration is not brought into play. The Westminster system does not refer to a personal failing. A personal failing suggests that a Minister should resign, not on a point of ministerial responsibility but because he is no longer a fit person to be a Minister. That is the doctrine which is alive in Britain and which is probably in most people's minds best associated with Mr Profumo, a British Minister for War. His was a personal failing and that made him unfit to be a Minister. The doctrine of ministerial responsibility did not apply in that case. As I said, this is a hard and harsh doctrine.

I suggest that if the new doctrine of ministerial responsibility that is being propounded were to be the one which became general in this country, particularly in private enterprise, the problems we would have in industry and commerce would be magnified alarmingly. Indeed, even within the law we do not recognise such a doctrine. Within the law we visit upon directors of companies responsibility for actions. They cannot rise in court and claim that they knew nothing about a certain activity, particularly if that were an activity of which, under their directorship, they ought to have been aware. The fact that they were not aware of it is not a claim to innocence. At some point we must re-establish the very harsh doctrine under which somebody eventually has to take the responsibility for what goes on.

We are not talking about the personal propriety of the individual Minister or whether he has been a fair, reasonable or honest person. These considerations are entirely beside the point. Rather, we are suggesting that somebody must finally accept responsibility for the problems that arise. If that is not the case we have finally reached the stage in this country where nobody accepts responsibility for what goes on. If that is so, the Government has established a doctrine which will be used in future not only by political parties in government, but also by other political parties when they are in government. It will be a system of buck passing, of duck shoving and of evasion of responsibility. It will also, of course, lead to what we have seen appearing on the scene, namely, bureaucratic scapegoating.

I thought a Public Service union official made a rather apt comment in relation to this. He said that a wink is as good as a nod. In other words, he was saying that if a Minister is not going to be tramping around with heavy boots, why should a public servant stick his neck out? I think that we will see this sort of flow on. If the new doctrine of not knowing something is going to be used by the Minister, presumably it can be used by his departmental head and every officer under him. The idea now is to know as little as possible because then one cannot be held accountable. That is not good practice in a bureaucracy. It is not good practice in private enterprise. In fact, such a practice is not acceptable under the law for the group in our society that the Government keeps talking about supporting. In fact, the Government has set in place a series of laws which affects private enterprise and which it now says does not apply to it and its dealings with its own bureaucracy.

I think the two matters concerning the gross inefficiency which has been turned up within the Department and within various Government instrumentalities in relation to the meat industry give us some unease when we hear a variety of other allegations floating around. Allegations have been made, for example, concerning the fishing section of the Department of Primary Industry. I am sure that is not the only allegation of which honourable senators have heard. There are allegations in relation to a number of primary products that presumably at some stage in the future will come to light. If this does happen I am afraid that there will have been set up a precedent for inactivity by this Government and by future governments of any political persuasion. That cannot be good for Government or for the country.

Senator Scott made the point that it would be a ridiculous assumption to suggest that the Minister for Primary Industry would want to harm the industry. I agree totally-it would be a ridiculous assumption. I think we can give the benefit of the doubt to all the Ministers in this Government-and accept that they would wish to act in such a way as to do the best they could for this country. I think that is a reasonable assumption to make, and I am quite happy to make it. But quite frankly, I do not see what that has to do with this matter . Nowhere in the report is the suggestion made that the Minister would want to harm the industry or harm this country. I certainly would not want to make such an allegation. What we are talking about is a totally different matter. We are talking about whether the Minister is the person finally responsible for what went on. If he was-and I believe that by his own actions in offering his resignation to the Prime Minister he showed that he was-it would have been in the best interests not only of this Government but also of future governments for that resignation to have been accepted. In that way we would re-establish that very harsh doctrine that the Minister accepts final responsibility for major problems that occur within the administration of his portfolio. Only then will we have confidence that the Minister and his officer will diligently pursue matters within his own department and seek to ferret out all that he can concerning major items within his portfolio.

If we allow the new doctrine to remain in place we will have the worst of all possible worlds. We will have the situation in which a Minister who is assumed to be responsible will not accept responsibility. We will have in place a doctrine which says that if a Minister does not go ferreting around his department he cannot be held responsible for what he does not know. We will have departmental officials using identical justification for their inactivity for supervising their part of the department. We will have, in fact, a continual negation of what I believe has been an essential part of the way our government operates. We have a range of drawbacks within our system in which the Executive resides within the Parliament. We must make sure that we do not give away any of the conventions that have been established around the Executive that resides within a parliament-those types of conventions which indeed are essential to and necessary for the continuing function of good government.

I believe that this report of the Woodward Royal Commission has served a useful purpose. I admit, as other honourable senators have said, that the vast bulk of what the Royal Commissioner said in his report was known before the report was presented to this Parliament. However, I do believe that the Royal Commissioner has done a service to the Parliament of this country by raising in a very clear way the problem of ministerial responsibility-as the end and ultimate goal of what goes on. If that alone is maintained and if that debate can be maintained, I hope that some time in the near future we will be able to re-establish a convention which is acceptable to all sides of this Parliament, a convention which embodies what we believe is necessary from our Ministers and others who hold high office. I, for one, do not believe that that is a task which will be simple. Neither is the task of a Minister simple. It is probably one of the most onerous tasks in this country and one which is rarely accepted in the community as such. Along with that high office goes an awesome responsibility. That responsibility has to be accepted when an issue such as is the subject of this Royal Commission report occurs again in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been looking forward to the report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry for some time. I have been looking forward to considering whatever its findings were. Therefore, I should like to do just that this afternoon. I would not want to divert from my intention on the basis of what Senator Macklin had to say, except to say to Senator Macklin that if he wants to get some good information on the subject of ministerial responsibility and how it should operate in our system, he should refer to some debates on the issue where current political mileage was not to be made. There are a number of good such debates. There have been some well thought out submissions to this Senate and debates in the Senate on the subject. But I have to say that the debate that has taken place on the subject of ministerial responsibility in relation to the report on this Royal Commission is one of the least enlightened debates to which the Senate has been treated.

SPEECH.PARA: On 21 August last year, very shortly after the meat scandal had surfaced, I raised the issue in Question Time with the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in this place, Senator Chaney. In my question I asked:

. . . in view of the importance of the United States market to Australian beef producers, particularly producers in Queensland who are overwhelmingly dependent on the United States export trade, and in view of the potentially disastrous consequences for meat producers, processors, exporters and industry employees, there must be no room for doubt in future as to the thoroughness of investigations. All involved must be prosecuted and must face the consequences of this sabotage of our beef industry. In short, not only must justice be done but it also must be seen to be done. Therefore, would the Minister agree to propose to the Government that a judicial inquiry be instituted so that all allegations and information can be publicly presented and no doubts can be cast in the future as to the integrity of Australia's meat industry as a whole?

A couple of weeks after that the Government announced its intention to appoint a royal commission into the meat industry. That was a matter of considerable satisfaction to everyone involved in, and who cares about, the Australian meat industry. The issues posed back in August 1981 are as current as ever they were.

We now have the report of the Royal Commission, the so-called Woodward report. I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to some of the content of the report as it relates to the meat industry. There has been much pother about some small sections of the report relating to procedures of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and the Department of Primary Industry. My concern in this case is the beef industry. I am particularly concerned that because there is a current political issue, the actual report, and the recommendations and findings of the report, will be overlooked. The urgency of the Government attending to the matters raised by this Royal Commission are as real as they were back in August 1981 when there was a fear that we would lose the United States of America market. That fear should be just as alive today and every effort should be given to attention to matters raised by the Royal Commission and to action to make sure that our meat industry can be removed beyond the taint of the scandal that has hung over it for so long.

I particularly want to draw to the Senate's attention two sections of the report. One section relates to the problems of investigating allegations of malpractices and comments that the Royal Commissioner makes on that. The other relates to findings concerning malpractices. The Royal Commission was given terms which concerned past malpractices and allegations of malpractice as well as current ones. The report stated:

. . . obtaining material as to past malpractices proved to be a more difficult matter. Initially, both government instrumentalities and industry had been much shaken by the substitution scandal. However, by the time the Royal Commission commenced hearing evidence, there seemed to be a general satisfaction that the new administrative arrangements--
That is, arrangements announced by the Minister after the scandal had broken--

were fully adequate to prevent a repetition of that scandal, that the USDA had been appeased by the introduction of the new security measures, and thus the export industry was free from any immediate threat. There was concern that nothing further should occur to 'rock the export boat'.

That underlines my concern in that whilst the Government certainly took worthwhile steps at the time in order to secure its United States market I urge the Government not to carry out that feeling that was indicated by Woodward as might have been abroad at the time he commenced his hearings. There is need for further action. The report continues:

There was thus little general enthusiasm for any detailed public investigation by a Royal Commission of past malpractices, either in the area of species substitution or elsewhere, because of the publicity that would inevitably ensue.

Lack of official interest in meat industry malpractices was not new. In the decade before the substitution scandal, a total of seven persons had been successfully prosecuted under various Commonwealth Acts for offences relating to export meat handling. Only one successful prosecution had been brought under the Exports (Meat) Regulations. In January 1981, the Bureau of Animal Health . . . the branch of the DPI then responsible for meat inspection, sought information and assistance from regional directors to aid a review of those Regulations, because of the considerable difficulties said to be experienced in proceeding with prosecutions. However, with one exception, the responses to this request revealed little enthusiasm for any such review.

The files of the Australian Federal Police . . . revealed a handful of police investigations conducted over the previous decade, most of them being unproductive. There had been no concerted effort by BAH and the police to detect and prosecute offenders. Indeed, the difficulties of prosecution inherent in the then-existing regulations, and the trivial penalties prescribed for offences,-
I interpolate that those penalties have since changed-
provided little incentive for any such effort.

Nor did the files of the BAH reveal any systematic attempt to collect or disseminate information about malpractices, either in Canberra or at regional level. When the setting up of the Royal Commission was announced, steps were taken by DPI to secure the files of the BAH and to search them to provide information for the Royal Commission. To that end a Royal Commission Information Centre . . . was established.

The labours of the RCIC over several months produced a bundle of 164 files relating to allegations of malpractice. In no sense did these files represent a comprehensive body of information previously available to BAH in the area of malpractices. They were specially constructed files, consisting of copies of documents gleaned from an examination of some 30,000 DPI files in Canberra and regional offices and of 'off file' material. This process was necessary because it was apparent that no comprehensive system of recording allegations of malpractice as such existed either in Canberra or in the regions. I had occasion to comment on the BAH files in giving my ruling on certain allegations that documents had been improperly destroyed at the time the Royal Commission was announced. (I found there was no substance in the allegations).

That underlines complaints and allegations made at the time of the announcement of the Royal Commission that those who should have cared about allegations of malpractice had in fact not put any strenuous effort into those previous allegations. It justifies the claims made by those who had long since expressed concern, firstly, at an apparent lack of interest by at least a good number of those who should have had a responsibility in this area and cared about the effect that substantiated allegations of malpractice might have had on the Australian beef industry. In the second instance it shows just what a muddle things were in, and that muddle was one of the criticisms being made at the time of the announcement of the Royal Commission. The report continues:

Despite the painstaking efforts of the RCIC staff to produce an intelligible collection of files for the assistance of the Royal Commission, the result was disappointing. Often there were obvious gaps in the sequence of events recorded in the documents on the file. Some files lacked either a clear starting point or a conclusion. Some lacked both. In many cases it was impossible to ascertain what action, if any, had brought the matter to finality. Nonetheless, these files did provide a useful starting point for a number of significant investigations conducted before the Royal Commission. It should be recorded that the RCIC was in no way to blame for any defects in the material provided.

Official indifference to, or ignorance of, the true state of affairs in the industry was reflected in some of the evidence given in the early stages of the Royal Commission. The Director of the BAH testified that he had heard rumours of local meat going for export, but never one that could be substantiated. He knew of no occurrence, and had not heard persistent rumours, of the substitution of mutton for lamb. He had heard no persistent rumours of the substitution of cow- beef for ox, nor of the use of pet food in smallgoods, nor of the substitution of local offal for export offal. The Chairman of AMLC testified that he had never heard of the relidding of cartons for any underhand purposes in his 44 years in the industry. The Australian Meat Exporters Council stated that 'the Council is not aware of any previous incidence of malpractice in the preparation and marketing of export meat', and the Executive Director testified that the question of blatant malpractice had never been raised at a Council meeting in his 19 years in office.

With the assistance of the Royal Commission's report one could draw some unfavourable conclusions about the interest and activity that some people had been taking in their own industry in previous years. It is only to be hoped that that will change. I emphasise that I am not interested in a witchhunt against public servants or other individuals as to whether they might or might not have done things. I am concerned only that because the situation has been tightened up in the last 12 months these people will feel that the storm has blown over and things are okay. Mr Justice Woodward continued:

As to the meat inspection service, the provision of free or discounted meat had been seen as a problem from time to time, and some desultory but unsuccessful efforts to control the practice had been attempted. The notion that illegal benefits were being obtained by meat inspectors on any large scale, whether by cash payments or claims for excessive overtime or otherwise, was apparently regarded as so unlikely as not to require any mention.

It was against this stance by government and industry officials of real or professed ignorance of malpractices that the legal staff commenced to search for evidence of past misdeeds in the industry. That search was to reveal a serious situation that should have been known to, or at least suspected by, the officials concerned.

I emphasise that there is a significant statement in paragraph 2.28 of the Royal Commission report and I hope that in things that follow from the report that paragraph will be referred to frequently. The fact that the Royal Commission, through its search, was able to reveal a serious situation that should have been known, might be in part-I am sure it is-an indication that the Royal Commission had tools available to it that enabled it to bring together a number of things that may not have been brought together in the normal course of events. However, the fact that the Royal Commission was able to unearth so much because it had undertaken a serious inquiry might also indicate that if somebody else had undertaken a serious inquiry he might have been able to unearth something of substance. The report continues:

Direct evidence of past malpractices was slow to emerge. As the Hon. C. R. Kelly had found in conducting a previous inquiry, industry managers professed to be 'proud of the fact that their behaviour was above reproach, but they all cast grave aspersions on the behaviour of their competitors'. However, when pressed for specific information about their competitiors' activities, these managers showed a general reluctance to identify individuals or to provide specific information for the use of the Commission. This approach was consistent with previous industry practice. Eventually it was revealed that there had been widespread malpractices in the industry, and that this was well known, but the industry had usually preferred to remain silent. Only rarely had industry leaders reported known or suspected malpractices, and then only when the activities of some competitors were seen as being so outrageous as to constitute a serious threat to the whole industry.
Apparently outrageous behaviour of the kind that was revealed and led to the royal commission was not new, at least in kind. The report continues:

To this general attitude of reluctance to assist the Commission, there were a few notable exceptions. These were persons who believed that the long-term interests of producers and of law-abiding processors in the industry would be better served by frank disclosure than by secrecy. These persons provided valuable starting points for investigations by the Royal Commission, and it is to their credit that they did so.

All I can say, in view of the attitude outlined by the Royal Commission's report of other people associated with the industry, is thank heavens there were those few people who were able to help the Royal Commission start a useful inquiry. Those paragraphs I think indicate very clearly that there was a serious problem.
