Indications are in the report that as a result of the scandal and the appointment of the Royal Commission, as well as government action subsequent to that in the export meat industry, it is unlikely that such malpractices are as widespread at present. However, when we can settle down and consider the merits of the report, we must make sure that we put all our efforts into ensuring that this cannot happen again. If the Australian meat industry were to face another major scandal, even if only in the distant future, the compounding effect following this scandal would be diabolical. I would like now to outline some of the findings on malpractices in the Australian meat industry as they point up areas that demand action by government and probably industry also. The fact that so many in the industry were able to be so casual about it in the past, that so many knew of malpractice but were unable, or unwilling, in at least some cases to provide any substantial information indicates a sickness in the industry which must be rigorously resisted by all concerned in the future. In his findings on malpractices, Mr Justice Woodward said:
The main question which the Royal Commission has been asked to answer is how widespread have malpractices been in the meat industry in recent years.

Unfortunately there can be little comfort for the industry or the community in that answer. It is clear that malpractices in the nature of commercial cheating have been widespread in the export industry.
That lays to rest the pious hope expressed 12 months ago that the people who had been caught out at that time were isolated operators. The report states further:

Certainly there will need to be a change of attitude amongst export meat processors generally, and a much firmer line taken by government regulatory bodies, if Australian meat is to attain the high international reputation which it ought to enjoy.

So far as meat for human consumption in Victoria and the Northern Territory is concerned, there is little to suggest that consumers have been cheated when buying fresh meat from their local butcher or supermarket.

On the other hand it is clear that purchasers of some meat products have not always been eating the meat they expected and have sometimes been eating an unwholesome product. There has been, particularly in the last few years, quite a large quantity of pet meat which has found its way into such products in Victoria and been consumed throughout Australia. I am speaking here of hundreds of tonnes of kangaroo, buffalo, donkey and horse-meat which was not killed or processed in the manner prescribed for human consumption, but which nevertheless found its way into the human food chain.

I suspect that it was the successful infiltration of pet meat into the human food chain in Victoria which gave several unscrupulous people the idea that the same thing might be done on a large and very profitable scale in the export trade. I believe that this has been a comparatively recent development, that only a handful of operators have attempted it, and that the amounts involved have not been very large-amounting in total, perhaps, to several hundred tonnes.

One has to bear in mind a comment by Mr Justice Woodward elsewhere in the report that he could not undertake an exhaustive inquiry into all the malpractices that might be identified, one reason being that he had to report. There is no implied criticism of the Government in that, because it was important for the sake of the industry that he bring in a report of substance as quickly as possible. However, he admits himself that his report is not exhaustive in that sense. The report continues:
Another area of malpractice which has caused particular concern, because of its potentially very serious repercussions in a vital market, has been that involving halal slaughter and certification.

Evidence given to the Commission in private sittings (because of the sensitivity of the subject) showed conclusively that industry arrangements for securing proper religious slaughter and certification for Muslim markets have not worked.
I can only say that I hope the sensitivity of the market has not been what has deferred a proper investigation of this in the past. The report continues:

There have been widespread abuses of the system by industry, considerable inefficiency on the part of the major Muslim group claiming to ensure the religious nature of the slaughter and some corruption among Muslim slaughtermen. Costs to the industry have been far too high.
Government authorities have, naturally enough, been reluctant to become involved in religious matters, but it is now clear that, up to a point, they must.
Indeed they must for the sake of our industry. The report continues:
The final issue which I need to deal with in this summary of malpractices relates to the corruption of government officials.

The most disturbing evidence to emerge from this inquiry has concerned bribery and corruption of a number of DPI meat inspectors and some DPI veterinary officers and Australian Federal Police officers. It is impossible to avoid using words such as 'bribery and corruption' in this context, although it is important to understand that, with a few exceptions, the value of bribes was not substantial and the corresponding neglect of duty not heinous.

In many cases the bribe has taken the form of valuable quantities of free meat or very cheap meat not available to employees of the meatworks concerned. In a number of cases cash payments or fraudulent overtime claims have been involved. In each of the cases I have in mind, there has been a regular, valuable benefit on which no tax has been paid.
Sometimes such benefits have been extracted from unwilling operators by the abuse of inspectors' powers.

Most often the meat has been given, or the payments made, to ensure that the meatworks will not be subject to unusually vigorous supervision by inspectors- that it will be treated at least as leniently as its competitors.

However in some cases payments were made to ensure that a blind eye was turned to clearly improper practices. In the case of police officers, and a senior meat inspector, meat was given and payments were made respectively in order to secure advance warning of troublesome inquiries.
That might explain the inconclusiveness of some of the files referred to earlier . The Royal Commissioner adds:

The really disturbing feature of these revelations was that the people concerned were not evil-many of them would have been regarded as reliable and effective officers. They were ordinary Australians, in positions of some responsibility, who were either demanding, or at least accepting, clearly improper payments which could only have the effect of compromising them in the performance of their duties. The surprisingly widespread nature of these abuses suggests the need to watch all areas of government licensing and control where the decision of an inspector on the job, or similarly placed official, can make a significant commercial impact on persons in business.

Mr Justice Woodward apparently felt that he could not make the comment that I would like to make now. The surprisingly widespread nature of these abuses suggests to me that such abuses had obtained for a very long time.

I conclude by saying that I urge the Government to take all appropriate action to implement this report and to continue to maintain the priority that it has given in the last 12 months to making sure that the reputation and conduct of the Australian beef industry are beyond reproach. Speed is essential. I can only hope that the political furore with which the Opposition has chosen to surround this report will not cloud its real substance, value and urgency for the Australian meat industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —One hopes that this evening, or within the next few sitting days in this place, we will have the final round in the saga of the great Australian meat export racket. Certainly no one hopes more than I do that this is the case. It is rather interesting now to retrace the history of this saga and reflect on what I said when I first raised the matter in this place on 7 March 1978. In part, I said, as recorded in Hansard of that date:

SPEECH.PARA: Over a period of time a number of meatworks, some of which have Commonwealth registration to slaughter for export and others of which do not have this registration have been processing meat for export which has not been inspected by Commonwealth meat inspectors. Some of this illegally processed meat destined for export can be of inferior quality. What has been occurring is that this meat which is not inspected for export has been brought into registered export works, the packaging has been changed, the meat has been stamped illegally with a Commonwealth stamp made without the knowledge of the meat inspector, and then it has been sent overseas. The most obvious reason for such an operation is to maximise profits for the processors.

On the following day, in another place in answer to a question the then Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Sinclair) said in part, as recorded at page 507 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 8 March:
It would seem that there is no basis now for Senator Primmer's allegations.

I go back a little further than the date when I initially raised this matter. Last Saturday morning, going through my in tray, in my office in Warrnambool, I found a letter. It was from the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, and was dated 21 November 1977. It was written to a Mr Alexander of 45 Erin Street, Richmond, Victoria. As I understand it, Mr Alexander was at that time a councillor on the Richmond City Council. It would appear that he had some knowledge of what was going on at a certain meat establishment somewhere in that region. Interestingly enough, the letter showed that people high in authority in this country knew about this malpractice long before I did. I quote in part from Mr Sinclair's letter to Mr Alexander, dated 21 November 1977:
Dear Mr Alexander,

The Prime Minister has passed your letter of 21 October 1977, concerning allegations of export of offal from an unregistered establishment and its possible contamination with salmonella organisms, for direct reply on his behalf .

That, in my view, proves beyond all doubt that the Prime Minister of Australia as well as the then Minister for Primary Industry were made aware of what was going on in at least one establishment in Melbourne some four of five months before I raised the matter. It is also worth noting that Mr Alexander had written to the Prime Minister on 21 October and it took a month before he received a reply-a month in which no action whatsoever was taken. I seek leave to have a copy of that incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MINISTER FOR PRIMARY INDUSTRY AND LEADER OF THE HOUSE
Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600 Telephone (062) 72 6661, (062) 73 1711; Telex 62308
100 William Street, Potts Point, N.S.W. 2011 Telephone (02) 357 2492, (02) 357 2341 21 November 1977 Dear Mr Alexander,

The Prime Minister has passed your letter of 21 October 1977, concerning allegations of export of offal from an unregistered establishment and its possible contamination with salmonella organisms, for direct reply on his behalf .

My Department views such allegations with grave concern, particularly because of the export trade and public health implications. Similar complaints made in Melbourne in recent months are already being investigated by the Commonwealth Police.

The Bureau of Animal Health, which is responsible for the export inspection of meat and meat products, is aware of your correspondence with Colonel McArthur of the Australian Meat Board on this matter and has passed this information on to the Commonwealth Police. I am grateful for your offer to make yourself available during any investigations and the Commonwealth Police will be advised accordingly.

Finally I would like to thank you for your interest and assure you that my Department, with the Commonwealth Police, will take appropriate action to substantiate or otherwise, the allegations you have made.
Yours sincerely, (Ian Sinclair) Mr A. Alexander,
45 Erin Street,
Richmond, Vic. 3121

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately we are not privileged to know exactly what Mr Alexander said to the Prime Minister in his letter but, as I have said, it is proof positive that both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry knew all about what was going on. Yet, the Minister for Primary Industry could later suggest that I was making wild assertions. That statement can be found at page 508 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 8 March 1978 .

SPEECH.PARA: A study of Hansard over the period will show that several members of the Opposition in this place asked questions relating to this matter. They included Senators McLaren, Keeffe, McClelland, Gietzelt and me. Again, nothing happened. I expressed the view that Ministers, departmental heads and the Australian Federal Police were adopting an ostrich-like pose-they put their heads in the sand and hoped like hell that the problem would go away. Of course, it did not. It became worse with the export at a later date of substituted meats. Then, a little over 13 months ago, the dam burst due to the vigilance of the American authorities. By that time we had another Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon . It is interesting, in the light of the findings of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, particularly paragraphs 1.62 and 1.64 wherein the Royal Commissioner fingered Mr Nixon, to look back at what Mr Nixon had to say about yours truly in another place on 16 September 1981. In reply to some matters raised by the honourable member for McMillan, Mr Cunningham, on page 1415 of the House of Representatives Hansard Mr Nixon, in part, had this to say:
Senator Primmer does not come out of this smelling like roses by any means for the part he has played.

Other Ministers have complained that I declined to name the source of my information, and I did. Interestingly enough, the only people who asked me to name my source of information were from the media. The then Minister, Mr Sinclair, any of his officers, or the Australian Federal Police did not ask me for that information. Surely Mr Nixon did not believe that I was going to blurt out across the media of Australia, to all and sundry, the names of my informants particularly at a time when those people were attempting to buck a very corrupt system in operation at that time. Surely Mr Nixon must realise that had I done that, those persons' jobs would have been jeopardised and their future and the future of their families would have been thrown to the wolves. Surely Mr Nixon knows, surely every member of parliament knows, that there are times when members of parliament, like members of the Press, are given information in strict confidence, on the strict understanding that the source of the information shall remain a secret.

I can recall one other experience some years earlier when I was placed in a similar situation. I was given highly confidential information on exactly the same understanding-that I would not release the source. That was when a Labor government was in office. When the Minister responsible became aware of the information he immediately called me to his office and, after some discussions, we worked out plans and proposals whereby my informants could talk to the police without being placed in jeopardy or anybody other than the people accused in the matter being involved. As a result of that, the police were able to move in and the issue was defused. But not so with this Government. As I said earlier, there was a head in the sand attitude; they hoped like hell it would go away-that it would disappear and that they could forget about it. I ask honourable senators just to go back again to Mr Nixon's assertion that I did not come out of the matter smelling like roses; maybe I did not but I believe I came out of this matter smelling slightly more perfumed than Mr Nixon.

I return to the rackets that flourished for years under two Ministers of this Government. In an interview on Countrywide on 4 September last year Dr Rees, a veterinary officer with the Victorian Department of Agriculture, had this to say :
Because of their indifference, their lack of action over the past 3 to 4 years when officers of my Department-
That is the Victorian Department of Agriculture-

have reported to them irregularities occurring in the transfer of meat from the local market to the export market. We have drawn to their attention at least 3 cases of exporters packing local meat for export. I know that those cases have been investigated by the DPI and the Federal Police but I believe that the exporters concerned are still operating as exporters.

Surely that is proof that over a period of time the respected people in the community whom one would expect to take some action on matters such as this had failed dismally to put the proper amount of muscle, thought, time or whatever was required into investigating these rackets.

In September 1978, on Estimates Committee D, my colleague Senator Walsh raised before officers of the Department of Primary Industry the matter of the misuse of the Commonwealth stamp in meat works. As everyone seems to know, in January 1980 Mr Kelly, the Chairman of the Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection System, reported to Mr Nixon and, in that report, pointed up malpractices within the industry. In particular, at page 41, he said:
We were also told that, in many if not all cases, the 'Australia Approved' stamp-
that is, the export stamp-
was provided by works management, and if a new stamp was required, the inspectors obtained it from management.
Mr Kelly was adamant in his report when he further stated:
This practice should cease.
But again, no action was taken. The head in the sand attitude, the lethargy by the Minister prevailed, so the corruption continued.

From reading the Prime Minister's statement, put down in the other place a couple of days ago, relating to this matter-I do not know whether it is he who hates Bert Kelly or whether it is the person who wrote the statement for him-one would get the impression that Bert Kelly was rorting and racketeering, instead of being a very honest, upright citizen who had pointed out problems in the game at that trade. It seems to me that the Prime Minister, caught again in a rather funny situation in which he is prone to get caught, was prepared to go to hell and back to protect his National Country Party Ministers, to put the blame anywhere but where it actually lay.

It concerns me that this episode had to drag on for the amount of time that it has done-1977, 1978 and right through to 1981, before any action was taken, because of the lethargy, the 'don't care', 'don't give a damn' attitude that was adopted by Ministers of the Crown, by officers in the Public Service and frankly , I believe, by the Commonwealth Police Force. A friend of mine once remarked to me that the Commonwealth Police could not track a wounded elephant across a snow field. At times I think he is right. It may be that the expertise is not there within the Commonwealth Police Force; I do not know. It may be, as the Commissioner said, that some members of the Force have been rorting and racketeering and taking bribes. They may have been able to head off any thorough investigations.

All of this concerns me, because we live in what we are prone to call a democracy. There are many people in our society who would wax much more eloquent on that subject than I do, but surely none of us would have it otherwise. I believe, however, that our status as a democracy is in no way enhanced by the events and the time taken for their resolving in relation to this matter or many others that have been flourishing under the present Government in recent years. Rackets and cover-ups have become the norm under Malcolm Fraser's Administration . Ministers and departments have been disinclined to accept fully their duties to the Australian people. The full face of capitalism at its worst has been exposed for everyone to see, and it is not a pretty picture. The lucky country has become a haven for rorters and racketeers under Malcolm Fraser's Administration. The only way to resolve that is at the next general election to return a Labor Party government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. I need not remind this chamber that the meat industry is one of the great industries that helped this country get on its feet. It is one of our great primary industries. The people involved in it, at the coal-face one might say, do not really have any control over their end product or over the price that they receive for it. So when something like this happens and we have evidence that something is amiss, it is of great importance that something is done about it. When real evidence came to hand, something was done about it with the setting up of this Royal Commission. But I guess that it is a bit indicative of our society today that there is always someone who wants to make a fast buck-or, to use the imperial term, a quick quid. There is always someone who sees the possibility of abusing the system. When that happened in this industry, it cast a pall over the whole industry for the time being, until we were able to set the Royal Commission in place and start to see what it was all about. The people who saw the possibility of this quick quid and saw their way through the system just about brought this industry to its knees in a very short time.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that it is unfortunate, and it is now accepted, that a lethargy came into the Department. I suppose that it is indicative of our society. As I have said there are these sorts of people in the world. It is part of the trauma of recent times in this place where there have been indicated to us allegations of businessmen ripping off the tax system. By doing that they are ripping off you, me and every other Australian who loyally and legally, irrespective of whether he likes it, pays his tax. We hear of the padding of expense accounts. But this sort of thing happens in all sections of the community. What about the cash economy? They are the blue-collar people who, quite often working under fictitious names and working for cash only, are also ripping off the tax system. We hear about the fictitious overtime slips. So it goes on. Unfortunately, it is indicative of our society.
It is interesting that at paragraph 1.53 of the summary on page 12 of the report, the Commissioner brings home this fact when he says:

The really disturbing feature of these revelations was that the people concerned were not evil-many of them would have been regarded as reliable and effective officers. They were ordinary Australians, in positions of some responsibility, who were either demanding, or at least accepting, clearly improper payments which could only have the effect of compromising them in the performance of their duties.

That itself is the damning indictment. They were ordinary Australians doing what I guess they had come to expect as the norm in their jobs. As I have said, it is indicative of a malaise which is spreading right around our land and with which all sections of the community have to come to grips ultimately. It is a malaise that crosses political barriers. The only way in which we can overcome it is to recognise the fact that all people have to look to the common good of this great country of ours. Unfortunately, that is what the report is all about.

I wish that this chamber as well as the other place could come to grips with the problem of this general malaise. Unfortunately, we have seen an attempt to malign a Minister of the Crown. It is significant that the report is about the corruption that existed in the industry at the time, but it is also significant that most of the report is about the speed with which the Minister and the Department-most of those concerned-acted. Paragraph 1.19, on page 5, says:

Returning to the Department of Primary Industry itself, it is only fair to say that, under instructions from its Minister, it acted promptly and effectively when the meat substitution scandal erupted.
Paragraph 1.20 says:

The steps taken were drastic, but appropriate to the situation. There was some confusion as a range of new measures were hurriedly introduced. Not all the detailed rulings made amongst the pressures of that time were sensible, but the Department did succeed in restoring the confidence of the United States Department of Agriculture in a comparatively short time and without excessive disruption or cost to the Australian industry.
Paragraph 1.21 says:
Since then, and during the Commission's hearings, the Department has, for the most part, reacted promptly and appropriately to problems that have been brought to light.
Paragraph 1.61 on page 14 of the report states:
Generally such matters as were referred to Commonwealth Ministers were dealt with adequately and effectively.
In paragraph 1.13 on page 4 the Department was critical of itself. The report states:

. . . the Department in its own frank self-appraisal contained in its final submission to me. The meat inspection service, in the words of that submission ' 'has proved to be inefficient, costly, poorly managed, overstaffed and . . . in some respects corrupt''.

So we see that the bulk of this report is really complimentary to the Department . The Department came to grips with a situation when it was found, recognised its own inadequacies and saw that the problem was remedied quickly so that our meat industry would not be harmed. But one would almost think that paragraphs 1. 62, 1.63 and 1.64 were written by another person. One wonders why they were put in after all the complimentary remarks. A sentence in paragraph 1.64 has caused most of the problems and it is the one which some of the media seem to have fastened on to. It states:
In my view he--
'He' being the Minister-
did not deal with this allegation in a manner that was adequate and effective.

As I have said, this is the one sentence out of the whole report-with all its compliments, all its recognition of and the coming to grips with, the problems- on which the whole debate seems to have centred in the last few days. Of course the allegations which are referred to-I am not going to go into them in great detail-were made by the Honourable C. R. Kelly in his report. But the comments were very general; no names and no places were mentioned, and most importantly, they were unsubstantiated. There allegations were nothing really to do with the reason for the Kelly report. They rated only a very minor mention by the Honourable C. R. Kelly. In any case, the allegations of corruption did not include meat substitution; they were about corruption and malpractice, I think is the term that has been used. They were not even substantiated but only alluded to as the Honourable C. R. Kelly went about his business. They did not include meat substitution. These malpractices, these petty thefts, without excusing them, are something which unfortunately are an every day part of our lives. I guess they happen in every industry-whether it be meat taken home, toilet rolls taken home from a store in which somebody works, biscuits, or a biro taken from a place of employment. They are all malpractices which, as I say , are unfortunately part and parcel of our lives.

These are the things to which Mr Kelly alluded quite properly. Yet these are the things on which the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) was supposed to act without any evidence being forwarded when inquiries were made. As I have said: No places, no names, no substantiation. The Minister acted as best he could on the information available. Because nothing further could be done at that time on the information available, a Minister has been condemned. Indeed, it has been suggested that he should resign from his position. Unfortunately this has brought out the very much overworked phrase that we have heard recently -ministerial responsibility. Senator Martin alluded to the fact that many people who are not of any particular political persuasion have looked at this matter. I would recommend that those who keep using this hackneyed phrase should read some of the debates. Senator Peter Rae alluded to them very well in this place within the last two weeks. Unfortunately, we still seem to think that when something happens and a Minister does what he can, and even though there is no evidence, under this overworked, hackneyed phrase about which so much rot is spoken- ministerial responsibility-the Minister should resign.

Because the Department acted so quickly and harsh measures were instituted we did not lose our credibility in world markets. That is the most important thing; that is what the Department of Primary Industry is all about. From talking to people both here and overseas I found that there was more comment in the Australian Press over a period than there was in the overseas Press. Certainly the meat substitution made the Press in sections of the United States but it was only a one or two-day affair. It did carry on here, but our officers were able to put into effect methods by which the substitution could be stopped and prevented from recurring, and gain the confidence of our overseas customers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a fairly light-hearted Press overseas.

—It was very light-hearted. A lot of cartoons were made out of it and some television stars made very light of the situation. That does not mean to say that it was not a wrong situation. I am just pointing out that we have gained the Americans' confidence because of the actions that were taken by the Minister and by his Department while this inquiry was going on.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically the report is sound; that does not mean to say that it is 100 per cent correct. As I have said, certain paragraphs almost seem to have been written by someone else. Many people have taken one sentence with which to condemn the Minister yet that one sentence is not backed up by any evidence at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been given an opportunity to examine and debate what can only be described as a very sordid episode, in respect of our world trade obligations and responsibilities, a very sordid chapter in maladministration by the Fraser-Anthony Administration and a very sordid way in which public administration of an important segment of our economy has been operating for a considerable number of years. I find it almost impossible to believe that every Government spokesman in the House of Representatives and the Senate has placed himself in a position of defending the role that the Government has played and the role that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, has played in this whole unhappy chapter. As one listens to the debate one wonders where the Government gets the strength to defend what is an indefensible position. There is not a newspaper editorial anywhere in Australia that has not condemned out of hand the Fraser Government's handling of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, and the handling of the episode involving ministerial responsibilities. One finds it difficult to understand Government members complaining that the public at large understands the Government's position whereas it is clear from all the empirical evidence, all the evidence of the inquiry, and all the evidence of newspaper reaction and public disquiet, that this Government is not only on trial but also has lost the confidence of a very substantial section of Australian public opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: What I regard to be the most serious tactical mistake that the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) has made since he assumed the mantle of leadership of this country was for him to go on the public record and attack the integrity, the standing and stature, of such an eminent person as Mr Justice Woodward who is regarded not only in the legal world as a person of impeccable integrity but also by this Government, insofar as it saw fit to have him in charge for a considerable number of years of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. The Fraser Government has attacked and defamed a Royal Commissioner, who carried out the terms of reference and the task allocated to him by the Government, in an attempt to defend its own position.

This is just another example of how this Government operates. It blames everybody but itself. When it comes to questions of wages and salaries, it blames the workers. When it comes to a royal commission, it blames the commissioner. When it comes to Medibank fraud, it blames the doctors. When it comes to the Australian Dairy Corporation, it blames people unknown for spiriting between $3m and $4m from a Singapore account. What does it do when it comes to tax evasion and avoidance on a mammoth scale? One eminent person, who shall remain unnamed, suggested to me in the last few days that tax evasion is the biggest scandal to hit Australian politics this century. Of course, it blames the public servants. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) blamed the Australian Taxation Office. The Prime Minister, because of the attitude he has taken with respect to tax avoidance, when he arrived back from his overseas trip had the temerity to suggest that the deficiencies existed in his Department. Senator Durack has attempted to pass the buck down the line to the Crown Solicitor and Deputy Crown Solicitors and people who are not in a position to defend themselves. Every misdemeanour and every deficiency in public administration is, in the view of this Government, always another person's fault. Never is the elected Government at fault. It is never the persons primarily responsible. As the Australian Financial Review stated yesterday in its editorial, this is the death of responsibility. The editorial went on to refer to Mr Malcolm Fraser beginning to rewrite the convention surrounding the Australian Constitution in 1975.

If we just think about it, there is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that Mr Fraser was involved in a conspiracy with the former Chief Justice and with the Governor-General in respect of the very sordid way in which he came to office in 1975. We are aware of the conspiracy that existed in this place in 1974-75. Ministers in this Government, who were then in Opposition, admitted that they set about creating the conditions for the downfall of the Whitlam Government by the obstructionist position that they took in the years 1974-75 in forcing two double dissolutions. A government that came to power on conspiracy, deceit and intrigue has continued that process over the years. Heaven only knows what else will emerge. As I understand it, more is to come in respect of the Medibank fraud.

The Australian Medical Association, in pursuit of the elevation of the prestige of its profession and organisation, has issued statements in recent days that in the last few years something like $1,000m has disappeared from public and private health insurance funds as a result of inadequate attention to detail and leadership in respect of health care services in this country. One finds it difficult to distinguish which scandal is of greater significance than the other . I can only say that all of them are totally unacceptable to the Parliament and to the Australian people.

I cannot agree with the previous speaker that our trading reputation has been rehabilitated. Surely it has been dealt a death blow by the knowledge that Australia has been involved in a gigantic fraudulent method of meat substitution on the foreign market, as indeed it was on the domestic market, that the Australian Federal Police played an unsavoury role and that officials in the Department had an unsavoury role, according to Mr Justice Woodward's report. The Prime Minister believes that he can overcome the difficulties that the Government finds itself in in respect of this matter by suggesting that Mr Nixon took steps in 1981. In fact it was clear, as Senator Primmer pointed out when he drew attention to these matters in the early years of the Fraser administration, that it was common knowledge in Victoria that there was a degree of malpractice in the meat industry. He was scorned by Government spokesmen. When the Government's committee, headed by a former Minister in the Liberal Government, Mr Kelly, drew attention to these matters, it was suggested that somehow a word or two might have been left out of the report. This is the means by which the Government seeks to defend itself and to cast some aspersion on the integrity of the Royal Commissioner. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reports

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 6 (2) of the Australian Science and Technology Act 1978 I present reports prepared by the Australian Science and Technology Council entitled 'New Telescopes for Australian Astronomy in the 1990s' and 'Australian Science and Technology in International Co-operation and Development Assistance' . There is a brief statement in connection with the papers and I seek leave to incorporate this in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The first is a report on new telescopes for Australian astronomy in the 1990s. Australia has established an enviable international reputation for its research in the field of astronomy. Many important discoveries and contributions to knowledge and understanding of the universe have been made in this country. The report of the Australian Science and Technology Council recognises that if this high standard of research is to be maintained, new telescopes and other instruments will be required from time to time.

ASTEC has examined two projects: The construction of a radio telescope, the Australia telescope, and an Australian contribution to a multi-national space telescope project, Starlab. Honourable senators will have seen from the Budget announcements that the Government has decided to act on ASTEC'S recommendation and construct the Australia telescope. This is to be a bicentennial project to be completed by 1988 and it is appropriate that it should be a bicentennial project because the telescope will enable Australian astronomers to maintain their high international reputation and build on their past achievements. It is to be operated by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation but as a national facility. The Australia telescope will be a large radio synthesis telescope and will be constructed at a cost of $25m over six years. The sensitivity and resolution of the new telescope will be equal to or better than corresponding instruments in the northern hemisphere.

The second project examined by ASTEC is Starlab. ASTEC has recommended some public funding for Starlab and the Minister for Science and Technology recently announced that $3.33m will be made available for the Starlab project over the next two years. This will enable industry to develop and acquire the relevant new technology and in two years' time we will be in a position to decide on Australia's future participation in Starlab.

The second report of ASTEC to which I draw the attention of honourable senators is a background report on Australian science and technology in international co- operation and development assistance. The report draws together information on bilateral and multilateral co-operation, including specific science and technology agreements, and on development assistance programs.
