DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Proposed Stockman's Hall of Fame-Unemployment in South Australia-'Hansard': Use of Honorifics-Answer to Questions-Sales Tax on Wines

PROCTEXT.PARA: Proposed Stockman's Hall of Fame-Unemployment in South Australia-'Hansard': Use of Honorifics-Answer to Questions-Sales Tax on Wines
Motion (by Senator Sir John Carrick) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks in relation to a petition that I presented yesterday. I do not wish to take too much of the time of the Senate. I suppose that after the last few heady days of debates what I am going to say will be somewhat of a letdown.
—Not from this end, I assure you, Senator.

—Thank you very much, Mr President. That is very encouraging. I wish to say a few words in relation to the petition that I presented. I believe that the petition is fairly significant and fairly important. It was signed by nearly 850 people throughout Australia and they seek to have a stockman's hall of fame constructed at Longreach. The committee which was set up and which sought signatures for the petition was non-political. As a matter of fact one of the people on the committee is Mr Katter, the honourable member for Kennedy.

SPEECH.PARA: After looking at sites throughout Australia, these people believe that Longreach is the place where a stockman's hall of fame, similar to the cowboys hall of fame in Oklahoma City in the United States of America, should be built. They genuinely believe that there should be some form of a museum or other building to establish an area that people from Australia and the world can visit in order to see the basis on which our early pioneers settled this country, particularly people who lived in the west in the early days. Members of the committee, volunteers, and others are gathering material and interviewing some of the pioneers who are still alive. They believe that all of this material should be housed in the hall of fame. Might I say through you, Mr President, to the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) that the committee that has been set up to call for the construction of this hall of fame is not a committee that has just made a statement or sought signatures for a petition to be put before the Senate. The committee has been very active in the way in which it has gone about its job. At this stage, it has established a fund of $1m for the construction of the hall of fame at Longreach and the shire council in the area has guaranteed in the vicinity of $300,000 for its establishment.

Because of the way in which the committee is set up, because of the attitude of the committee, because of the way in which the committee has developed its ability to raise finance and gather support through Australia, I believe that this Government and the State governments should take some note of it. Approaching the Bicentenary celebrations I think it is important to recognise these Australian achievements. The Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt), in a letter about the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program, said that the theme was Australian achievement. It is important that this hall of fame be established and that it be established in a western area where it can provide a much needed tourist attraction. We need to establish some sort of industry in areas of unemployment. I believe that a tourist attraction such as this would alleviate the unemployment which has come about because of the downturn in the rural industries in western areas.

I believe this project should be financially supported by this Government and by a number of State governments. Many people throughout Australia believe that it is shameful that Australia does not have some form of monument, some place people can visit and see what Australia was once like. The Minister can shake his head, but people are interested in this project. They believe that there should be a stockmen's hall of fame in the Longreach area so that we can see what our pioneers did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter tonight which I first spoke about on 24 August by way of a question of the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney. The question dealt with the serious unemployment in the south-east of South Australia, which is getting worse. I did not get an answer from Senator Chaney, although he said to me on that day in answer to a supplementary question that he had no information on that matter but would check the points that I had raised and let me have a further reply. I had not had a further reply by 16 September. I then raised the matter in the adjournment debate and went on to mention quite a few other matters. I might say that I still have not had a reply from Senator Chaney about the matters that I raised. I will be dealing with them later on in my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday of this week, 21 September, Senator Jessop spoke on the adjournment. He endeavoured to refute many of the remarks that I had made. That is what I intend to address my remarks to tonight. Senator Jessop, on Tuesday, paid me the courtesy of letting me know that he would raise this matter but because of another commitment I was unable to be present in the Senate. I did not know what he said until I got the Hansard yesterday and read what he said. I asked the Opposition Whip's office today to let the Government Whip's office know and to advise Senator Jessop that I would be raising this matter tonight. Perhaps he is not here. I understood him to say today, when he was tabling a report, that he was leaving the country as leader of a parliamentary delegation. I am not sure whether he is leaving tonight or during the recess. I was hoping that I would get the call on the first reading of a money Bill, but that did not come about. So I now have to use the procedures of the adjournment to reply to Senator Jessop and set the record straight in quite a few areas.
Senator Jessop, in his opening remarks, talked about matters that I had raised. He quoted from Hansard what I had said on 16 September as follows:

We have a government in South Australia which was elected on a promise, among others, to stop the job rot and to get industry on its feet. Its claim at the time, that industry was lagging in South Australia under the then Labor Government, has been proved to be untrue by what has happened in the last three years.
That is what I said in the chamber. Senator Jessop went on to say:
I suggest that this claim cannot be supported by fact. Therefore, I regard it as an attempt to prop up the Australian Labor Party Opposition in South Australia.

The Australian Labor Party Opposition in South Australia, like the Opposition here, needs no propping up. As soon as we can have an election we will have a change of government. That is all the more reason why I should raise this matter tonight. Things may be in train by the time we resume. The writs may even have been issued in South Australia to have an election. What I am saying tonight would be of no value then because John Bannon would be the new Premier of South Australia. Senator Jessop said that he wanted to raise two matters under two headings, investment and employment. He then went on to say:
Since the election of the South Australian Liberal Government over $3 billion has been spent in that State by companies investing in projects or conducting feasibility studies.
He further said:

Those projects were identified in a publication that was produced earlier this year in South Australia under the heading 'Major Manufacturing Projects: Announced, Commenced or Completed since October 1979'.

Of course, some very important words are contained in that statement. It is all very well to announce projects. But when will we see them come to fruition? It is all very well to say that they will be commenced and that they will be completed. Then Senator Jessop said:
I have a list which indicates that 22 projects are valued at--

He gave a whole series of figures. But he did not tell us who the companies were . He made no mention of the companies, so I am unable to check them. Having read what Senator Jessop had to say, today I went to the Library and I took out a document which was put out by the Department of Industry and Commerce. It is headed 'Major Manufacture and Mining Investment Projects, June 1982'. Later on I will refer to what Mr Stone had to say about this particular document when it came out, I think in May. I will refer also to a Press release issued by the South Australian Minister for Industrial Affairs last week, which was commented upon in the Adelaide Advertiser by Matt Abraham in an article relating to State politics. I have looked through this document and find it very interesting. No doubt this is the document which Senator Jessop was using. Under the heading ' Company: Electricity Trust of South Australia, Leigh Creek, steaming coal mining expansion, implementation' we see that the total project cost will be $130m. But there is no information available on construction employment or on production employment. We all know that Mr Tonkin is not responsible for commencing the mining at Leigh Creek. It was the late Tom Playford, a Liberal Premier, who started that project. It was nothing to do with Mr Tonkin at all. It was a Labor government in office for 10 years which saw that mining venture continue. It was at the behest of a State Labor government and through the good work done by the Labor Minister for the Media, Senator Douglas McClelland, that television came to Leigh Creek. The people there could not get that from a Federal or State Liberal government. The people at Leigh Creek are very appreciative of that service.

Another mining project mentioned is the Western Mining Corporation venture at Kingston in the south-east of South Australia. No figures are given for the total cost of that project. We are told that 500 people will be employed on construction and 600 people on production. But the timing is between 1981 and 1988. So this is another project which one cannot say is coming to fruition under the Tonkin Liberal Government. I will later quote some figures from the document entitled 'Compendium of Australian Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Project No. 3 December 1981' which will prove that a lot of these things were actually put in train under the Dunstan Labor Government.

The Mannum coal mine at the Sedan site is supposed to have a total cost of $ 100m and a remaining cost of $100m. But nothing has been done in respect of this venture. I have asked Senator Carrick questions about this in the Parliament. He has told me in reply that there has been no request from the Tonkin Liberal Government to do anything about the mining of this coal at Sedan. Of course, that would no doubt be one of the projects which Senator Jessop is talking about in respect of investment in South Australia.

Preliminary studies are being carried out on the steaming coal mine at Lock, which is 130 kilometres south-west of Port Augusta. That is the stage of development of this project. We are given no figures in respect of the total cost, construction employment or production employment. Preliminary studies are also being conducted in respect of the steaming coal mine at Bowmans. Again, no figures are given in respect of this project. The document also lists the steaming coal project at Arckaringa Basin near Coober Pedy. However, we are not given figures in respect of the preliminary studies, construction and production employment. No one will argue the fact that that location was well known and might have even been found when Hughie Hudson was Minister for Mining, Minerals and Energy in South Australia in the Labor Government.

No details are given in respect of the total or remaining cost of the Cooper Basin oil and gas development. However, we are informed that construction employment is 2,000 and production employment is 800. But that is another project that was started under a Labor government. I do not think that Mr Tonkin was even in the Parliament-if he was, he was on the back bench-when the Cooper Basin got underway.

The document also lists the Honeymoon joint uranium mining venture. Senator Jessop, Mr Wilson, Mr Tonkin in particular and Mr Brown are always talking about what a great employer of labour in South Australia uranium mines will be. This is very interesting because we see that the Honeymoon location which is 75 kilometres north-west of Broken Hill will employ 45 people on construction and 36 people on production. This is a long way short of the 15,000 jobs which we are told will be involved in these uranium mines and this includes, of course, the mines at Roxby Downs. Mannahill, another uranium mining project, has been deferred because of low prices. The cost of that project is $5m, construction employment will be 50 and, if it gets underway, it will employ 25 people. This is a very interesting document from which to quote, especially when people like Senator Jessop come into the Senate chamber and talk about so-called facts. Senator Jessop more or less tried to rebut my arguments by saying that I did not have the facts.

No figures are given for Roxby Downs either in terms of the total cost, the remaining cost or construction employment. We are not told what the level of employment will be if it is recommended in the feasibility study that the project get underway. However, the document does indicate that 230 people are currently living in the Olympic Dam village. Of course, that is 230 people, not 230 employees. The document also refers to the copper project at Leigh Creek. Of course, we all know that the price of copper is rock bottom at the moment. Whilst the Government in South Australia might say it can get money out of copper if Roxby Downs is mined, we all know that copper is not a valuable proposition. That was detailed by the President of the Australian Mining Industry Council at a seminar in Canberra earlier this year. We know now that it is very hard to get orders for uranium.

Senator Jessop, Mr Tonkin and Mr Brown have put forward these pie in the sky proposals. There is not much substance in them. If they ever come to fruition the jobs will be a long way in the future. The Wallaroo Fertilizers Ltd venture is also listed in this document. The total cost of that project will be $22m and the remaining cost is $4m. No figures are given in respect of construction employment or production employment. It is important to note that it has been recently reported that the existing plant is to retrench workers in November. Therefore, I am wondering whether that project will ever go ahead and come to fruition. The Government has now decided to pay a subsidy on imported fertiliser . Many fertiliser companies in South Australia made representations begging us to oppose the subsidy paid on imported fertilisers because it will effect the jobs of local people and the sale of local fertiliser. That, again, will have some effect on whether this plant will ever come to fruition.

No figures are given in respect of the cost of the Asahi-CRA petrochemical joint venture. We are not told how many people will be employed. The document lists the possible sites for the venture as Whyalla, Stony Point or Port Adelaide. We now know that the possible site is Port Adelaide. But again this venture is an off shoot of the Cooper Basin which was developed under the jurisdiction of a Labor government in South Australia. The total cost of the soda ash and salt fields expansion at the ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd development is $100m and the remaining cost $100m. Preliminary studies are being carried out. However, this is all that is being done at the present time. This is what Senator Jessop has spoken about. No figures are given in respect of how many people will be employed to construct the project; no detail is given in respect of how many people will be employed on production when the project gets underway. We are told under the heading 'Project details' that no decision has yet been made on the project. We are told that the Stony Point operation will cost $1,000m and that the remaining cost is $1,000m. However, development has been deferred indefinately. If the project ever gets underway, it is envisaged that 1,720 people will be employed on construction and 481 people to operate it.

Everybody knows that the coal gasification project at Port Wakefield was started by the Dunstan Labor Government. Many of us have visited the project. If I had the time to do so I could go on to quote the details contained in this document. I think I have quoted a sufficient number of projects to say that Senator Jessop is quite wide of the mark in his efforts to bolster up the chances of Mr Tonkin. Last week during the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee E I was given a document entitled 'Compendium of Australian Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Pro- jects No. 3 December 1981' by officers of the Department of National Development and Energy. This document gives details of the money that was made available to look at South Australian coal fields during the period June 1978 to June 1982. Of course, the Dunstan Labor Government was in office at that time. The document also indicates that underground coal gasification is being examined during the period June 1978 to June 1985 and that the Honeymoon in situ leach uranium project commenced from January 1977. So a Labor government has the proud record of researching and commencing many of these projects. I suppose the present Liberal Government of South Australia is trying to cash in on a lot of those things and fool people who do not do research into believing that they in fact commenced these studies and encouraged companies to come to South Australia.

I would like to refer again to the documents from which Senator Jessop quoted and to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 11 September written by Matt Abraham. The article, which is headed 'Sorting out the Statistics', states:
When does 2 plus 2 equal a headache? Simple.
When it's a Government Press release containing the latest 'facts and figures' proving how well the South Australia economy is faring compared with the rest of Australia.

Such a release arrived on Monday, containing a statement from Industrial Affairs Minister Dean Brown from Canberra on the results for South Australia of the latest Federal Department of Industry and Commerce surveys on the economy.
The Press release was a neat example of a Minister, running up to an election, with a lot of job and investment expectations to fulfil, pumping out the good news with almost indecent haste.
That is what Senator Jessop was doing here on Tuesday night. The article states further:

It is an example of a political statement's being absorbed by the media without either the necessary facts to support the statement or the original survey's being immediately available to the Press, the Opposition, or even to government departments involved.
And it is an example of those figures, once issued, being enshrined into inviolable facts in political speeches, virtually within hours.
The Press release did have figures showing SA has a 19.5 p.c. slice of national manufacturing cake, an impressive performance which almost doubles the normal ratios for SA.
But what about the big rise in SA? How big was that rise over the last six months?
What figures were there to support Mr. Brown's statement that the State is moving against the national trend and there would be a 'substantial lift in employment' over the next 12 months?

TALK.START.PARA: —Premier-
—Matt Abraham goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Precious little really.
I will cite today's unemployment figures, which Senator Thomas, who is an ex- South Australian, will not like either. The unemployment figures are getting worse and worse every month.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about talking about New South Wales?
—I am a South Australian. Matt Abraham goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: 'We don't think it was. It could have possibly been but it's highly unlikely.'
Later, when referring to the Press release of Dean Brown-no doubt that is the Press release from which Senator Jessop was quoting-he said:
Once published or broadcast, the speed with which these figures become folklore is staggering.

I say again that they will not become folklore in South Australia because the people in that State are realists. As Ben Chifley used to say: 'The people take notice when their hip pocket nerve starts to pinch'. That is what is happening. I mentioned earlier that Mr Stone torpedoed these documents which were put out by a Government department-the Department of Industry and Commerce. In the House of Representatives on 22 April my colleague, Mr Hurford, drew the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to a letter written by Mr Stone. There are some very damning statements in it. I will not quote the whole letter because I intend to seek leave to incorporate in the Senate Hansard the letter which appeared in the House of Representatives Hansard. Part of that letter states:
My officers have expressed their concern about this project . . .
He was referring to the document in which all these good things that are going to happen have been set out. The letter continues:

There is, first, the question of the meaning and reliability of such estimates and their potential for misuse. I understand, for example, that not all the States have responded as fully as requested. Additionally, there are doubts about the extent to which the information received from individual authorities has the imprimatur of State Governments and, even where that might be the case, what meaning can be attached to it in advance, in some cases years in advance, of relevant State Budgetary and Loan Council processes. I believe that publication of the schedule would give any estimates therein a degree of credibility and prominence they could not possibly warrant (and should not be assisted in attaining).
That was Mr Stone's objection to the Department's action. Further, he states:

For those various reasons, therefore, I would ask that you consider carefully whether the proposed publication should proceed. As you will gather from the foregoing my own strong view is that it should not.
That letter was addressed to Mr N. S. Currie, Secretary of the Department of Industry and Commerce. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Treasury Canberra, ACT 2600 Office of the Secretary 20 April 1981 Mr N. S. Currie, C.B.E.
Secretary
Department of Industry and Commerce
Edmund Barton Building
Barton, ACT 2600
Dear Neil
PROPOSED SCHEDULE OF INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS

I understand that your Department has recently been collecting information from , inter alia, relevant State and Commonwealth authorities regarding their proposed investment in infrastructure over the next several years, and that publication of such a schedule is envisaged within the next couple of weeks as a supplement to the schedule of 'Major Manufacturing and Mining Investment Projects' relating to the private sector.

My officers have expressed their concern about this project on several occasions, but I understand the attitude of your officers to be that a decision now not to publish would be embarrassing because of undertakings given to the State authorities.

The purpose of this letter is to convey to you personally my concern about the proposed publication of these estimates. There is, first, the question of the meaning and reliability of such estimates and their potential for misuse. I understand, for example, that not all the States have responded as fully as requested. Additionally, there are doubts about the extent to which the information received from individual authorities has the imprimatur of State Governments and, even where that might be the case, what meaning can be attached to it in advance, in some cases years in advance, of relevant State Budgetary and Loan Council processes. I believe that publication of the schedule would give any estimates therein a degree of credibility and prominence they could not possibly warrant (and should not be assisted in attaining).

Of even more concern, however, are the potential difficulties which I see publication creating for the Commonwealth in its dealings with the States in the area of infrastructure financing at the forthcoming meetings of the Loan Council in May and June, and beyond. Although Cabinet has not yet completed its consideration of this matter, it is my expectation that the Commonwealth will be seeking at the forthcoming Loan Council meetings a significant re-scheduling of borrowings under projects already approved. In the longer term the pressures building up in the economy-as evidenced most recently by the December quarter National Accounts, released last week-in part as a result of resource developments, underline the point that keeping the infrastructure program within reasonable bounds will be a continuing requirement. I need hardly say that the publication in the next couple of weeks of a schedule of the sort proposed would be anything but helpful from that standpoint. I gather that investment totalling $20.8 billion has found its way into the 'committed' and 'final feasibility' categories. In my view, publication of figures of this sort, whatever caveats might be put on them, would be quickly promulgated as a 'benchmark' of the infrastructure 'task' facing the States over the next few years.

Your officers have, I believe, also pointed to a demand by private developers for such estimates as a further reason for publication. Frankly, I find it difficult, in view of the nature of the estimates and the various alternatives available (e.g. the Jackson and Associates survey of construction activity already conducted on a consultancy basis for the Department of Housing and Construction) to attach any weight whatsoever to that argument. Indeed, I would have thought that, notwithstanding the fact that there will always be businessmen eager to have the Government do market research for them at the taxpayers' expense, the added information burden on the States and relevant private developers runs quite counter to what the Government has been trying to achieve in the Review of Commonwealth Functions. This is quite apart from the question of what possible value to private developers there could be in estimates which quite clearly, under the pressure of economic events, are not going to be realized. Better, I should have thought, to have no estimates at all than to have such misleading ones as, under those circumstances, these will certainly prove to be.

I also put it to you, in all frankness, that it seems more than a little ironic that the Department of the Chairman of the Functions Review Commitee should be seeking a new role for itself as the collator of information on projected public sector infrastructure expenditures, particularly when relevant information is already available to the Commonwealth through normal Loan Council processes and at a time when the capacity of the Bureau of Statistics to undertake collections in this kind of area is being so tightly circumscribed. There is a strong smell of 'making work' about it which seems even less attractive in these times than it would in any case.

For those various reasons, therefore, I would ask that you consider carefully whether the proposed publication should proceed. As you will gather from the foregoing my own strong view is that it should not.
I should say that we have mentioned this matter to the Treasurer, who has reacted very strongly to the same effect.
I should also mention that I am forwarding a copy of this letter to the Chairman of the Public Service Board for his information.
Yours sincerely J. O. Stone Secretary to the Treasury

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I point out that those figures, which have been bandied around the country-in particular by Mr Brown-have no worth in them at all. I know full well that the electors of South Australia will not be fooled either. What I was talking about when I raised this matter in my speech during the adjournment debate last week was the desperate employment situation in the south-east of South Australia. Of course, there is unemployment all over South Australia but it is much worse in the south-east. I also mentioned in my speech that South Australia now has the lowest population of all mainland States. I think that is a real tragedy in view of the fact that in 1979 we were accused of chasing people out of the State. Whilst some people might have been leaving the State then, they are leaving in much greater numbers now under the Tonkin Liberal Government. I also said that about 300 jobs could be lost because of the shorter working week and a nine-day fortnight. The day after I spoke in the adjournment debate the Adelaide Advertiser reported that the south-east pulp mill, the Cellulose Aust. Ltd plant near Millicent, is to close and that nearly 150 jobs will go. In the Adelaide Advertiser on the same day appeared the heading 'Murray Bridge firm to cut operations'. The newspaper reported that J. I . Case (Australia) Pty Ltd which operates at Murray Bridge, my home town, is going to cut operations. We now find that it will close down altogether and that 85 people will not have a job. The same situation applies at Mannum, where what is now known as Horwood Bagshaw Ltd also has a problem. The defeated Leader of the Liberal Government in New South Wales, Mr McDonald, is now in charge of operations. The people in Mannum do not have very much confidence in him either. Mr Tonkin, when he was in Mount Gambier last weekend-he took the Cabinet to Mount Gambier to try to bolster support in that electorate-attended a civic reception. A newspaper report of the reception stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Tonkin told the reception he had urged the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, yesterday to maintain the protection of Australian timber against New Zealand imports.

He said as a result of several representations to Mr Fraser the Federal Government had delayed the signing of the Closer Economic Relationship agreement with New Zealand, which had been due to be settled in August.
The CER agreement aimed to remove some of the barriers against the importing of NZ goods, including timber.
Mr Tonkin said his hopes that South-East timber would be protected had been encouraged by the delay in signing the agreement.

That is a lot of nonsense because timber is still coming in. Despite the fact that representations have been made, both by the trade union movement in that area and by the Softwood Producers Council to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Lynch, nothing has yet been done to prevent that timber coming in. All the Department has done is to send a few of its officers to talk to their counterparts in New Zealand. Nothing has been done.

Then, of course, it is interesting to look at a headline which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser on 21 September 1982. It is interesting that Senator Jessop did not make any mention of this when he spoke. The headline states: '30 to lose jobs when Whyalla firm closes'. Senator Jessop was quite silent on that. When the Premier was in the south-east he talked about a bid to save the south-east clothing manufacturer, Fletcher Jones and Staff, which had been encouraged to come to South Australia by the Dunstan Government. The next day we found that the manager had to deny that the company was in trouble and had to claim that it was a very efficient industry. There again, Mr Tonkin has fallen flat on his face because he is trying to ginger up a lot of support for Mr Allison. I think he has just about admitted that he is a dead duck and that the seat of Mount Gambier will be represented by the Labor Party as soon as a State election is held. I turn now to the employment figures. I refer to figures which appeared in an article by Grant Nihill in the Adelaide Advertiser on 10 September. He stated :
The jobless total rose 4,400 between July and August to 50,300.
He was referring to the unemployment rate in South Australia. My State leader in South Australia, Mr Bannon, was reported as stating:
The Tonkin Government should be ashamed of the total of 50,300 unemployed in SA for the month, which was a post-war August record.

What did we see today in the figures that came out at noon? I got them from the Parliamentary Library. The figures now show that the number of unemployed has gone up by 100 in the last month. The total figure now is 50,400. It has gone up by 100 in South Australia in just four weeks. The total rate of unemployment in South Australia is now 8.4 per cent, compared with 7.7 per cent last month. There has been an increase in that month. Every month since the Tonkin Government has been in office in South Australia-since September 1979-there has been an increase in the unemployment figures in that State. In not one month has the Tonkin Government been able to reduce the figure. I ask honourable senators to compare the 8.4 per cent unemployed rate in South Australia with the Australian average of 6.7 per cent.

If we examine the figures relating to Mount Gambier we find that they are even worse. I will quote figures obtained from the Department of Social Security on the number of people in receipt of unemployment benefits. We find that in May 1980, 447 people in Mount Gambier-that is in the postcode area of 5290-were in receipt of unemployment benefits. In May of this year the number had risen to 675-an increase of 34 per cent. For the postcode area 5291-which is the other outer Mount Gambier area-in May 1980 there were 69 persons in receipt of unemployment benefit and in May 1982, 102, which is an increase of about 50 per cent in the outer area of Mount Gambier. That has happened since the Tonkin Government came to office. The next lot of figures will be worse because of the problems in the timber industry in the south-east of South Australia, which I have already spoken about. One mill has already closed down. We are in for real trouble down there, but the Government does not appear to be very concerned about it.

I refer to the building trade and the number of homes constructed. Catalogue No . 8703.0 of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, published today, shows that the number of houses approved for construction has also dropped. A total of 1,700 new dwellings were approved for construction in South Australia for the June quarter of 1981, and for the June quarter of this year only 1,400 were approved. That is a drop of 300 homes. If we look at the 1982 report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry, which was tabled in the Parliament today, we see under the heading 'Short-Term Forecasts' that private home commencements in the first three quarters of 1981-82 were well below the level for the same period in 1980-81. That is borne out by the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics published today. If we go further on in the document we see on page 82:

During 1981-82 funding made available under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement fell by 13 per cent from the 1980-81 level. However, a substantial injection of funds arranged by the State Government through the State Government Insurance Commission and the State Superannuation Fund, along with financing initiatives by the Housing Trust, has enabled a substantial increase in capital expenditure by the Housing Trust on new construction during 1981-82.

Of course the Government has to use the State Government Insurance Commission to make this money available. When the Liberal Party was in Opposition it fought the Labor Government tooth and nail when it tried to set up the State Government Insurance Commission, and now the Government is using it to help the building industry. It has been a very worth-while venture and it is one of the most viable insurance companies in South Australia. The report continues:
Private house commencements are expected to fall from 4 970 in 1980-81 to 4 400 because of the cost and restricted availability of housing loans.

So that is the answer to what Senator Jessop had to say to me in trying to rebut what I said. I always use facts when I come in here and make statements. I do not make airy-fairy statements and say that I have a document before me. I quote the document, it is there for people to check. I stand on my record of what I said here the other night. It was absolute fact and I was not trying to belittle the Tonkin Liberal Government with fictitious figures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for half an hour or anything like it. I want to raise a couple of points briefly. First of all I raise a matter with you, Mr President, about Hansard and the correction of speeches. Of course, we expect Hansard to improve our grammar and that sort of thing, but I must say I am often embarrassed when Hansard has me saying things that I did not say. For instance, I would never have referred to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as 'Senator Sir John Carrick', yet on about five occasions in a relatively short speech yesterday I am reported as having called him 'Senator Sir John Carrick'. Mr President, I wonder whether it is possible, in my case, if in nobody else's, for Hansard to be told that when I call the Leader of the Government 'Senator Carrick' he is to be so referred to in my speech because I find it rather embarrassing to have those words put into my mouth. I would appreciate it if you could investigate that matter.
—I join you in those sentiments, Senator, because I have made that request many times.
—Have you been successful?
—I have, but it seems to be creeping back in again. It might be that we have new Hansard writers who are not aware of my request.

—I would appreciate it, Mr President, if that matter could be attended to. The other matter I wish to raise refers to an answer I received on my desk yesterday from Senator Messner to a question I asked him, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, on 18 August. It is Question on Notice No. 2568. When I received that answer I was upset to discover that it had appeared in Hansard a week ago but that the copies of the question that should have preceded that publication were a week late. That is just a minor complaint that I have. My main complaint is that the answer to my question is quite ambiguous. I am seeking guidance from the Minister for Education ( Senator Peter Baume) as to what I should do next. I put an earlier question on notice to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) some months ago concerning the Minister for Administrative Services. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) What loans have been made to the Minister for Administrative Services under :
(a) the Defence Services Homes Act;
(b) the Re-establishment and Employment Act;
(c) the Loan (War Service Land Settlement) Acts; and
(d) any other arrangement involving Commonwealth funds or guarantees.
(2) When were these loans approved and by whom were they approved.
(3) What were the amounts of each loan, at what interest rates, and for what terms.
(4) How much of each loan has been repaid, and when.

I asked that question of the Prime Minister because it involved several Ministers. I think it involved three Ministers-the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Minister for Primary Industry, who has responsibility for part of one of those Acts, and another Minister. After some months I got an answer saying: 'I suggest the senator asks those questions of the Minister for Administrative Services himself'. So I did exactly that--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not exactly what it said, Senator. It said: 'I believe that it is appropriate that honourable senators approach Ministers directly'.

—I am referring to the earlier question; the question I asked some months ago. After some months the Prime Minister replied: 'I suggest the senator asks the Minister for Administrative Services himself'. I then put exactly the same question on notice to the Minister for Administrative Services. Senator Messner, on his behalf, replied:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question: (1) to (4) I believe that it is appropriate that honourable senators approach Ministers directly on questions of this nature .

I thought that was what I had done in response to the Prime Minister's suggestion, that is, as directly as we can in this place, asking the Minister representing the Minister concerned. Then I thought: Well, perhaps this answer from Mr Newman suggests that I approach the individual Ministers responsible for those Acts by a question on notice; that is, the Minister for Primary Industry, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and so on. But there is a further interpretation that suggests that perhaps I should interview Mr Newman personally about these matters, which I think would be entirely inappropriate. So rather than put the same question on notice again in some slightly different way I am seeking some guidance from the Minister as to what is meant by that ambiguous answer. It may be that Mr Newman has something to hide, I do not know. I am not suggesting that at this stage, but I think I am getting the run-around in my attempt to find out straight, factual answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too will not keep the Senate long. I wish to raise an issue concerning a constituent in Queensland -I believe this is an appropriate time to do so-which refers to an anomaly under the tax law in relation to fruit wine made from fruits other than grapes. Fruit wine is the subject of a 17.5 per cent sales tax while grape wine is totally exempt from sales tax. There is only one general commercial producer of fruit wine in Australia. It is very much a struggling industry which was pioneered by a small family concern in central Queensland. The Federal Government has been aware of this anomaly since 1977. The then Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Ian Viner, explained that the correction of the anomaly would require an amendment to the sales tax law. Regular representations seeking such an amendment have been made to the relevant Government Ministers by members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives representing all political parties. The reason given by the Government for taking no action is that it would require an amendment of the sales tax provisions. That does not seem to me to be an adequate defence or reason, particularly as the Government has had five years in which to make this minor change.

SPEECH.PARA: That takes us to last year, 1981. Senator Messner, in his capacity as the Minister assisting the Treasurer, wrote that the granting of a sales tax exemption must take account of the overall economic strategy. The letter was probably a joke because the family involved is the only producer concerned and in the financial year prior to the writing of that letter it paid sales tax amounting to $3,818-hardly, I would imagine, an amount that would have to be taken into account in considering the overall economic strategy. I suggest that this revenue is gained from the 17 1/2 per cent sales tax levied on wines simply because they are made from fruits, particularly tropical fruits other than grapes which are, after all, an imported fruit, if one wants to be chauvinistic and nationalistic about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you mean exotic.

—Yes, definitely most exotic ones are imported. The persistent refusal of the Government to make such an amendment to the sales tax laws is incomprehensible. I ask the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) to convey my request again to the Government and see whether this industry may be assisted in the same way as assistance is given to the grape industry of South Australia. I say in closing that if the Government's economic policies are dependent on $3,818 I fear not only for the small firm but for the country in general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have taken part in the adjournment debate. The answer to Senator Macklin's question is yes. He seeks equality as between varieties of wine. I am not certain that he is not asking the Government to consider as one option-I do not know exactly what he is asking-the imposition of a sales tax on grape wine. Mr President, I know that you would blanch if that suggestion were made. However, I will pass it on as requested. I thank Senator Macklin for sitting through some of the long speeches that were made, although perhaps he had no choice. I note that the first two speakers have not remained.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jones raised the question of the creation of a stockman's hall of fame. He is not present to hear my response, so I will be brief. The Government has referred the matter to the Australian Bicentennial Authority. A one-off grant of $10,000 was made in 1980 for the project and tax deductibility has been granted. I cannot blame the honourable senator for not remaining. Senator McLaren showed a remarkable propensity for driving from the chamber all who could be driven. Senator Watson was here for a while but he too gave up and left.

As for Senator McLaren's speech, I must say that it will never be a best seller . It was too long and too turgid. He said that he would stand on his record. I fear that is exactly what he will do; it is a little broken. I am sure now that the Senate acted properly in amending the Standing Orders regarding the length of adjournment speeches. The honourable senator has not remained either, so I will not address myself to the substance of his remarks.

Senator Coates raised several matters, the first of which concerned the style used in Hansard. I assume that before he came into the Senate he went to Hansard and discussed the matter. If not, I suggest that he should do so. Matters of courtesy and title are not for me to judge. It is up to him to make his own way in that regard but I suggest that he take it up directly with Hansard. In relation to his comment that the answer to a question appeared in Hansard before he was informed of it, I point out that a question on notice is one given to the Parliament. It appears on the Notice Paper of the Senate and any response made is made to the Parliament and appears appropriately in Hansard. I am glad that the honourable senator did receive a letter but would emphasise that the answer, in appearing in Hansard, appeared in the correct place.

As to the other matter raised by him, if I read correctly the question concerned it relates to the affairs of Mr Newman as an individual. It does not refer to the portfolio of Administrative Services. Nor, I believe, does it refer to Mr Newman's administrative functions or duties. It refers to personal matters affecting Mr Newman as a returned soldier and to benefits that he may have obtained as a result. I would suggest that that is no more the business of the Parliament than would be the private affairs of any other veteran who had served his country and had taken advantage of, to use the examples given by the honourable senator, the Defence Services Homes Act, the Re-establishment and Employment Act, the Loans (War Service Land Settlement) Acts and any other arrangements involving Commonwealth funds or guarantees. I have no knowledge of whether Mr Newman is or is not taking advantage of the provisions of those Acts. He certainly may have an entitlement under them as someone who has served his country with distinction in military forces. It is entirely proper that if there be a tradition of not making public what individual citizens may have obtained by way of war service loans and the like, it should be followed in this case also. Thus the answer is appropriate. If the honourable senator wants to learn what Mr Newman is receiving I suggest that he ask him personally.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Since Senator Coates did direct part of his remarks to me, I assure him that I will take up the matter he has raised and endeavour to obtain a response for him.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.47 p.m., until Tuesday, 12 October, at 1.45 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much does the Government pay to A.G.C. Ltd to lease the upper floor of the building at 159 Collins Street, Hobart, as offices for parts of the Department of Social Security.
(2) What would the purchase price of the building have been.
(3) Why did the Government decide not to buy the building but to lease part of it instead.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The current rental is $50,116 per annum.
(2) Following its conversion to office accommodation it is understood that the property was purchased by private interests for $1,027,755 in August 1979.

(3) The Government considered buying the building for Archives purposes prior to its conversion to office accommodation. The building is not considered suitable for purchase for Government office accommodation purposes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American schoolchildren and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I assume that the question relates to the unauthorised use of computers which permit communications access from an acoustic coupler or a remote dial-up facility. I am aware that it is possible to access some computers in this manner .
(2) No. The computers in my Department do not permit access in this manner.
(3) The Department's computers do not permit access in this manner.
(4) Not applicable.
(5) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Commonwealth cars and drivers were brought from Sydney to Canberra during the week ending 20 August 1982.
(2) Why did this transfer occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 16 Commonwealth cars and drivers.

(2) The Commonwealth cars and drivers were transferred from New South Wales to assist the Australian Capital Territory Commonwealth car-with-driver fleet to meet the projected demands of Parliament and other VIP activities during the first week of the Budget session of Parliament. The number of available drivers in the Australian Capital Territory was 10 less than the same period in 1981 due to resignations and leave. The demand was an estimated 8 more cars than normal for Parliament and 8 for a conference of Police Ministers and Commissioners being held in Canberra at the time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the original version of the Film Australia production On Sacred Ground been edited to a shorter version.

(2) Have scenes critical of the Government of Western Australia or any footage of Western Australian State Government Ministers been removed from the original version to produce the new shorter version.
(3) Was the new shorter version produced at the suggestion of a Federal Minister; if so, which Minister.
(4) Is the new shorter version of the film, unlike the original version, to be granted approval for overseas distribution and sale to television.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In early 1982 Film Australia re-edited the 58 minute version of On Sacred Ground to 48 minutes, which is the length required for commercial television programming in Australia.
(2) No. The scenes removed when the film was re-edited were mainly lengthy explanations considered too drawn out for television audiences.
(4) The new shorter version is available for sale to television in Australia. No decision has been made at this stage to offer it for sale to overseas television networks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Federal Government funding has gone to the provision of homes for aged Aboriginals in 1980-81 and 1981-82.
(2) Has any provision been made for this item in the 1982-83 Budget.
(3) What proportion of allocations for this item has gone to New South Wales in 1980-81 and 1981-82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Aboriginal Hostels Limited has indicated that it allocated $456,915 in 1980 -81 and $569,563 in 1981-82 for the accommodation of aged Aboriginals. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs spent $289,150 in 1980-81 in grants-in-aid for the housing of aged Aboriginals. The Aboriginal Development Commission, which took responsibility for housing grants-in-aid from 1981-82, has not made separate grants for aged person housing. It provides funds to Aboriginal housing associations to build or buy houses, some of which are used to accommodate aged persons.
(2) Aboriginal Hostels Limited plans to spend an estimated $877,304 on the accommodation of aged Aboriginals in 1982-83.

(3) None of the expenditure on housing for aged Aboriginals by Aboriginal Hostels Limited has been in New South Wales. Of the 1980-81 expenditure by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, $43,000 was spent in New South Wales.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What role is the Commonwealth Government playing in the proposal emanating from the West Australian Department of Fisheries and Wildlife to establish a numbat captive breeding colony in Perth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government is not directly involved with the proposal to establish a numbat captive breeding colony in Perth.

I am advised that the proposal to which Senator Mulvihill refers was submitted in June 1981 by the West Australian Department of Fisheries and Wildlife to World Wildlife Fund Australia for financial support and has been given a high priorty in the 1982 Conservation Program.
The Commonwealth has contributed to the World Wildlife Fund.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1982 Senator Townley asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the following questions without notice, relating to the proposed code of conduct for the Commonwealth Games:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) Has the Minister seen the document?

(ii) Is it true that the New Zealand Commonwealth Games Committee has refused to sign the code because it feels that to do so would be overstepping its authority as it says the code applies to sportsfolk outside its jurisdiction?
(iii) Is it true that, if the Australian Commonwealth Games Committee signs that code, it may well be to the detriment of many sporting Australians?
(iv) Why should such a group and indeed any group be able to dictate to other sportspeople?

(v) Will the Minister arrange for the code to be released to the public so that we can have some discussion of the issues and so on that may result from the signing by Australia, behind closed doors, of a code that may well be used to apply pressures to people who in no way are involved with the Commonwealth Games?
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

(i) No. The code of conduct is part of proposed revisions to the constitution of the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF). The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has been advised by the Australian Commonwealth Games Association that the code has only been distributed to national Commonwealth Games Associations prior to planned meetings of the CGF General Assembly in Brisbane on 27 September 1982 and 6 October 1982.

(ii) Recent Press reports indicate that the New Zealand Olympic and Commonwealth Games Association does not support the introduction of a code of conduct into the constitution of the Commonwealth Games Federation since the New Zealand Olympic and Commonwealth Games Association and its affiliated members are already fully committed to support both the principle and the letter of the Gleneagles Agreement.
(iii) As I am not privy to the content of the code I am unable to answer this question.
(iv) As I am not privy to the precise nature of the code I am unable to answer this question.
(v) The code of conduct has only been made available to affiliates of the Commonwealth Games Federation and is not available for public comment.
